speechtext: Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 34(1) I have the honour to present, in both official languages, the report of the Canadian delegation to the first parliamentary assembly of the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe held between July 2 and July 5, 1992 in Budapest.

Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to present a petition on behalf of a number of constituents from Clearwater, British Columbia. They point out their strong opposition to a company's intention to divert water from the North Thompson River and eventually sell that water in San Diego, California.
They simply ask the government to introduce legislation that would prohibit Canadian waters from being sold to the United States as a commodity like coal or copper.

Madam Speaker, on another matter, petitioners from throughout western Canada are simply asking Parliament to ensure that we maintain the current level of services provided to veterans through the Veterans Independence Program and to ensure there are no increases in charges to veterans for
board and lodging in those long-term care institutions in which veterans are resident.

Madam
Speaker, it is my honour to present thousands of signatures on petitions today. These signatures are from every part of Canada. We have over 500,000 that have been presented on the same topic.
The petitioners believe there are serious deficiencies in the criminal justice system. Women, children, and disabled persons are particularly vulnerable.
They also believe that crimes of violence against persons are intolerable and constitute the most abhorrent crimes society faces.
They ask Parliament to recognize that crimes of violence against persons are serious and abhorrent to society and to amend the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act, 1972, and the Parole Act accordingly.

Madam Speaker, it is my duty and pleasure, pursuant to Standing Order 36, to present several petitions totalling more than 100 names and asking Parliament to urge the minister of immigration to issue minister's permits for spouses and dependent children of refugee claimants who have been permitted to apply for landing from within Canada, including persons in the backlog and persons accepted under the new legislation, and to allow them to be reunited in Canada for inland processing.

Madam Speaker, I have two other petitions. One is a petition of 36 names mainly from the community 680 Queen's Quay West, a government assisted housing project.
The petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to recognize housing as a shared provincial-federal responsibility, to support the federal non-profit co-operative housing program, and to maintain the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation.

September 10, 1992
Routine Proceedings THE CONSTITUTION

Madam Speaker, I have a petition from 508 persons from various parts of Toronto, including some within Trinity-Spadina who have asked me to present it. They are concerned about the preamble to our Constitution which affirms that our country is founded upon principles that acknowledge the supremacy of God and on respect for moral an, spiritual values.
They point out that about four million Canadians do not believe in God or are unsure and the ones who do, disagree on the nature and desires expressed by God and that for many Canadians freedom is founded on secular values rather than spiritual values.
Therefore they request that Parliament remove references to God and spiritual values from the Constitution, ensure that the Constitution is a secular document that defines religious belief or unbelief as the right of the individual, and that the Constitution forbids the state any religious endorsement.

Madam Speaker, the petition I have the pleasure of placing before you today is from Canadians from across the country.
They are urging the government not to proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22 which was passed in 1987 so that Canadians will have the full benefit of lower priced generic drugs and so the provincial and private drug plans can serve Canadians without being forced to charge higher fees and/or provide less coverage.

Madam Speaker, I rise today to present a petition signed by over 125 residents of northwestern Ontario, rural Thunder Bay and Thunder Bay.
These petitioners are concerned about what they see as a direct attack on the rural way of life: cuts to VIA, abandoning the rail lines, neglect of fishery, forestry and agriculture, and erosion of rural postal service, particularly the closure of small rural post offices.
They humbly pray and call upon Parliament to support Canada's rural way of life, to support the maintenance of rural post offices and postal services and to reject the Conservative government's agenda of cutbacks and closures.

Madam Speaker, I
rise to present a petition signed by several hundred Canadians from the provinces of British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec.
They point out that the price of both new and existing drugs has increased substantially to individuals on provincial and private drug plans since the passage of Bill C-22 in 1987. They call upon this government not to proceed with Bill C-91 and to repeal Bill C-22 in order that Canadians may benefit from generic competition.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to present a petition pursuant to Standing Order 36. This petition originates in Toronto and across the country.
Whereas the incidence of violence against women and children is unacceptable, the undersigned petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to accept legislation designed to eliminate violence against women and children. As in duty bound your petitioners humbly pray.

Madam Speaker, I also have a number of petitions signed by over 2,600 Canadian seniors from all across Canada indicating that hundreds of Canadian senior citizens live below the poverty line, that it is desirable for all Canadians to provide senior citizens with the necessary support to live their lives as independently as possible, and that the federal government has the primary responsibility to ensure the adequacy of seniors' pensions.
Therefore the petitioners call upon Parliament to urge the government to ensure that Canadian Old Age Security pensions are sufficient to meet the basic needs of Canadian senior citizens.

Madam Speaker, I too have a petition to present pursuant to Standing Order 36. It is signed by hundreds of constituents in my riding of Broadview-Greenwood who have
September 10,1992

indicated that the incidence of violence against women and children is unacceptable.
They are calling upon this Parliament to accept legislation designed to eliminate violence against women and children.
They are asking for special effort in the training of police, lawyers, court workers and judges to become knowledgeable about women and child abuse and to focus public attention on this very important and long ignored problem.

Madam Speaker, in cooperation with my colleague from the great riding of Cardigan, under Standing Order 36 I would like to present petitions on behalf of seniors from the province of Prince Edward Island and across Canada who have been offered a 37-cent increase in their old age pensions.
This is basically a reaction from the seniors about the niggardly amount of money that the government seemed fit to give people who are in need, most of whom are single women.
They humbly pray that Parliament take into consideration seriously this petition from the seniors of Canada.

Speaker, I rise today under the provisions of Standing Order 52(1), of which I gave you notice, to seek leave to adjourn the House in order to debate a matter of national importance.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is really a wonderful moment for our country and our people. It represents with the prospect of a Canada-wide direct vote on the constitutional amendments a new partnership between Parliament and those who send us here.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
We have seen a long history in this country of efforts to make major changes that have not involved the people directly. A century and a quarter ago Sir John A. Macdonald refused the appeal in 1866 of some 20 members of Parliament from Canada East, Quebec, who petitioned for a mandate from the people prior to implementing the confederation plan. What we saw was the development of a feeling against the plan, particularly in Nova Scotia, that led to successionist movements. There has been a long period throughout our history of trying to have the people involved in major changes.
Robert Borden wanted a plebiscite in 1914 on the question of Senate reform. There was no legislation in place for that and he lost his moment of opportunity and no such vote was possible. Prime Minister Trudeau, a decade ago, sought a national referendum in relation to constitutional amendments, but he was neither able to get his legislation through Parliament in spite of two efforts bringing it before the House, nor was he able to get the agreement of the premiers to such a process.
Today for the third time in our history there will be a national plebiscite, but for the first time in our history it involves the Constitution.
I have no doubt whatsoever that the success that has been possible in negotiating this current comprehensive package of amendments to our Constitution was possible because in June of this year Parliament passed the enabling legislation, the Canada Referendum Act. This act made it very clear to all who gathered in Charlottetown that if they were unable to come to an agreement there was another avenue open, namely that the government could proceed with the support of Parliament in going directly to the people.
We have crossed an important threshold in our country. We are now in a period of transition in which the people are becoming much more directly involved in the process of fundamental change. I note that the promise in the May 13, 1991 throne speech by the government has been fulfilled. At that time, it was said that the men and women of Canada would be asked to participate directly in the process of constitutional change.
I am personally very happy to rise to speak in this debate. I have read all the Hansard accounts of the 1898 debate on the Dominion Prohibition Plebiscite Act of that year and also the debates that took place in Parliament in 1942 on the plebiscite relating to conscription for overseas military service.
In 1942 the Prime Minister of the day realized, having made a clear promise in the 1940 general election and having received a mandate from the people based on that promise, that he could not within two years reverse the position that had come from the people in a clear mandate without going back to them.
That certainly, when we are on the subject of mandate, is fundamental in a democracy. The far-reaching constitutional changes that are now proposed have never been discussed in a general election either nationally or provincially. There is no conceivable way that this whole package, as it is now put together in a new 1992 statement, could be said to have been contemplated by the Canadian people or discussed by them as the comprehensive package that it is.
It is absolutely important and vital in a democracy that the people be part of the process and that they give after deliberation a mandate with respect to this package.

The Prime Minister told this House in his speech that the Canadian model was used for the Australian constitution. In 1900, way back at the beginning of this century, the Australians decided that any amendment to their constitution would have to be ratified by the people. Therefore they added to their fundamental law specific provisions to that effect and, on 32 occasions since the beginning of the century, when changes to the constitution of Australia were contemplated, the people of that country were called to the polls to vote on them. In eight cases the proposals were ruled satisfactory by the majority and ratified, but they were voted down in every other instance.
I suggest that is how democracy should work. If the majority of the people cannot be convinced of the relevancy of a proposed change to the supreme law of the land, there is no legal or moral way it should be adopted. The rationale behind this is that democracy operates basically through consensus among citizens, not through coercion. If a majority of citizens cannot be induced to support a given position, the country will be in deep trouble, and in time the schemes the political leaders devise to put new deals together without getting the public on board will get the country in trouble. As a matter of fact, the present feeling of disillusionment created by governments and politics in Canada is largely due to the fact that for 20 years or so major innovative policies have been put in place without first gaining the
September 10, 1992

support of the people and reaching a consensus, which is a necessity in a democracy.
A direct vote from the people preserves the commitment principle in that the responsibility involved in the decision-making process rests with the people of Canada themselves.

The coming campaign for the direct vote on October 26 will be like a national teach-in. Canadians have listened for several decades now to discussion about constitutional change but it was always in orbit, distant from them. The fact that now every citizen of our country knows that he or she will have to mark a ballot indicating yes or no to these proposed amendments will focus their attention and give real meaning to citizenship in our country.
In his speech on Tuesday the Prime Minister said that the question on the ballot is in fact a proxy for many other profound questions about who we are and where we are going. That indeed is the process of the campaign that will now unfold as we debate sincerely, and with differences, from different perspectives and backgrounds who we are as a Canadian people.
This exercise of self-definition will be a transforming element in our country. We have passed the stage, happily, in which those who govern believed that they could patch together fundamental changes. Perhaps fearing the fragility of something Scotch taped on here and held with a paper clip there they end up as if they are walking on eggs and not really wanting to let people see it or examine it too closely or breathe on it. Certainly they would never have put it out so that there could be intense public debate on it over a four, five or six week period, as in a national plebiscite campaign.
We are now past that stage. The people are partners with those of us in Parliament and the provincial legislatures in dealing with this question. Indeed, all we are really debating in Parliament at this stage is the wording of the question and the process. The real decision now, through the conclusion of the campaign, will be with the Canadian people themselves. That proves that we have
Government Orders
come to the point of recognizing that constitutions belong to the people and not to governments.
Indeed, when Her Majesty spoke in our capital on July 1 she mentioned that constitutions are not simply written documents on parchment but must, if they are to be effective and meaningful, live in the hearts and in the minds of the citizens. Therefore, we now come to examine what citizenship is really all about in 20th century Canadian parliamentary democracy.
There have been several criticisms that have been directed to this process which I would like to address. One is that it is an abdication of responsibility by Parliament and the legislatures.
Second, people do not know enough about the issue to cast an intelligent vote.
Third, the cost of this process is too great.
Last week when I was being interviewed on CFRB about this process several callers phoned in with that very comment. They said: "We elected you to be in Parliament and decide these issues. Why is the government bailing out? You are ducking responsibility".
We have not heard the other side of that coin so much this time, but certainly in 1942 and 1898 parliamentarians said: "I was sent here to decide issues. I was elected. We cannot just take these things back to the people all the time". All the time? This is the third time in our history that we are doing it.
Perhaps the best statement of all dealing with that concern was made by the finance minister, a Nova Scotian, in 1942 when speaking in that debate after many people had criticized the government of Mackenzie King for lacking the courage to deal with the issue in Parliament and taking it to the people. In fact, I quoted what the finance minister, J. L. Ilsley, said in the House of Commons in my new book, The People's Mandate, on this very subject. Here is what he said in February 1942 in justifying a national plebiscite: "Surely the cowardly government or Parliament is the one which fears to ascertain the views of the people". Ilsley said that it was far more an act of leadership to define the issue and then

September 10,1992
Government Orders
to go to the people and defend it and explain, in partnership with the people, what was intended.
On that same point a former Prime Minister of Canada, Arthur Meighen, wrote in 1937 about the fact that about 98 per cent of what goes through Parliament did so without ever having a mandate from the people. They came from the ordinary grind of government and public business, detailed amendments to statutes and changes in the tax act and so on. However Meighen went on to make, in terms of the popular mandate and support from the people, a very important exception. He said that any legislation that would "affect positive principle going to the root of our institutions" ought only to proceed when there is a clear mandate from the people.
No one could read the comprehensive package of amendments negotiated at Charlottetown and then suggest that they did not constitute legislation or change going to positive principle of our country. They most assuredly do. Therefore, there is very clearly an answer here to this criticism that Parliament is somehow ducking its responsibility by going to the people. I see it as Ilsley did, as a high act of national leadership and partnership.
Just to briefly mention those final two criticisms. First, that people do not know enough about it to answer the ballot question. That is precisely what the next four, five or six weeks are all about. We will have a national teach-in and all Canadians and certainly we parliamentarians have the duty and responsibility to share that information. We will go through an exercise of self-definition of who we are as Canadians that will be very valuable.
Finally, as for the cost. I would point out that the largest element of cost concerns the preparation of the voters' lists. It should be borne in mind that the voters' lists prepared for this national direct vote will be used in next year's general election campaign, simply being revised for that purpose. Therefore, the cost of that election will be significantly reduced. Those are the accounting principles.
On the broad question of value to a democracy we have now come to a moment that is historic for our country and I am glad to be able to rise and support this initiative.

One hundred and
twenty-five years young, Canada is a new country, a country with promise, a country that is the envy of the world. Today we are called upon, as citizens of this great country to say yes to a chance for constitutional renewal, to a chance for rebirth and to a chance to get our country working again.
I am proud to live in a country built with the tolerance and generosity that is the envy of the world. Aboriginal people, French, British and yes, Irish and other settlers, immigrants from all over the world have built a country that we call home.
[Translation)
Aboriginals, people of French or English descent, immigrants of every country in the world, together we have created a nation envied by all.
Last Monday, 17 Romanians were found hidden in a container in the port of Antwerp, trying to sneak into Canada. Why? As they said themselves: "Because Canada is an ideal country".

On October 26, we will be called to reaffirm our faith in this country of ours. Faith in a country that has given her children opportunities. Faith in a country that saw the children of the Great Depression, not educated, not having the same opportunities as my generation, raising families that can be the best they want to be. Faith in a country that over generations has struggled with linguistic differences but has bridged them. That is what makes us unique as a people. We are not pseudo-Americans. We do not believe that to be equal you have to be the same.
In this particular debate we will set aside political differences, partisan differences to stand up for Canada. We will have to work hard together, New Democrats, Liberals, Conservatives, and believe me, for me that will be difficult. But we will have to work together to convince those who have doubts that it is worthwhile to live together in honourable compromise.
You may be tempted to ask on the ballot: "What is in it for me?" But I know that Canadians in the final analysis will set aside individual self-interest to ask: "What is in it for Canada?" This deal does not solve all our problems. It does not guarantee gender equality. It does not give the homeless a place to sleep. It does not solve forever
September 10, 1992

all linguistic tensions and it does not guarantee racial equality.
But the bottom line is this deal makes sure that we will have a country so that we can build to bridge those differences. We will have a Canada to work out those problems.

Our challenge in the next 50 days is to convince Quebecers to say yes to Canada and to convince Canadians outside Quebec to say yes to Quebec.
I am not afraid to tell Quebecers: "Yes, you are a distinct society and I am proud of it."
We must convince native people to say yes to Canada and other Canadians to say yes to native people.

To people in my great city of Hamilton you may ask: "What is the point?" There is a point. On October 26 every citizen in the city of Hamilton will have a chance to say: "Yes, I want self-government of the aboriginal people to be a fundamental part of my Constitution. I want the capacity of francophones to speak their language enshrined in the Canadian Constitution. I want to say yes to Quebec. I want you as part of my Canada and I want the west and the Atlantic provinces to feel that they too have a share and a stake in our society".
I fear in my own area the fight may not be between yes and no, but the fight may be between those who will vote and those who will stay home. When you are called to vote and fight for your country, it is not the time to stay home. Therefore, I urge you to circle October 26 and get out to vote.
When we recognize someone else's rights we do not lose, we all win. By empowering others we become stronger, not weaker. Ontario will be stronger in a stronger Canada. The west and Atlantic Canada will also become stronger, and a stronger Quebec makes a stronger Canada.

I am asking Quebecers to say yes to Canada, to a Canada they have built themselves throughout the centuries. Tomorrow's challenges will be met by those who speak more than one language. They will be met by
Government Orders
those who can live in peace and co-operate with their neighbours.
We hear a lot about Europe 92. I was there last summer and I now realize that Europe 92 is what we have known in Canada for centuries. What we have here are people who can get along in any language. We already have two official languages. We have in Canada people who speak all sorts of languages. This agreement is not perfect, but it is unanimous.

I too was one of those who thought it could not happen. I wondered whether Atlantic Canadians, Quebecers, westerners and Ontarians could sit at the table and reach a unanimous agreement.

This unanimous constitutional agreement is living proof that we can live side by side and make the compromises necessary to get along in this country in spite of all our differences.

This referendum gives us a chance as Canadians to explore our heritage of tolerance and generosity and to build upon it. We are a living example of what many countries in the world could not do: different people, different languages, different cultures living together peacefully and respecting our differences. We are sending a powerful signal to the world. On October 26 the world is going to be watching whether that signal will remain as clear and vibrant as it has been for the last 125 years.

I agree with the Prime Minister when he says that this is an opportunity to say yes to Canada and to be an example for the rest of the world. I agree with the Leader of the Opposition when he says that it is essential to give the Constitution back to the people through this referendum. I also agree with the Leader of the NDP who says that this vote is a vote for all of Canada.

This deal recognizes the rights of minorities to feel at home wherever they live in this country. Whether you are an anglophone in Quebec or a francophone anywhere in Canada you are home.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders

You are home, that is exactly right. This is what we have accomplished. We have gained something for Quebec. We have also gained something for Canada by recognizing aboriginal rights. We recognize the balance between the different regions which have developed since the foundation of this country. We recognize a basic fact, namely that French is not simply an insigni-cant historic detail in this country.

This Constitution guarantees forever that French is not a simple footnote in our history books, that those who came to this country 450 years ago and carved the land out, and indeed in the beginning of the historic agreement between the British and the French said that we will have two peoples, two languages, two cultures, two religions, it was a fundamental guarantee that led to a country where we did not tell everyone that to be a Canadian you have to be like me. You can choose this country.
[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Italian.]

They chose our country because they saw a country which said from the beginning of its historic roots that differences are welcomed here. That is what Canada is all about and that is why those who say "let the French go" are waving goodbye to a piece of Canada that makes us unique and different from all other countries in the world.

My French speaking friends, Canada is your country. You have built it. The fact that my daughter started school this week in a French Catholic public institution here in Ontario speaks volumes. The fact that my brother in Montreal is raising his daughter Beatrice in French-as an assimilated anglophone-would only be possible in a country where people have realized that speaking two languages and recognizing two official facts in their Constitution is not a loss but a gain on both sides. The fact that francophones can feel at home in every part of the country is quite something.

The deal is complicated. It is not perfect. I do not know of any constitution in any part of the world that has
achieved perfection. But is that a reason to throw away a great country? Some opponents may say: "I don't like section 3(l)(b)". That is fine. There are some details that I am not crazy about. But I say this unanimous deal is a chance to bring Canada back to the real issues.
Let us examine the alternative. The alternative is intolerance, exclusion, further constitutional conflict and indeed potential chaos. Canadians have a chance now with a unanimous deal to avoid the bloody histories of other parts of the world. There may be those who say: "Well, if Brian Mulroney is for it and Jean Chretien is for it and Audrey McLaughlin is for it then I am against it". And I heard that. I heard it on a local radio show in Hamilton.
I ask Canadians not to let their anger at politicians kill our country. This vote is not about settling grudges. This vote is not about teaching a lesson to an MP or an alderman. This vote is about our desire to keep Canada together. You will have a chance to express your disappointment, your disenchantment, at the ballot box in the next election. This is not what October 26 is about. Do not confuse the issue. Set aside our political differences, our partisan differences and work as a united front.
Canada is more than the individual interests of individual provinces or individual Canadians. This is one of those rare times in the history of a country where we can say yes.

We can say yes to Quebec and yes to Canada. [English]
It is one minute to midnight, the clock is running out, and the chance is here now for Canadians to say yes to Canada so that we can rebuild a great country into the 21st century.

Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure today to rise in support of the motion which approves the following question for the referendum on October 26.
"Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28,1992?
yes
no
September 10, 1992

I support yes. I am asking the voters of Trinity-Spadi-na in Toronto particularly to vote yes. I am also asking people across Canada, where I have many friends and acquaintances, to vote yes to this. I am not asking them to vote blindly. I am asking them to study this document and the information that will be distributed about the agreement that was unanimously reached by the Prime Minister, by the First Ministers of the provinces and the territories and for the first time in our history or perhaps in the history of the world, by the representatives of the aboriginal peoples of Canada, and then consider whether they can conscientiously vote yes.
If they decide they cannot and decide they should vote no, I honour their conscience in doing so. However, I hope they will have examined the document that was arrived at unanimously.
I would like to point out six reasons. There are more but I would like to point out six reasons why they might vote yes. The first and to me the most important is that it recognizes the inherent right of the peoples who have lived here for thousands of years, before any of my ancestors came to Canada, to the self-government they never gave up.
I have to confess that I thought I was an educated Canadian when I had two university degrees. In the last three or four years I have found that I grew up grossly ignorant of certain important parts of Canadian history. Like a lot of other people in Canada, I have learned a lot in these three years. I am very glad to have that history restored to me by the process that has taken place in the last three years and confirmed by what is in this document, recognizing that they have always had that inherent right.
There will be many questions we will have to work out with them. We have five years at least to negotiate. This document sets the foundation for that.
Second, there is the reconciliation that I believe is now possible between the people of Quebec and francophones in other parts of Canada and all the people of Canada, in Quebec and elsewhere.
The essence of the Meech Lake five points is present; the distinct society, the three members representing civil law in the Supreme Court, much more independence and responsibility for immigration, clearly defined limits and responsibilities in federal spending and the right of
Government Orders
veto on changes to federal institutions. Besides that there is an assured share of the membership of the House of Commons and a sharing of federal powers.

I want to say that our two daughters who have been living in Montreal for a number of years, as well as their husbands and children who speak French, are all bilingual. They can go to Toronto, just like my wife and I can go to Montreal, without crossing a border between Quebec and Ontario.

Also very important for me is the social contract. I wish to read some of the points that have been made in the social contract that was incorporated in this agreement.
"The objectives of our country shall include providing throughout Canada a health care system that is comprehensive, universal, portable, publicly administered, and accessible. Providing adequate social service and benefits to ensure that all individuals resident in Canada have reasonable access to housing, food, and other basic necessities. Providing high-quality primary and secondary education to all. Protecting the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively". I am particularly proud of that because that has also never been so fully recognized in the history of Canada and now it is in our Constitution as proposed for this vote.
"Protecting, preserving, and sustaining the integrity of the environment for present and future generations". Those are only promises but they are now promises that should be part of our Constitution.
There is a Canada clause which undertakes to state the general nature and commitments of our country. I regret it is not as strong as it might be in at least one way. There was a strong request that section 27 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms be amended to say not just that the people of Canada are committed but the Government of Canada is committed to preservation and promotion of racial and ethnic equality and that clause should be exempt from the notwithstanding clause.
I believe that was a reasonable and fair request to make. I wish it had been included, but I believe we can make progress in that direction nevertheless. I will come back to that.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
There is the division of powers in which the provinces which have grown greatly in population and economy throughout Canada now have greater flexibility to exercise their powers as they see need locally in the provinces and yet with a strong federal government that can provide financial support and co-ordination.
There is the reform of the Senate. I have agreed most of my life with my party about the abolition of the Senate which has been undemocratic fundamentally and in practice. This abolishes the undemocratic Senate and replaces it with a Senate whose constitution aims at providing fair representation to all sections, not just geographic, but all parts of the population of Canada.
I regret there also we did not go as far as many many people asked us to go to including proportional representation of women in the Senate. I will come back to that.
I see three problems we should deal with. They are not problems that should cause us to vote no or to stay home on October 26. They are problems I believe we can deal with better after we have voted yes and after this agreement has been put into law by the legislatures of Canada.
There is one problem, and I am happy to see that the Secretary of State is here and I respect his continuing attention on these subjects. There is a problem of pressure on certain visible minority groups and ethnic groups to be manipulated. That is to say there are phone calls, so I am well advised, coming to certain leaders of ethnic and racial groups from the multiculturalism department and/or the Secretary of State's office, talking about their vote, talking about the grants that come to their organizations, and in fact strongly suggesting they should vote in accordance with the grant.
There is the appearance that grants are greater to organizations that undertake to vote in support of yes and smaller or to absent organizations that do not agree to vote yes.
This is not a practice to be dealt with directly in the Constitution, but it is a matter that could be dealt with by the minister between now and voting day on October 26.
I ask the minister to review the conduct of his office and
his department to see whether it is possible to remove any hint of manipulation of the vote through the use of public funds. I ask that because I want those people to vote yes. I do not want them to be alienated by a sense that they are being manipulated. As is often said, it is important not only that justice be done but that justice appear to be done, and that is one of the problems.
I believe the minister and his department can deal with that in the next few weeks. I also believe the wider problem of the absence of the amendment to Bill C-27 can be addressed by premiers of Canada. At least one of them, the Premier of Ontario, has already addressed it, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs has addressed it and some of the native leaders have addressed it by urging that an amendment to clause 27 be incorporated. It is not possible to incorporate it now into the agreement on which we must vote on the 26th, but there could be a public pledge by the premiers and other leaders that they will see to it that it is considered a minor amendment that could be incorporated into the final drafting after the 26th when, as I hope, the vote will be resoundingly yes.
The final problem, and I have heard this from a number of my constituents, is that while this process proceeds in promoting acceptance of a political Constitution for Canada, there is another process afoot that would establish a very much changed economic Constitution for Canada, what President Reagan called the economic constitution of North America. When Canada signed the free trade agreement with the White House, that was President Reagan's triumphant declaration. Now we have an economic Constitution for North American and he obviously had in mind Mexico, which is now under way.
I want to quote what my leader said about 12 days ago: "We have begun the journey into the 21st century. There are those who tell us that it is a journey that must be led by the strongest and survived by the fittest. There is no choice. On their journey there is no time to pause and help a child born into poverty or a family forced into need. They are wrong. They are so very wrong. We have not struggled to politically unite this country only to have it divided socially and economically. Canada's journey into the 21st century has to be a journey with room for all, a journey where the strong help the weak, where the
September 10, 1992

Government Orders
healthy care for the sick and where every child will rise up with confidence and hope. Then and only then will the hard work and struggle have been worth it".
I believe it is highly relevant to what we are doing today because these two processes go together. The government, with millions of dollars of the taxpayers, is funding its view in favour of the North American free trade agreement while we continue with this referendum process.
Therefore, I find it necessary to call on the people of Canada to present the other side since three-quarters of them, according to public polls, reject that agreement and with reason. They reject it through knowing that more than one and a half million out of work Canadian adults and their families are living on their savings or unemployment insurance cheques or welfare and that is a poor living.
The U.S.-Canada trade deal has cost half a million good jobs, mostly in manufacturing. We are now being drawn into a negotiation with Mexico in which the standards of wages and environmental protection are so low that they are bound to damage the standards in Canada.
We are asked to join a trading block which will shut out the people of Asia and the people of Europe and break the concept of unified world trade for which most nations of the world have struggled since the end of World War II.
Finally, it would be a deal that would turn the raw material producing areas of Canada into areas of low-wage workers, hewers of wood and drawers of water, as General McNaughton said almost half a century ago when he warned against giving away our water. The workers in the present manufacturing areas of Canada would be reduced to low paid service workers, the equivalent of hewers of wood and drawers of water.
I ask that we look at these things together. The North American free trade agreement must be debated further. We do not even know whether the United States will accept it. It must be debated and we must begin now. I ask people in Trinity-Spadina and in Canada to vote yes, to put an end to this constitutional crisis which has seized us and to get on with building a democratic economy in Canada.

Madam Speaker, you may have noticed that for the past three days harmony has reigned in this House. Liberals, New Democrats and Conservatives have become a mutual admiration society, and all for the sake of making us accept a so-called constitutional agreement. Why so-called? Because in the preface we read the following:
The asterisks in the text that follows indicate the areas where the consensus is to proceed with a political accord.
That means no agreement was reached. In fact, I counted 28 asterisks in the text, which means 28 items on which there is no agreement as yet. At the end of the text
it says:
Other constitutional issues were discussed during the multilateral meetings. The consensus was not to pursue the following issues:
This is followed by a list of 14 items. If this is an agreement, I wonder what is being agreed to. Finally, it
says:
Other issues were discussed but were finally resolved, among which
were:
Another six items are mentioned. That is certainly not my idea of an agreement. It is full of gaps, and there are still many issues to be settled, as we just heard.
Like the majority of Quebecers, I refuse to accept this agreement. In addition to the considerations I just mentioned, I have other reasons for doing so and some very concrete examples.
Take the economy. That Canada's economy is deteriorating is no secret. In fact, there is a connection with the constitutional fatigue people are talking about. Governments have taken advantage of the constitutional debate to cover up their inertia, their lack of initiative, their lack of innovative ideas for restoring the prosperity of this country. As Jean Allaire put it, Canada is technically bankrupt. The economy is a disaster. For some time, Quebec's demands have ceased to be political.
They are more closely related to economic matters, because Quebec is willing to do anything to build its own prosperity. This need to regain control, to obtain all the tools required to rectify the situation, has been misunderstood in Canada. Quebec is stuck in a country which denies its need to obtain more powers to overcome its difficulties, while, on the other hand, the federal government increases its debt, mortgages the future of its citizens, imposes policies unrelated to regional realities,

September 10,1992
Government Orders
is unable to increase competitivity, and finally insists on controlling everything, even though there is increasing evidence that it has lost all ability to control anything.
In this context, it is surprising to hear comments about the terrible apocalyptic scenarios were Quebec to refuse to ratify the proposals. If it has to make a choice, why would Quebec opt for the worst, namely for a federal, centralizing, controlling system which overspends without taking into account the distinct realities of Quebec? Quebecers have long understood that it is useless to ask what Canada can do for them. They now ask themselves instead what they can do for Quebec. And what we can do now for Quebec is to say: no thanks.
But what about the draft agreement of August 22 on which Quebecers and Canadians will be asked to vote? It is important to analyse what benefits Quebec can find in this hastily achieved agreement. A more equitable sharing of powers? Certainly not. Quebec is far from having gained a new arrangement which would give it the powers it has demanded for 30 years, at least according to Francois Rocher, professor of political science at Carleton University.
Is there any need to remind the House that Quebec has been asking for the same thing for the past 30 years, to assure that Quebec will have the powers required to manage its own cultural, social and economic development? The so-called agreement of August 22 does not grant any new powers to Quebec. It provides for six exclusive fields of provincial jurisdiction: tourism, recreation, fisheries, housing, mines and urban affairs, which all came under provincial jurisdiction in the 1867 Constitution. I must also point out that the minister of constitutional affairs has even watered that down. He stated this week in the House that some sectors in these fields of juridiction will continue to come under federal responsibility. He said so to reassure one of his Conservative colleagues who had asked a question on the subject. As an example, he mentioned housing, which is quite a large exception.
Let us deal now with culture and immigration. Culture will come exclusively under provincial jurisdiction but- and it is an important but-the spending powers of the federal government in this area are confirmed. In addition the federal government will continue to control certain institutions such as the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the National Film Board. It is another example of the federal government giving with one hand and taking back with the other.
As for immigration, the only so-called advantage is an agreement under which the federal government simply undertakes to negotiate agreements on immigration, which it has been doing since the sixties.
Finally, under the draft agreement, manpower training would come under exclusive provincial jurisdiction, but once more, there are restrictions, such as the fact that unemployment insurance would remain under federal control.
As for regional development, negotiations are planned for the provinces that desire to play a greater role; what role and within what limits we shall see. In any event, it will be renegotiated in five years.
We must therefore admit that Quebec gains nothing in the distribution of powers. The answer to the federal offers is a very simple no.
Turning now to the distinct society, which was the cornerstone of the Meech Lake accord, and considered the bare minimum required for Quebec, this concept is worthless in the new constitutional agreement concocted by our first ministers.
The distinct society clause in the draft 1992 accord has virtually no value for Quebec, based on its nature, its wording and its context. The distinct society clause loses all its value because it is followed by a clause providing that the Quebec and federal governments have a commitment to the growth and development of the anglophone minority in Quebec. This clause totally limits the scope of the distinct society.
In sum, the distinct society clause in the proposed constitutional agreement becomes a mere interpretation rule subject to the discretionary power of judges; furthermore, by mentioning three criteria that distinguish Quebec, namely language, culture and civil law, the limitations are increased.
This will make it hard for Quebec to defend its social and economic legislation on the basis of the distinct society clause. For example, the law on the language of
September 10, 1992

advertising and commercial signs could be overturned on the basis of this clause.
Since Quebec gets no advantage or, worse, loses the little power it has, the answer to the offers of August 22 is a simple no.
The proposed constitutional agreement provides for a new equal Senate that confirms the triumph of English Canada's vision of federalism which diminishes Quebec.
As Professor Guy Laforet of Laval University says, by making Quebec a province like the others, the equal Senate is tantamount to official recognition, in the very heart of the Canadian political system, of the end of the dual vision of the country.
The equal Senate confirms Quebec's loss of power in the Canadian political system; its share of the representation will drop from 23 per cent to 9.6 per cent and maybe even 7 per cent, with the seats reserved for native people and new provinces.
In practical terms it means that a senator from Prince Edward Island will represent 21,717 citizens, whereas a Quebec senator will represent 1,140,833. It is quite a difference. To offset this loss of 18 seats, they are being transferred to the House of Commons. Quebec will have 93 members instead of 75 as now, but what will that change?
In any case we know that the 56 Conservative members from Quebec blend with those from the west and the maritimes. They have no opinion of their own. They will follow their party line.
Looking at the Senate and representation in the House of Commons, we cannot speak of advantages for Quebec. That is why I will again say no thanks to the offers of August 22.
Let us talk about this right of veto. Meech gave Quebec a general veto over changes to federal institutions and the establishment of new provinces. Now the federal government only has a moral obligation to consult with provinces regarding the establishment of new provinces.
What is Quebec gaining from this so-called right of veto? Nothing. Our only option is to say no to these offers.
Government Orders
This proposed constitutional agreement includes an interesting section concerning native issues. It is interesting because it reveals the open-mindedness of English Canada toward the aboriginal people, in contrast to its attitude toward Quebecers. The agreement recognizes aboriginal self-government without defining it, leaving the concept open to all kinds of interpretation.
After five years of negotiations the courts will have to settle the matter and will be free to define this important notion unrestricted by clear criteria.
It is just the opposite for Quebec where English Canada was determined to limit to only three areas the distinct society clause. Obviously English Canada's open-mindedness varies according to whom it is dealing with. Because of the insult to Quebec I say thanks, but no thanks.
All in all, English Canada's attitude is an insult to Quebecers who have shown through the years their trust in democracy, peace and negotiation only to face continued rejection. We must recognize that Quebecers are patient and tolerant.
Madam Speaker, you are indicating to me that my time is up so I will close by saying that Quebecers cannot accept the August 22 package. Because we must reject the centralization of powers at the federal level I say no on behalf of Quebec. Because we must refuse to become architects of our own failure, I say no on behalf of Quebec. Because we must prevent the decline of one of the founding nations of this country, I say no on behalf of Quebec.

The member for Outremont has the floor. I am told he will share his speaking time with the member for Manicouagan.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders

Madam Speaker, I have less time than I had hoped and I will have to use it sparingly. Time is precious and it is my pleasure, as you mentioned, to share this period with my colleague from Manicouagan.
I will make a few comments, primarily from my unique perspective.
First I want to make some corrections. Yesterday the leader of the Parti Quebecois gave his reply in the National Assembly to Mr. Bourassa's speech. He made a presentation that was a reflection of the man. He was calm and proper. On a few occasions, he referred to another premier of Quebec, Mr. Lesage. He did so with great gusto. He talked about him at length. Nothing was usurped. He alluded to the place occupied by a premier that belongs to the Quebec people and their past.
Nobody is offended by that. But then the Bloc Quebecois leader got all upset when the Prime Minister of Canada referred to another Quebec premier, Mr. Levesque.
This premier belongs to me just as much as he belongs to all Canadians. No one has the right to be so intolerent and think that this man only belongs to a caste.
Finally I want to get back to my university colleague and repeat again that Mr. Parizeau is an economist. If you really want to know what the agreement is all about you consult a constitutionalist, and this is what I did. I consulted our colleague, Senator Beaudoin, who is a constitutionalist of international reputation. Senator Beaudoin tells me that this agreement is a good one. He is an expert on that issue. I accept his analysis and his conclusion.
I want to deflate another falsehood. The Belanger-Campeau commission is not and was not the Bible. In fact it never will be the Bible. You had to be a member of that commission to see what went on. I was there. One must not minimize the work done by the commission, but at the same time you must not put it on a pedestal that it does not and never will deserve.
If you look at pages 53, 54 and 55 of its report where it deals with solutions, the commission makes a new attempt to redefine the status of Quebec. I am talking about the title of the paragraphs that follow and will follow within the Canadian federal regime.
They start by saying: "A first solution, as we saw, would consist for Quebec to try once again to obtain major changes within the federal constitutional framework". A
little farther they add: "Federalism, as a principle of political organization, is characterized by the flexibility of the structures that it makes possible". A little further still we can read this: "The general concept of Canada and of the federal regime that prevails today appears rigid and clearly geared towards a search for uniformity and the negation of the differences".
What happened under the authority of other governments that managed the affairs of the country in the past no longer takes place since the Conservative government has been in power and since the present Prime Minister has been in control.
This man and this party want decentralization as well as the respect of regional entities and identities. Pages 54 and 55 of the document mention changes that Quebec would accept: the need to create a new relationship based on recognition and respect between that province and the rest of the country; a sharing of jurisdictions and responsabilities; the allocation of jurisdictions and re-sponsabilities to Quebec regarding its social and economic developement, et cetera. Madam Speaker, all that you find in the Charlottetown accord is in this presentation made on pages 54 and 55 and on which the Belanger-Campeau commission agreed.
As Mr. Parizeau says, the content of the question is clear. You answer yes or no. Just like in any relationship negotiation is a continuous process, but this process can be done with either a conciliatory or antagonistic approach.
I would like to emphasize the fact that the Charlottetown process made it possible to search for a consensus in a climate of confidence. The objective was not to look for a compromise, but to recognize the true worth of all parties involved.
When the Canadian people including Quebec vote yes, it will be to demonstrate their self-confidence and its wish to control their own future.
Research has shown that national unity is possible, both in theory and in practice, even if we also promote regional differences. The people of Quebec and the way French-Canadians and Quebecers can now function show us that this nation is going through a maturing process and is becoming increasingly self-confident. Thus, these negotiations will not be the last ever. It would be illusory to believe so, but they will be productive and positive.



September 10, 1992

Voting yes will give Canadians and Quebecers another opportunity to show their maturity.

speakeroldname: Mr. Charles A. Langlois (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Industry, Science and Technology):

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, Canadians are being invited to make an historic decision on October 26. On that day they will be asked to reply to the referendum question now being debated in the House of Commons.
The question is short, clear and, most important, non-partisan. Its wording will allow all Canadian citizens to vote on the most important constitutional renewal project since the foundation of our country.
It will certainly be no surprise for anyone here or for the residents of the Manicouagan riding to learn that I shall reply yes to the referendum question. I shall vote in the affirmative because I am deeply convinced that the agreement achieved in Charlottetown a few weeks ago will make it possible for our nation to meet two basic objectives.
The first is to maintain the unity and integrity of Canada as a country which is respected and envied throughout the world. The second is to strengthen Quebec within the Canadian nation.
The provincial premiers, the leaders of the governments of the territories and Yukon, the representatives of the First Nations and the Prime Minister of Canada have come to an agreement which represents an historic stage in the evolution of the Canadian nation. This agreement completes the process begun in 1981, a process from which Quebec was unfortunately left out at the time but which was relaunched and carried out tenaciously in November 1984.
I was there in Sept-iles in 1984 when the right hon. Prime Minister undertook to bring Quebec back into the Canadian family with enthusiasm and dignity. All those who witnessed this commitment applauded the Prime Minister and gave him their support.
This commitment has now been met, thanks to the agreement achieved in Charlottetown a few weeks ago.
Why can we say today that Quebec comes back to the constitutional table with enthusiasm and dignity? Any-
Government Orders
one who reads the text of the consensus report on the Constitution will understand.
Through this agreement Quebec consolidates its position in a number of jurisdictions including immigration, culture and shared cost programs.
Through this agreement Quebec makes major gains, including recognition of the distinct identity of Quebec's society, full responsibility for manpower and manpower training programs, and full jurisdiction over forestry, mining, tourism, housing, recreation and municipal and urban affairs.
This agreement recognizes Quebec's expanded role in regional development and telecommunications.
The agreement also confirms Quebec's right to appoint three judges to the Supreme Court and gives Quebec 18 new seats in the House of Commons.
These are historic gains for Quebec.

This agreement, to which the Government of Quebec agrees, recognizes in its Canada clause that Canadians and their government are committed to the vitality and development of official language minority communities throughout Canada. Here is a commitment that will reassure the anglophone communities of the lower north shore in my riding. This clause assures them that their rights will be respected, will be recognized, will be protected and will be promoted.
This historic agreement makes all Canadians proud to be Canadians and it also makes the people of Quebec proud to be Canadians.
['Translation\
The aboriginal people of Canada and Quebec have finally obtained recognition of the principle of self-government. I am glad our partners in Confederation recognized the need to include in the Canadian Constitution the principle of self-government for aboriginal nations.
In 19881 made a commitment to support this principle, and it is with great pride that I invite my Montagnais constituents on the North Shore to examine the agree-

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
ment and measure the gains their people have made as a result of agreement.
It is of course understood there will be further discussions on this great principle of aboriginal self-government. The discussions will have to continue. Just because the principle has been recognized and will be enshrined in the Constitution does not mean discussions will no longer be necessary and that all obstacles have been overcome. On the contrary, we must be prepared to compromise and to continue the discussions on the principles of aboriginal self-government, in order to help undo the wrong done to aboriginal peoples since our country began and accept them as full citizens and partners in the development, including the economic development, of our country and help them achieve their legitimate cultural, language and developmental goals.
In concluding I would like to pay a real North Shore tribute to the right hon. Prime Minister, the North Shore boy who will go down in history as the man who made it possible to conclude this agreement. His perseverance and that of the right hon. member for Yellowhead have produced positive results for our country and Quebec.

Mr. Speaker, what the Prime Minister characterized as a Canadian compromise is certainly cause for congratulations to the Prime Minister, and particularly to the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
Those gentlemen, the leaders of our country, are entitled to bask in the glow of their achievement. For Canadians generally, however, the consensus at Charlottetown is more cause not for congratulations but for a collective sigh of relief. It is some release from the constitutional fatigue that has been building into a national trauma.
It all began when Quebec was excluded from the 1982 agreement. Reopening the constitutional issue in 1985 might have been a beau risque, to use the words of Rene Levesque cited Tuesday by the Prime Minister. It was a dangerous risk, too.
Nonetheless, the Prime Minister did achieve an accord at Meech Lake. It was an accord which, to my view,
supported by good constitutional advice from across the country, particularly from the then attorney general of Ontario-Ian Scott, who retired from the legislature early this week-was a satisfactory compromise allowing Quebec its recognition as a distinct society within our Confederation without yielding federal power.
Despite all the assertions to the contrary there was no sacrifice in that accord of the federal spending power. Indeed, the accord was specific in stating that nothing in that agreement altered in any way the balance between federal and provincial constitutional authority.
Granted, the accord responded primarily to Quebec's concerns but it would have been a useful first step in the renewal of our Confederation. It was contemplated by all the first ministers, and it was certainly contemplated by the Prime Minister, that the problem of western alienation and the injustice shown for centuries toward our original peoples would have been addressed thereafter.
I read that document of Meech Lake carefully. I have read the current document just as carefully. Meech Lake was a far cleaner deal than the document we now have before the House. In my view, those who opposed Meech Lake will bear the burden of history for the national disruption of the last three exasperating years, lost opportunities, a gnawing national frustration and who knows what permanent damage to the psyche of the country.
I have always been suspicious of referenda or plebiscites. Of course they are the ultimate democratic gesture. But the more complicated the national fabric of a country, the more divisive a referendum can be. A referendum is simplistic, reducing complex issues to a simple yes or no answer.
Moreover, under our parliamentary system we have representative democracy. In Canada we elect those who sit in the House and in the legislatures, and those who are municipal councillors. We elect those whom we charge or mandate to analyse the issues for us, to vote for us, and we hold them to account regularly at general elections.
A referendum tends to be an abrogation of that process because under our representative democracy we rely on the judgment of our members of Parliament and members of the legislatures. We rely on their ability, in
September 10, 1992

the best interests of their constituents and of the country generally, to act on our behalf and to vote on our behalf.
A referendum is an abrogation of that style of leadership. It is the quick fix. Having said that, what is done is done and there are provincial referenda in place. Therefore, I accept the fact that we now have a referendum. The people will decide and we will await their ultimate decision. I can tell you it is far from a done deal in many parts of Canada right now.
Looking at the substance of this consensus report from Charlottetown on August 28-1 have never in 30 years since being elected to the House of Commons had trouble as a Canadian, certainly as a former member of Parliament from Quebec, with the concept of a distinct society. For me it reflects reality. A different majority language, a different system of law, a different history, a different culture, different traditions, and a different sense of humour.
It is now more clearly defined in this document. I reiterate what I said in the House once before, which was reconfirmed by the judgment of the late Justice Jean Beetz in the Supreme Court of Canada on the sign language law, that a distinct society in Quebec includes not only a French speaking majority but it includes the English speaking minority. That is part of that distinct society. There is no impingement of minority rights by the concept of a distinct society.
Mr. Speaker, in Vancouver, which you and I have the honour to represent, and elsewhere Quebecers are visiting us this summer, certainly on the Voyageur Program. They must feel pretty good seeing those bumper stickers that say "My Canada Includes Quebec". For me there is no Canada without Quebec.

If I were a Quebecer, I think I would be satisfied with this agreement. It might not be as good as I would have wished, but it is probably better than what I expected. I cannot present at length the case for Quebec, but this was done, anyhow, by my friend and colleague, the hon. member for Papineau-Saint-Michel, in his masterly speech yesterday. I can say that it was among the best pleadings I ever heard in this house.
If I were a Quebecer, this document would provide a better protection for my language, my culture, my
Government Orders
heritage, my system of civil law. Quebec's control over its natural resources and immigration is improved, and Quebec is guaranteed a third of the Supreme court judges and, more importantly, 25 per cent of the seats in this House, that is to say 25 per cent of the shares in the business that is Canada. It has a perpetual guarantee of 25 per cent of the seats in order to protect the home base of French speakers in Canada: Quebec. On top of that it has veto power over any change in federal institutions.
If I were a Quebecer, I would say again: My homeland is Quebec, but my country is Canada.

I salute the justice finally accorded to our first peoples. Finally recognition of the inherent constitutional rights of our original peoples, the constitutional right to selfgovernment. I want to caution the House that strong leadership is going to be needed from all quarters during the next five years to make it work.
These provisions-the distinct society and the inherent right to self-government for our original peoples-were perhaps what Sir Wilfrid Laurier had in mind when, in this House, he recalled a visit to Canterbury Cathedral in London, a cathedral made of granite, oak, and marble. This is what he said to the House:
It is the image of the nation I wish to see Canada. For here, I want the granite to remain granite, the oak to remain oak, and the marble to remain marble. Out of these elements, I would build a nation great among the nations of the world.
What about the Senate? We argued this issue in this House on a government motion by the then Minister of Justice, now Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, on June 7, 1985. I remember it, it was my birthday.
At that time I repeated what I had written in a thesis that is now gathering dust in the library at the University of British Columbia, although there is a well worn copy in the Senate library here. The thesis was to the effect that the Senate should be abolished and, if not abolished, elected so that it became a real territorial balance against the overwhelming population of our central provinces.
Now we will have an elected Senate, an improvement certainly for western Canada. We are going to have an equal Senate, as the Leader of the Opposition said on Tuesday, at the price of being a less effective one.
September 10, 1992

Government Orders
I have always supported the British Columbia thesis advanced by the late W.A.C. Bennett when he was premier at the 1971 Victoria conference when I was attorney general under Mr. Trudeau. The British Columbia thesis of the five regional divisions for the Senate was the thesis advanced again by Premier Harcourt, which I supported.
Parenthetically, permit me to congratulate our current premier for his very constructive role throughout the long and difficult negotiations. He spoke for British Columbia but, as the unanimous report of the legislature advised him to do, he put Canada first. That is what the legislature, after touring the province, came to the conclusion that British Columbians wanted him to do and he did it. In my view, he deserves the support of all British Columbians in supporting this agreement.
There will be a better equilibrium in our Confederation as the result of an elected Senate, but it is impossible to predict how effective individual senators are going to be under our new parliamentary process. It is impossible to predict the interaction of the two Houses. One thing is certain, the power of the Senate to defeat a bill and then force a joint session of the House of Commons and the Senate will add a new dynamic in the power structure of this country and, frankly, I am optimistic that it can work.
On the issue of division of powers between federal and provincial jurisdictions, I do not believe that the federal authority gave away too much, although I have some doubts about culture, telecommunications and broadcasting and I deplore, as the Leader of the Opposition does, the weak economic union clause.
As I said during the trade debate, I have read the document. It is not a perfect document. It is not my document. But it is the only document we have. It happens to be the document resulting from hours and days and months of strenuous negotiations finally culminating with our democratically elected leaders from every part of the country and every segment of the country agreeing on this consensus. For that reason it deserves our support.
We Canadians ought to recognize that this referendum is more than just a debate about words, laws and powers.
It is about the future of our country as a cohesive, emotional, economic union. This debate not only involves our future as a people, but our individual well-being as citizens. It involves our future as a country that can continue to welcome citizens from every comer of the globe as a proud country.
We have been warned by the new political gurus of our age, the omnipotent pollsters, that we should not preach fear in this debate.
Does that mean that we cannot say to our fellow citizens that there are economic consequences of failure for all of us, that we should not warn that dividing up the huge public debt will not be costly, that we should not caution that there will be an effect upon our credit rating in the markets of the world, or upon the exchange rate, or upon interest rates, or that our trade would not be affected, or jobs and investments not lost?
No, this is not an abstract debate. This has real consequences, on a daily basis, for every one of us and every one of our constituents. More important, if we fail, it will affect the way that we feel about ourselves. We will feel that we have let ourselves down. We will feel that we have lost, perhaps irretrievably, the uniqueness we had as a special nation.
Canadians want a positive conclusion to this question. Most of us in this country believe that we have a great and beautiful land. Most of us believe that Canada has been a wonderful experiment. Most of us believe that Canada has been a great achievement. We are reluctant to sing the praises of our country, restrained in our patriotism. Waving the flag is not our way, not our style.
I happen to believe that we need renewal. Certainly we need renewal of our Constitution. We need renewal of our pride in our country.
speakername: Right Hon. John N. Timer@Vancouver Quadra

speechtext: Hear, hear.

We need to shed our cynicism and our negativism and our sense of frustration. We need to feel good about ourselves again.
Let us remember what we have here. Let us remember what we are talking about: a land of limitless space; a tolerant people, a fair people and a decent people. Let us reassert our belief in ourselves as a nation, using the
September 10, 1992

words of Laurier, "great among the nations of the world". We are the envy of the world.
It is time we woke up. It is time we shook ourselves out of this lethargy. I hope that this national debate encourages all of us, all Canadians, to stand up, to speak up strongly and loudly and clearly for Canada.
I support the motion and I will campaign for it.
Hear, hear.

Madam Speaker, I would like to congratulate first of all the speaker from Vancouver Quadra on a very excellent, eloquent speech this morning in his defence of the amendments and of the proposal to present the referendum to the Canadian people. I found it most illuminating and historic. I would congratulate him on a very well thought out and well presented speech and text.
I am also from British Columbia and I would like to present a slightly different point of view. I would like to discuss some of the concerns that we have in British Columbia with the constitutional representation in the referendum as it has been presented to us. The Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs has done an excellent job, an outstanding job, and at times an impossible job in bringing the premiers together to present a completed document with unanimous consent. Each one involved in this whole episode and exercise deserves our thanks and appreciation for the hard work and the compromising which they have done.
I would like to point out, however, that this is a debate in which various points of view are presented. I would like to present some points of view from British Columbia that I feel are significant and need to be discussed.
There are four points that I would like to make and the first one is that the redistribution of the seats or the increase in the number of seats compounds a problem which we in western Canada have complained about and have been concerned about for many years; namely, the increase in the centralization of power in central Canada. The idea of a Triple-E Senate was presented to resolve that problem. In a way it has done that in that the Senate is now equal according to provinces. As the
Government Orders
previous speaker mentioned, it is a question as to how much effectiveness there will actually be. I think that is something that will have to be developed as time goes on.
One of our major concerns is the increased centralization of power within central Canada. Forty more seats in central Canada is the equivalent of more than what B.C. has in total in the House. It is equivalent to what the Atlantic provinces have. It means that there would be increased Cabinet representation, increased membership of committees and everything that is entailed in having more members in this institution.
The second concern that has been voiced to me by many British Columbians is the increase in number of seats. They say we want less government and not more. It is recognized that by reducing the number of senators and increasing the number of MPs, the numbers will remain essentially the same. However, we should point out that it is much more expensive to maintain a member of Parliament in today's atmosphere than it has been in the past to have our senators. The new senators also will be much more expensive to maintain with their increased office staff, their constituency offices and the many things which they do not have at the present time. There is a real concern in British Columbia about the number of members of Parliament and what they will be doing. At the present time, we find that 60 per cent of our time is spent with immigration matters and such things. This is not a responsibility of members of Parliament primarily and I think we could best spend our time doing other things.
A third area that is of great concern to British Columbians, probably more so than any province in Canada, is the concept of aboriginal self-government. To me it is a potential time bomb and one of the most serious concepts within this whole document that needs to be studied, examined and worked on with all due care and attention that is required. It will affect British Columbia more than any other province because we are not covered by any of the treaties by which the other provinces have been covered. None of the groundwork has been done. Concerning our land claims at the present time, 120 per cent of our province is claimed by the natives, by the aboriginal people under the land

September 10,1992
Government Orders
claims. There are more Indian bands in British Columbia than in any other province. We have 53 separate bands, each with its own language and system of government. There will be a very complex problem of self-government.
The majority of aboriginals in British Columbia are not going to be satisfied with the status or the Sechelt pattern as has been described. Rather, they are concerned that their goal is to have either provincial or federal status for their people. We can see that there is going to be a lot of conflict. Some of these things need to be formulated. They have told me personally that they would not be satisfied with the municipal form.
In relation to this point the costs are unknown. It has been shown in the referendum document that the federal government will be responsible for the costs that are involved. As I say, with 53 bands the educational, legal, justice and administrative systems that will be set up will be tremendously expensive to maintain because of the small numbers of people that will be involved in them. This is a real concern for the people of British Columbia.
These are some of the major concerns of people. Another major concern, the fourth concern, is the unanimity clause that has been included. Every speaker so far has pretty well said that this document was flawed, that it had problems and that they had reservations. Yet we are going to carve in stone the unanimity clause which says that all provinces and the House must agree to changes in the Constitution. Rather than doing that, we should be perhaps writing it on paper so that it can be changed much more so than carving it in stone. I cannot see any reason for putting this clause in at this time when there are so many doubts about it.
The people of British Columbia have looked at these problems and considered them. On the other side they ask: "What are the benefits of getting this referendum through and agreeing to the constitutional package?" This is a major issue that is going to be present in this whole referendum. Re-establishing political stability within the country will allow our economic problems to be resolved. We will be able to direct our attention to the economic problems which each province and area is facing.
Residents of British Columbia will have to weigh these two factors: the shortcomings and the very positive commercial aspects. As a previous speaker pointed out, the great pride we have as Canadians within Canada about Canada must also be considered.
I look forward to further debate and discussion on this matter. I hope the final package will show fairness to all Canadians.
