Madam Speaker, my first thanks goes to the hon. doctor from Delta who yielded half of his time to let me make about a three-minute speech on this vital issue.
My congratulations go to the right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra who made one of the most magnificent speeches that I have heard him make in this House of Commons. He was fighting and has implored us to fight for this country. I really applaud him.
Tell him that.

They say: "Tell him that". I did.
The other right hon. member in this House who should be applauded is the right hon. member for Yellowhead, the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs. My wife and I are very proud of that right hon. member. I have never seen him in better form, tired as he may be, over the 16 months of trying to cobble together what is the most important Canadian exercise since we were formed 125 years ago.
The question that people are being asked is the following one:
Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed
on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28, 1992?
I went into Zehr's Plaza across the street from where I live in Ancaster, in beautiful downtown Hamilton- Wentworth, and I asked the first 10 people: "What does the question mean to you?"
In effect, what they said was: "What the hell are you talking about? What package? What is in it? Will you be specific?" With the co-operation of editors of six weekly newspapers that I put my column in every single week, I decided to ask my own question. The question is in two parts:
September 10, 1992

1.	"Do you want to keep Canada together? Yes_________
No________"
2.	"What is the best way to do that?"
Really what we have to decide is whether we believe in Canada. If not, why not? I am not putting that in writing.
I am just saying that. I feel that you can examine nothing with a closed mind. Let nothing be invoked but the truth and the truth is we have the best country in the world to reside in according to the United Nations and according to all of us who live here. The truth is that the only answer can be yes to keeping this country together.

I imagine there are a lot of people in every corner of this country who are not happy with this deal and say it is imperfect. What else do we have in front of us? I do not like either/or situations. Like all politicians, I would rather move around, come out and duck back in again. However, there is no room for moving around, no room for coming out and ducking back in again. It is either/or.
Who placed us in this position? In my opinion it is the Prime Minister of Canada who must be responsible one way or the other, whether you agree with him or not on every other issue. He must take the political responsibility with the premiers to come up with a deal.
I am not crazy about referenda. Referenda catch the spirit of the moment. The population can be inflamed or cooled by intemperate remarks. Prejudices can be appealed to. Biases can be appealed to, and more impor-

I intend to hold my nose and vote for this deal. It is not Dave Barrett's deal, but who is Dave Barrett to hold up the whole country? If I had my druthers, I would have written my own constitutional deal, voted on my own referendum and said here it is, it is my best and it is mine.
Fortunately or unfortunately, nobody asked me to do that and I am presented with a human document that I am forced to make a decision on.

I want to address some remarks to the Liberal leader in the province of British Columbia. As the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs, Mr. Garth Turner (Halton-Peel): Madam Speaker, on a man who deserves praise from all sides of this House, October 26 the people who live in the riding of Halton- said in this House yesterday: "This is not a test of Peel will be asked to vote yes or no to a package of loyalty". Instead it is meant more to move the country

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
forward into the future. I think we all know what is coming in the future.
It is evident that Canada is moving into a future that will be dominated by trends like globalization, as trade barriers around the world come down and countries have to be more competitive in order to prosper and succeed in the world to come. As well, we are looking at a country with rapid demographic change. Canadians are growing older. The population is getting more stable. We have to consider what that means for our finances and economic future.
We are also coming into a future with new technologies. Technologies are changing so rapidly that the countries that are going to compete and be successful in this globalized world will be those that have modem, flexible constitutions, rules that govern their countries.
We know what is coming in the future. Therefore it is important to put constitutional change behind us so that we can concentrate on what is coming. Trade, prosperity and national unity are linked.
Trade is important to the people in my community, to the people who live in Halton-Peel. This riding is home to many companies that compete globally. They not only compete, they are successful.
The issue of Canadian constitutional unity and peace is important to the people in my riding. That is one message that I think the people of Halton-Peel would like me to record here on the floor of the House of Commons. However, there is another even more important message, which is about democracy, freedom and all the things that make this country the best in the world in which to live.
To the voters in my riding who will face a decision on Monday, October 261 have one brief message for them. Soon you will be asked to accept or reject the package of changes to the way the governments of Canada are structured. It is an important vote. The future of our country will be very much determined by its outcome. However, while the federal government, the provinces, the territories and the aboriginal leaders are all supporting this package, that does not mean that you have to. You have a clear choice and a right to vote as you see fit.
As the member of Parliament for the riding of Halton-Peel I would like to tell the voters of my riding that I do not intend to tell them over the coming weeks how they should vote. Politicians have no comer on patriotism. I will be supporting the agreement and I have an obligation to tell people why I will be doing that.
Many of the people in my riding know that I have campaigned for things that are not in this agreement, things that I would like to have seen such as a guarantee of property rights and a stronger economic union. People in my riding also know that I wanted less government, not more government. I would like to have fewer politicians, not more members of the House of Commons.
I would even like to see an end to the 19th century concept that this country is comprised of 10 provinces, widely different in size, population and economic structure. In the future other rounds of constitutional reform can perhaps restructure Canada on the basis of five regions.
In this deal I did not want to see a social charter that inhibits the flexibility that we need for the future. I did not think a reduced role for Ontario in an elected House of Commons was fair. Having said that, let us remember a fundamental truth as we reform Canada. Let us remember that there are no perfect countries, as there are no perfect marriages or perfect business partnerships.
Canada is a huge place. Many people are very attached to their regions. It is also a country that was founded by two peoples in 1867 and that remains true today and needs to be recognized.
Addressing all of these things takes compromise. In fact, if we cannot compromise we may not be able to keep our country together. The former Yugoslavia, Bosnia and Croatia, is a place where they have not been able to compromise.
Some people in my riding will not like this accord. Today members of the Reform Party are deciding whether they can support it or not support it. I sincerely hope they are with us. I hope we can speak with one voice to accept this.
My personal conclusion is that the accord that people will vote for on October 26 is not the one that I would
September 10, 1992

have written, but is one I can support. I ask the voters in my riding to take time to understand this agreement, to study it, to appreciate it and then come to their own conclusion.
God bless Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to be able to speak for a few minutes on the constitutional agreement reached on August 28.
A constitution is a framework of law, the fundamental law of the land. It is also more than the rules by which we govern ourselves. A constitution should reflect the values, the characteristics, the beliefs and the tolerances of a country.
For quite some time there has been a desire, a need to re-evaluate our present Constitution. Many areas of our country have expressed dissatisfaction and concern that their particular needs were not being addressed. The constitutional proposals reached in Charlottetown on August 28, after over two years of consultation and discussion by citizens across our country, represent a great deal of dedication and hard work by the individuals who were there: the Prime Minister, the premiers, the leaders of the territories, the aboriginal leaders. They worked together to develop this compromise agreement.
I give special tribute to the chairmen of the meetings, the Prime Minister and at other times the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, for the leadership they provided, as was brought to our attention by the participants at this final meeting.
The challenge was to remake the Constitution in the image of the countiy that we have become, not the country we once were. I believe that the proposals certainly achieve this goal.
Canadians have expressed a desire for change. They have demanded more responsive institutions and accountable government, justice for our aboriginal peoples and the rebalancing of the roles and responsibilities between federal and provincial governments. This agreement, although not perfect, is a solid step toward making our constitution work for the entire country of Canada.
Government Orders
The agreement that I am sure will be endorsed on October 26 by the Canadian people will mark an incredible milestone that has eluded many Canadians for a number of years. Outlined in this agreement is a statement of what it means to be Canadian-the Canada clause. This is important for it gives us a sense of the values that we hold in common while also accommodating our diversity in this countiy.
The Canada clause entrenches certain fundamental characteristics such as parliamentary democracy', linguistic duality, Quebec's distinct society, and equality of race and gender, to name a few.
For aboriginal peoples this agreement represents a long overdue justice through the recognition in the Constitution of the inherent right to sett-government. Our first peoples will now feel that they are truly Canadian. They can now confirm their commitment to share in building a new and stronger Canada.
By reforming our Senate to make it equal, elected and effective in responding to the demands and concerns of Canadians the Senate should become a more effective legislative body and not simply a rubber stamp.
This agreement provides for better discipline in the use of federal government spending power and the protection of intergovernmental agreements. Provinces will now receive exclusive jurisdiction, if they desire, in many areas they were requesting.
These proposals will also deal with the important issues of social and economic policy, regional development, equalization payments and the amending formula.
As I said, this agreement is not perfect. There were compromises made on all sides, but in the end I feel we have reached an agreement that all Canadians can live with. It resolves the most pressing concerns that have dominated the national debate for many years. Quebec's interests were satisfied, western Canada got its equal and elected Senate with more legislative power, and our aboriginal peoples finally achieve self-government.
In my constituency of Sarnia-Lambton I get the distinct impression from those I have talked to that over all there is great support for the constitutional amendments that have been agreed upon. I have also talked to my provincial counterparts-and I will not get into politics-the elected members of the NDP Government of Ontario. They certainly have expressed their interest

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
in working in my constituency and theirs in support of these amendments. I will certainly be available there to provide support. I am supporting these amendments.
I also will be available in my constituency as a resource person to answer questions and provide information. I ask all my constituents to take this very seriously and to be sure to cast their ballot as they see fit. I ask them to study it with serious concern and interest. I know they will. If they need information I certainly will be available to provide it to them. It is a chance for our great country to stay together and to make this a better place to live.
My family came to this country in 1849. They were also, as said the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca, hard working, solid families. We came here and have thrived in this great Canadian family. Certainly my family, and also my neighbours, friends and constituents, look forward to carrying on our all-Canadian future with all of us in a confederated family staying together. These important amendments will allow us to do that.

Madam Speaker, I will be supporting this set of proposals. I will be voting yes on October 26. Obviously the first question is why. Undoubtedly the major reason is that I really want to unshackle this Parliament and future parliaments from the constitutional crisis we have suffered over the last several years. Many of my colleagues in this House and I want to get the country working again. Parliament working more smoothly and Canadians back to work.
There are other reasons I want to go through quickly to give my constituents and other Canadians a sense of where I am coming from. We all know that in any negotiation no one party ever gets everything he or she wishes. This is the case in this particular instance.
I believe that under current circumstances it would have been difficult to have had a better set of proposals that most parties could have bought into, that most parties would have supported. I think that is a significant achievement.
We have an over-all consensus. Let us remember that. The Prime Minister, 10 premiers of our 10 provinces, the
leaders of the two territories, and the leaders of four major aboriginal organizations are supporting this set of proposals. Clearly there should be some sense of satisfaction in recognizing that these individuals feel this is a good deal for Canadians and for Canada.
Let us not forget as well what is happening on October 26. It is a referendum, an opportunity to go to the people and ask Canadians whether or not they will support it. I am hoping with all my heart that the majority of Canadians in every province and each of our two territories will say yes. I am very much hoping that will happen. This referendum is something my party under the leadership of the hon. member for Beausejour has been calling for, for a long time. I am delighted the other parties have agreed this is a good idea.
Let us not forget as well that as a result of this referendum there will be no future substantial changes to our Constitution without going to the referendum. That is a major gain for all Canadians.
What are some of the other gains? Obviously aboriginal self-government. I have always felt, and I wish it had been different, that many of our aboriginal peoples from a social economic perspective can be compared, and not always favourably, with Third World nations. That is a shame. I am hoping this particular initiative will permit them to break out of the cycle of poverty.
The distinct society has been recognized and accepted. It has now been defined for those who had real concerns. There have been other gains for Quebec. If I were a Quebecer I know I would want more. Obviously I would want more, but I think we have to recognize it will be better for Quebec after this referendum, assuming that it is won, than it was before.
Canadians from origins other than French, English and aboriginal have had some modest gains as well. Linguistic minorities have much of the protection and the support they sought, providing the political will is there of course.
In the division of powers it is much clearer today, or it will be once this is accepted, what level of government supplies what kinds of services for its population. That has always been a contentious issue.
September 10, 1992

Government Orders
There is a social charter and albeit perhaps not as strong as many people would have liked it is there and it gives us a sense of direction as to what are our social values and our commitment to social programs.
There is a "reformed Senate". That will be contentious. There are some reforms but people will question the significance of them.
Those are some of the major reasons I will be supporting this agreement.
Do I have concerns? Obviously anyone who has read the agreement, anyone who has read any agreement, will have concerns. Yes, absolutely I have some concerns. I have several.
Self-government just because it is realized in the constitutional agreement is not a reality. We will require an openness of mind, a generosity of spirit, and political will if it is to happen.
Canadians of origins other than English, French and aboriginal have not felt they were sufficiently included in the process coming up to this agreement. They do not feel, certainly the people with whom I have spoken, they are sufficiently recognized in this set of proposals. Therefore there will be some problems there.
The linguistic minorities have had what they sought in terms of constitutional guarantees, but you and I know that even the constitutional guarantees will not necessarily correct the injustices that have occurred.
If there continues to be laws such as those passed in Quebec, Alberta, and Saskatchewan limiting the use of one of Canada's official languages, be it English or French, there will continue to be tensions. That will go on until we can in fact open our hearts and recognize there is enough space in this country for everyone.
I would hope as well that subsequent to this agreement-

Provincial governments are realizing that the Supreme Court of Canada reached numerous decisions that indicated that French minorities outside Quebec had the right to administer their education system, had a right to school administration. It is a priority for that group.
I hope that finally we will go ahead and that we will not hesitate to give them their responsabilities, that we will allow them to grow, to take their own decisions for the future of their children.

The division of powers will also cause difficulties because even though it is written and somewhat defined there continues to be a need for additional work. It will require further discussion and negotiation. There is no getting around that.
The complexities of government when one looks at the federal, provincial and municipal levels are such that one cannot possibly define it in one document without having some further discussions.
On the reformed Senate the major issue is the whole notion of effective. Is it effective? We could debate that. It has probably made some gains over what exists but I wonder how many gains.
I would have much preferred the proposal my party had advanced that called upon an elected Senate, an effective Senate, and an equal regional representation of senators. It would have been better to have accentuated the effective rather than equal provinces, but it is not to be. I can accept it with some difficulty, but I am prepared to do what I can to improve that effectiveness within the tools available to us.
Because it is unclear as to whether or not senators will be appointed or elected-they may be-potentially that is very contentious. I would hope that all provinces and the territories would decide to elect their senators. I really believe it is a must.
I believe as well that we should have a system of election which is proportional, which will make sure that the under-represented groups such as women, Canadians of aboriginal origin, Canadians of origins other than English, French and aboriginal, will get an opportunity to be elected as senators.
If not, what are we going to do? We are simply going to extend that which we have at a national election, which is probably more of the same, that is more of the same people who are from the governing party. I think that would be unfortunate. We need to have mechanisms that will permit women, visible minorities and others to serve this country. This is a great opportunity to start doing something significant about it.
We should also be exploring the feasibility of having French speaking senators outside Quebec and English speaking senators in Quebec to ensure those two large linguistic minorities are fairly represented.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
I would like to see a reduction in the number of members of Parliament. Rather than go to 337 we could virtually keep the same number or reduce it and still keep the same proportions if that is necessary.
We would be responding to that cry out there that we are overly governed. We would be responding to that cry out there that government is too costly. We would be saving a lot of money. A 15 per cent reduction, for example, would amount to roughly 287 members of Parliament rather than the 295 that we have now and the 337 that is expected with these new proposals. That would save over $20 million a year, and that is not without looking at additional costs of infrastructure and a number of additional costs to support MPs.

I would really like for us to recognize that even if the proposals are there, even if there has been an agreement between the first ministers, the leaders of the two territories, the Prime Minister of Canada and the leaders of the four aboriginal groups, there is still time to improve some aspects without changing the basic principles.
I think that if we examined what people with some concerns are saying, we could reach a better consensus with much more support.

I want to point out that in my opinion the no side will have to put up. It is not sufficient simply to say that one is against something. It is necessary to propose an alternative.
What is the alternative going to be? Will all the people voting on the no side be able to get a coherent package together that the Prime Minister, whether it be this one or another one, and the premiers, the leaders of the territories and the aboriginal leaders, whether it is the ones who are there now or others, will be able to accept? Will they be able to do that? No, I do not believe it for one moment.
If they think they can, let them put their package on the table and let us take a look at it. It is not good enough to stand on the sidelines and swipe and snipe and attack. It is necessary to put forward constructive proposals.
I think there is still time to improve the package. I have made some suggestions, some modest proposals. I stressed the election of senators. I really believe that is essential. That gives senators legitimacy. It gives them additional power. If they continue to be appointed there will still be the criticism that is legitimate today.
I believe that there should be proportional elections of senators because there are under-represented groups that are not serving the nation as members of Parliament, as senators and at other levels of government.
I also believe that we have to look at whether or not we have done an injustice to those Canadians who are labelled disabled, those Canadians who have disabilities. We are not without knowing that they feel they have not been treated fairly. We saw evidence of that yesterday in this House. They believe that they were included in the first set of government proposals and that they should be included again. Let us not forget that these Canadians with disabilities are among the poorest of the poor and that they do not sufficiently often have people who advocate to better their economic and social conditions. Therefore we should look at that.
We should seriously look at the reduction of MPs. What is there to lose? We could save money. We could keep the same proportions if it is necessary. On the other hand, those two large provinces, Ontario and Quebec, if they chose, could accept fewer MPs than they would have received in order to bring about a reduction. If we could reduce the number of MPs it would not only save money, but it would give senators a greater proportional weight when there is a joint session. Of course if there were a generosity of heart from Ontario and Quebec to take one-half of what they would have received in these proposals then clearly that would be well accepted by other parts of Canada.

I suggest that we go ahead, that we try to reach specific conclusions in order to get to other issues, in order to ensure that Canadians who rely on us, on all members of this House to try to resolve the deep problems of this country, can do so.

As I complete my remarks I want to just make a couple of very brief points. We must remember that it is much easier to destroy than it is to build. That is one of my great fears as we go out on this adventure. We also have to remember that it only takes a little drop of poison to
September 10, 1992

poison a whole lake. My great, profound fear is that the several drops of discontent that will occur could kill Canada.
I believe that if we look at the pluses and the minuses over all this accord is worth supporting.

I intend to support it. I will not tell my constituents how they should vote, but I am ready to talk to them about it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I take pleasure in taking part in this debate because for weeks, months and literally years the Canadian public has been treated to the vicissitudes and the vagaries of constitutional debate.
There has been a constant emotional tug of war for all our people because inevitably this constitutional debate is divided into camps of them versus us, winners or losers. Did they get more than we got?
Finally, we are coming down to the debate. This tug oi war has created feelings of uncertainty about the outcome and what would happen to our community, what would happen to Canada and what would happen to our place within the nations of the world.
Now we have the benefit of debate with a text before us. We are no longer dealing with promises, conjectures, vagaries and anticipations. We are now dealing with a text. I am encouraged by the fact that people in my community are calling my office asking for copies of the text. We are not talking any more about newspaper reports, what the hotlines are saying, what the news is saying. We are now talking about a document which everybody can have before them. We are talking about the precise wording in that document.
The difficulty of the debate is that there have been some premature conclusions made all across the country because of assumptions, because of fragmentary news articles, because of rumours and feelings that it is them or us and feelings of conflict within the country that have been generated by this debate. This has developed the mindset of for or against the proposals, the consensus.
Government Orders
Too often it has been a premature decision to be against the proposals even before the text is seen.
I want to emphasize throughout this debate that we have to return to the text and what it says, not what other people say, not what other people think it says. But actually, what it does say. The first question we have to ask ourselves is that very one: What does it say?
Today we have to make a decision in this House. On October 26 the people of Canada have to make a momentous decision for the country. Again, not on rumour, not on speculation, not on fragmentary quotations, but on the entire text and what it says to us.
In the process we have to reject some myths. The first myth is that we have to agree with the total package. That is an impossibility. Nobody is going to agree to the total package. The 17 people in the room negotiating and reaching a consensus on this did not agree on the total package. I do not agree with the total package. There is not one member in the House, I believe, who agrees with the terms of the entire package. What we are talking about is not individual items but the wholeness of the package. We have to destroy the myth that says if we do not agree with the package, we cannot vote for it. The fact is, we have to deal with that myth.
As the member from Winnipeg said previously, I do not believe the membership of the House should get constantly larger. Maybe we could do with a reduced number of members in the House. With the Senate being reduced in numbers, they do not necessarily have to be added to the House. We could reduce the proportion.
I do not agree with the economic package. I do not think it is strong enough. I find various segments of this package wanting, but as the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs said in Halifax some weeks ago: "If I had been alone in a room writing this package I would not have written it this way. But I was not alone in the room. There were 16 other people there".
What we have to do is deal with the myth that we have to agree with the whole package. Nothing could be further from the truth. It could never be true that 27 million Canadians are going to enjoy unanimity on all of this.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
There are Canadians who have genuine detailed concerns about individual items in the package. These need to be explained. We have a duty to go to those people as much as possible and explain the items in the agenda so that we can deal with those concerns. Many of those concerns are very legitimate. They are based not on speculation or on feelings, but on text.
We need to look at the implications of each of the ingredients and see what those implications are for the future of Canada, whether it is in the Senate proposals, the distinct society, the aboriginal agreement, or the economic package. We need to look at those implications and see what the future of Canada would be like once we have implemented those particular proposals. In the end, it is impossible for 27 million Canadians to agree.
The second myth we have to deal with is that we can oppose this. We can vote it down and simply return to the status quo. There is no stable status quo. We cannot return to the past.
The very process we have been going through has been one of dynamic change. People's attitudes have changed. People's viewpoints have changed. There is no returning to the past. Does anybody believe if we reject this package that the west will tolerate another 10 or 20 years of wrangling about institutional reform? Does anybody believe that?
If we reject this package, will the aboriginals easily accept another promise when this one is so close to being fulfilled? Can we return to some mythical status quo there? Would anybody believe the people of Quebec will quietly defer their cultural aspirations if we reject this package? Will the business community or the economic climate withstand any further postponement of this issue?
The fact is there is no returning to some kind of a mythical status quo. We have to deal with it and not pretend that we can vote it down and simply return to the past and start all over again.
Ultimately there is a big question. I am speaking now to my friends in my constituency and to the country at large. If you oppose individual items in this package, what changes would you require to be made on individual items to make the package acceptable for you?
Write them down. Is it the Senate package? What do you need changed in the Senate? Is it the 25 per cent floor for members from Quebec? What is it that you need to have changed? Write them down and then come with me to the maritimes, to Nova Scotia or New Brunswick. I will introduce you to fellow Canadians there who also have a list of bottom line demands that they think are imperative to make this a complete package. Sit down with this Nova Scotian and compare those lists. I can assure you they are not the same lists. They will be different.
How will you accommodate two intransigent positions and satisfy both regions of the country? For the west, any federal government involvement is intrusive. For the maritimes, federal government involvement is imperative. Tty to reconcile those. If we in the west feel so very strongly about individual items on the agenda that are so important for us, let us sit down with people from other parts of the country and compare with them what their demands are.
A second big question is: Do we really want to have a break in the impasse? Do we want to have constant wrangling? If we want to have a break in the impasse, what is it that we are willing to concede in order to break that impasse?
I am reminded of the words of Leo Tolstoy who once said: "Everybody thinks about changing humanity; nobody thinks about changing himself". It is the other person who has to change, not me.
In an impasse it is impossible to think of a change, a resolution or a reconciliation unless both parties make a concession. The danger we have in this debate is we will overlook an ancient truth. Believing is not so much an act of gathering more information, but an act of the will. We decide to believe. We make a conscious decision that we will believe or reject certain things. Look at the people who smoke and the limp excuses they use to prove it does not hurt them: "My Uncle Fred is 90 years old and smoked two packs a day. He never died of tobacco use. He was hit by a bus". They will believe that because they want to and they have decided to believe that.
In an issue much more critical for our country, we cannot embrace ancient and continuing prejudices and accommodate new realities all at the same time. We cannot do that. We decide to believe or we can decide to reject information.
September 10, 1992

The whole commitment to education is built on the notion that we spend billions of dollars so that students change. We do not expect them to come out of educational institutions the same way they went in.
Now we are asking the public to participate in a process of change for our country and to experience what 17 leaders of our nation experienced over the last few months in intense negotiations and in intense dialogue. Can you imagine 17 more diverse people with strongly held views sitting here in Ottawa or in Charlottetown discussing what bottom lines are for them?
Compare Premier Wells with Premier Rae and their bottom line positions, Premier Getty and Premier Bou-rassa, or the aboriginal leaders and the premiers. They have very opposite points of view and yet they came to an agreement. Would anyone suggest that Premier Wells or Premier Rae denied their convictions when they came to an agreement? The fact is they kept all their convictions. What they did was they found it acceptable to acknowledge the validity of somebody else's point of view. They did not deny their own convictions. They accepted additional ones.
We ask ourselves whether there is a risk in all of this. Of course there is. There is risk in any change and we fear change because there is risk involved. Ask any businessman about an investment that he has to make. Is he afraid? Is there risk? Of course there will be risk and there is risk in this, but that is the nature of change. There is change and there is risk in the nature of change of relationships and we must accommodate that risk, not overlook it.
We are not asking for reckless, blind acquiescence to the terms of a document. What we are asking for is a willingness to be objective about the terms of a text and what it says and that we look at it with reason in the cold light of day. We ask for a willingness to accommodate change and the change of mind, the change of attitude and the change of heart.
The fundamental simple question is: Will Canada be better off with these changes? Will Canadians' futures be brighter as a result of these changes to which these people have agreed? If we ask that question and look at the text in that context, we will say a resounding yes to the package and we will have a bright future for Canada.
Government Orders
I close with one statement from William Penn who said: "Oh, Lord, help us not to despise or oppose what we do not understand."
May we look at this text in the cold light of reality and find it in our hearts to look at other people's points of view at the same time.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, let me commence my remarks by congratulating the member who has just spoken. I think he presented a very thoughtful speech to this House.
On October 26 Canadians will be asked the following 21 word question:
Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed
on the basis of the agreement reached August 28, 1992?
That is really the preamble. The question itself is yes or no.
I like the question. It is short. It is easy to understand. All Canadians can participate in the process and feel comfortable that at least they will understand that which they are voting on.
Contrary to the past constitutional accord, the Meech Lake agreement-and I voted for Meech Lake-this deal was not only approved by the first ministers. It was also approved by the territorial leaders, by the aboriginal leadership, and it will be subjected to a referendum.
Furthermore, it has been the result of extensive consultation.

Extensive consultations were held for nearly two years: the Spicer commission, the consultations I had in my own riding, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee, the Unity Forum sponsored by the aboriginal people which I attended, the meetings of first ministers, with the exception of the premier of Quebec, followed by further meetings, this time with the premier of Quebec attending.

To those who say there has not been sufficient consultation, I think that Canadians have heard enough. They probably feel they have been consulted and they want to get this issue over with.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
Meech Lake took too long to ratify and I think that is one of the causes of its demise. Once the deal is approved by this House, once it is ratified not only by the Canadian people, which it will be on October 26, it has to be ratified by all legislatures and by this Parliament. I really hope we can do that quickly, having received that instruction by the Canadian people.

I would like us to do Canadians a favour and promise them the agreement will be ratified before Christmas. Would that not be a nice Christmas present? I know my constituents would appreciate the fact that we would not be talking about the Constitution for a while.
Talking about the Constitution is not a bad thing in itself. We will have an agreement approved by Canadians in a referendum and by the legislatures of all the provinces and both Houses of Parliament. Of course we can talk about the Constitution at some point in the future, although right now I have a slight case of constitutional indigestion.
As soon as we have that consent we will be able to talk about it without the threat looming on the horizon of Canada breaking up.

Discussing constitutions is not in itself wrong. There are constitutional talks in the United States. It has had one since approximaltely 1787 and that is not unhealthy. Every time it discusses a constitutional change, the fabric of the country is not threatened by the fact the U.S. talks about it.
Once we ratify this Constitution by way of a referendum and the subsequent votes of our legislatures and our Parliament, we could talk in the future if we so wish about constitutions without threatening ourselves and our very existence.

There are a few parliamentarians who say there is not enough in this agreement and who do not like certain measures. Granted, some measures may not be winners, and if I put on my partisan hat for a second, I would say my leader is a better negotiator than the leader of the party opposite. If I did not think so, I probably would not be a member of my party.
Of course the agreement could be improved on, but that is not the point. The point is not whether the agreement is perfect. As far as I know, the last perfect person was crucified nearly 2,000 years ago. The point is whether the agreement is good for our country, and my answer is yes. Of course the naysayers are grabbing the headlines today, but you can bet they are not going to stay in the House. Everybody knows who they are. Everybody is talking about them. Everybody is saying, or at least some people are, "he said more or less what I was thinking".
People will remember Sir John A. Macdonald and Sir George Etienne-Cartier. People will remember George Brown who set aside partisan concerns for the sake of this country more than 125 years ago. But who remembers William Hannon, Antoine-Aime Dorion, L. H. Holton and A. J. Smith who were against Confederation in 1867? With the exception of Mr. Dorion who had been a Prime Minister several years before, I had never heard of them.
We all know about George Washington and Thomas Jefferson in the United States. How many of us would remember names like George Mason, Richard Henry Lee, George Clinton and Robert Yates, the American anti-federalists of the time? They are no longer in the news today. No buildings or bridges were named after them.

There might be a moment of glory in being against this deal. Those who at this moment seek that advantage for their own personal gain, in the long term will be forgotten much easier because of what they are doing today.
I have the intention of voting in favour of this referendum.

I will urge my constituents to do likewise. This Saturday, I will set up a group in my riding to form a common front for the yes campaign in this referendum. Yesterday I contacted the presidents of the NDP, Progressive Conservative and Liberal riding associations and other groups. I invited them to a meeting on Saturday to form this common front in support of our country.
September 10, 1992



I also intend to organize three rallies in my riding, at least three. Perhaps this committee that I am appointing will recommend more. There will be one in Glengarry, one in Prescott and one in Russell.
They will be rallies which people could attend and hear speakers in favour of this constitutional accord. I would like to invite Conservative members of Parliament to come to my riding to speak at those rallies. In turn I would volunteer to go to theirs if that is what they choose.
I have never done that before as you can probably imagine.

Earlier today I was talking to the hon. member from Quebec City. He is a cousin of mine-once removed, but a cousin just the same. His family is originally from Cornwall, next door to my riding. In fact, his great-aunt, who is my great-aunt as well, still lives there. I asked the hon. member from Quebec City, the President of the Treasury Board, to come to my riding and make a speech during the referendum campaign and he said he was interested.
I invite other friends opposite to do the same, and perhaps I should explain that despite the impression we get from watching television, just because our role in the House is an adversarial one does not mean we are enemies. When I refer to my friends opposite, I mean what I say, because there are a number of members opposite I consider good friends. I would ask these parliamentarians to pay us a visit and I would be glad to share the platform with then.

The Leader of the Opposition said it well a few days ago when he reminded all of us that he had shared the stage in his own constituency in 1980 with the Leader of the Opposition, voluntarily doing so at that time in the 1980 referendum to speak with a united voice in favour of this country. It was that speech which inspired me to try to do the same thing in my own constituency in an attempt to show that we, as parliamentarians, not with-
Govemment Orders
standing our divergent opinions on many issues, can work together for the unity of this country.

That is why we all have a duty to work together to defend the interests of this great country of ours.

I am a Quebecer by birth, a franco-Ontarion. [Translation]
I have lived in the province of Ontario for many years, and the riding I have the privilege to represent in this House is right on the border with the province of Quebec. For instance, the eastern part of my riding borders on Quebec to the north, east and south.
Although I represent an Ontario riding, I feel at home and I am at home in both Quebec and Ontario, but I also want residents of Quebec to feel at home in Vancouver, Newfoundland and anywhere else in this country. Canadians should be made to feel once again that this country belongs to all of us. I would ask the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean and those who are like-minded to consider, when he flies over the Rockies in Alberta and British Columbia that those mountains belong to his children. He tends to forget that, and he is not alone.
I do not say this out of contempt for nationalist feelings, because there are times when members of a minority feel they are being treated unfairly, and they are often right. However, there is a difference between feelings aggrieved and refusing to have anything to do with the rest of the country.
I believe this constitutional agreement has managed to combine a certain measure of autonomy for the provinces and regions in this country with what I believe will remain a strong central government.
I also think that the principle of guaranteed representation for Quebec in the House of Commons provides a unique safeguard that recognizes the distinctness of Quebec.
I have read the agreement. I have also read what it says about language minorities outside Quebec. Of course there were concerns, but I am satisfied that the agreement contains sufficient safeguards for the minority in my own province and language minorities elsewhere in Canada.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders

I will vote for this accord. I ask all my constituents to do so as well. To all members of this House, to the few who disagree with my position on this, I say that there is still time. There is still time to reconsider for the greater good. George Brown did it some years ago. There is still time for all of us to think that way. Just maybe we will be remembered if we do it that way, not forgotten like some of the others who were against Constitution 125 years ago.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Nicole Roy-Arcelin (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Communications):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I will gladly share my speaking time with my colleague, the hon. member for Abitibi.
At this critical time of our history, this special moment when all Canadians, from Halifax to Quebec City to Vancouver, are about to decide the constitutional future of their country, I have the great honour, as member of Parliament for the beautiful riding of Ahuntsic, in Montreal, to take part today in this important debate to end the constitutional adventures, so to speak, of the past few decades.
Since 1867, the year the Confederation came together, the year that saw John A. MacDonald and George-Etienne Cartier decided to found a new country, Canada, a land where freedom and democracy would flourish and both founding nations, the French and the English, would unite to build a multiethnic and multicultural society. The Canadian people have encountered political ups and downs and obstacles that they have always managed to overcome and which in retrospect have strengthened their determination to live in freedom and unity.
This constitutional agreement is fair to the French speaking province of Quebec, with the distinct society clause protecting their higher interest for years to come, as well as to the English speaking provinces which scored some points with the Triple-E Senate.
This is also an historic moment in our life as a nation, as the native people of Canada, these oft forgotten First Nations, were invited for the first time to participate freely and fully to negotiations aimed at reshaping Canada as a land whose sons will all have equal opportunities to blossom, from Halifax to Vancouver.
As far as I am concerned, as a Quebecer and the member for Ahuntsic, one of the most francophone ridings in Montreal, I am proud to be a Canadian and to support this agreement which will allow Quebec to re-enter the Canadian family, as our Prime Minister had promised.
He did keep his word. Not only does this agreement which will close a chapter in our national history and open a new one respond favourably to the historical demands of Quebec, the economic, social and cultural development of which continued within Canada over the past 125 years and has been rather outstanding, but it sets out the main thrust for a renewed country with a nice spot for a truly empowered province of Quebec to blossom freely.
On top of the five conditions contained in the Meech Lake accord, Quebec made gains in the areas of training, manpower, forestry, mining, housing, municipal affairs, tourism, recreation and culture, the most important of which, in my opinion, aside from the distinct society clause, is the guarantee that at least 25 per cent of the representation in the House of Commons would be from Quebec at any given time, whatever the population of our province may be.
Because of our disappointingly low birth rate and our aging population, this guarantee gives Quebec unmatched political and decision-making power. Once they have learned about all these gains, Quebecers in general and the people of Ahuntsic in particular will approve this agreement, the only hope for a better future for their children. They will not listen to the sirens of independence who proclaim the division and breakup of a country that despite all its problems and difficulties has the best quality of life of 160 countries in the world, according to the United Nations. The place Quebec holds in Canada and in the world is envied by over 160 countries.
By giving a majority yes vote to this agreement, Quebecers, aware of the past that they have built with the other peoples of Canada and of the present that they are building with them in mutual respect, will give a clear answer that Quebec belongs in Canada and avoids hatred, racism and division.
I know that in the Quebec referendum, the advocates of independence will accuse us of being prophets of doom who frighten people. Is it the truth that frightens
September 10, 1992

them? Their idyllic talk of bright tomorrows has more to do with passion than with reason, with narrowness than with openness, with destruction than with construction.
By saying yes to this agreement, Quebecers in general and the people of Ahuntsic in particular will say yes to Canada and especially yes to Quebec.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Abitibi has eight minutes.

Madam Speaker, as part of my speech today, I would like to read into the record excerpts from an article by Roch Carrier published in the September 1992 edition of L'Actualite, in which he described incredibly eloquently his vision of Canada. I can only do him justice by quoting him. He said: "I have inherited Canada as a whole".
I do not intend to settle for a piece of it, be it celebrated by the poets. I feel no urge to leave Canada when people from all over the world are seeking refuge here. If we are to get off this boat, we better make sure that, like our separatist shepherds we can walk upon the water.
The global economic context will remain unchanged. What will become of us? We will be a smaller nation, so tiny next to the United States. We will also have lost the authority we presently have over the Canadian territory. No proclamation will change that.
The separatists claim that independence will give Quebec the tools required to control its own economy. When the reaction of the Tokyo or New York stock exchanges to some event sends shock waves world-wide, newly redefined boundaries-and what would they be- would not afford Quebec better protection.
Did Confederation prevent the growth of Bombardier, Lavalin or that of the Cirque du Soleil? There are admittedly a few irritants. That is no reason to scuttle a country. It calls for discussion, negotiation, not brooding!
China and Asia are restructuring their economies. Europe, Mexico, the U.S. and Canada are preparing for free trade. Latin America is putting its Mercosur into place. Black Sea countries are grouping together, and what is Quebec doing? Sadly a high percentage of our fine minds which have been preoccupied by constitution-
Government Orders
al humming and hawing for too long have been driven to stupidity by nationalism. Proclaim independence if you wish, but which state can claim to be independent in the world today with a 20 per cent illiteracy rate, with too many workers unable to meet today's challenges, with too many teenagers with very little education?
Is it really necessary to separate from Canada to put an end to this tragedy of so many young people condemned to a life of menial jobs, unemployment, prostitution and welfare? Unfortunately nationalist ramblings leave little room for those who want to decry the urgency of the situation.
I learned the lessons of tolerance from the French philosophers and I am extremely wary of nationalism. It can serve to unite a people without resources, as we saw 25 years ago. We no longer need nationalism. We should now be sufficiently lucid and self-confident to no longer need to worship the twist of fate which determined our place of birth.
The separatists want to take over all the economic tools in countries with a strong economy. It is quite obvious that the only economic tools are work, education, imagination, information, planning and ambition. No constitution can replace those tools.
According to nationalist doctrine, English-speaking Canadians constitute a homogeneous group whose only purpose is to threaten Quebecers. I find this vision of ourselves narrow minded, frustrating and disheartening. Are we really suffering that much? Is the St. Lawrence River overflowing with the tears of our distressed population? The only thing that matters is interdependency. A country can only be free if it is interdependent. In the chaos of recent years, certain populations have broken their chains. In the future, they will group together and probably reinvent what we now have in Canada.
Confederation is the best invention after democracy. It is based on the respect of differences. Someday, all countries will join in a world confederation where individuals will no longer be sacrificed to tribal rivalries. I may be naive, by I would rather be politically naive than adhere to an outdated nationalist ideal which takes its fear for courage, its withdrawal for conquest and its small mindedness for greatness.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
I believe that it would be a disaster in the long run to isolate ourselves. In Abitibi the people would rather work and have a stable job. They have families to support. What is most important for me is to help my constituents to put bread and butter on their table.
These are feelings that all of us, Canadians and Quebecers, should share because we have the marvellous opportunity of living in one of the best countries in the world, from sea to sea to sea. My Quebec understands Canada. On October 26 I shall be saying yes to this agreement, for Quebec and for Canada.

Madam Speaker, last week I was fortunate to attend a conference in London on the new Europe. The Danish foreign minister was in attendance at the same meeting and was asked the question: "What happened to the referendum in Denmark? Why was it defeated?"
He gave a very interesting answer that is important for all members to understand. He said: "We lost touch with the ground. We lost touch with the people. It was a matter of all the people in powerful positions, the politicians, the journalists, the academics all saying it was a good thing to have a- new Europe but we had not been able to touch the hearts and minds of the people we represented".
I raise that point because it is a lesson that is important for us all to recall as we embark upon this important referendum in Canada. We must not lose touch with the people. We must understand that their concerns and interests spread way beyond the legal wording of the Constitution. This important debate must be a time of listening. We cannot simply rely upon the public relations campaigns, the slick advertising, and the television promotions, but must be out there listening to what they have to say, listening to both the advocates and the critics, those who support it and those who are against it.
They are all going to be trying in their own way to define what this country is, to use this important occasion, as Canada debates where it wants to go, to discuss where the country should be in the future. It is a chance, if you like, to awaken the slumbering potential for goodwill within the country, to bring people together from all parts of the country in a common cause.

I remember this past summer we welcomed the young voyageurs from Drummondville riding, which is represented by their good MP. We had a party on the shore of Lake Winnipeg, which was discovered by La Verendrye over 100 years ago. It is very important to have groups from Quebec and Manitoba get together to discuss concerns like work and our common future.

These young people from Quebec and from Manitoba were not making false distinctions based upon some kind of frontiers that were divided 100 years ago. They were young people searching for their own concern about the future and looking forward to a relevance coming from the political system that maybe we had not been providing as well or as effectively as we should have in the past.
Let us use this time effectively. Let us use this time well to make sure that those rare meetings that I was part of in my constituency this summer on the shores of Lake Winnipeg when two groups of young people got together to talk in both their languages about their common problems is an example for the entire country to fulfil.
Let us make no illusions. There are concerns out there that will not be answered by this particular set of propositions in this deal. In my own part of Canada there is deep unrest and unhappiness about some of the proposals as they relate to the Senate. It is not a matter of being equal, it was a question of having a better balance of power in Confederation. Western Canadians felt that they had a better chance of having their voice heard and being listened to in this Parliament and in the councils of national influence and decision making. For many westerners that was not achieved in this deal. That is not in itself reason to oppose it because what we should be saying is that there are chances in the future to improve, to augment and to change.
My own leader, in his speech a few days ago, indicated that one of our concerns and interests will be to use the debate on the legislation of the Senate to ensure that there is a clear understanding that the Senate is not simply another chamber to which we refer legislation. It is the balance wheel of Confederation for the less populated regions, for the hinterlands. We must bring that together to make sure that it is not a question of
September 10, 1992

numbers, it is a question of fairness and equity. Equal was not the operative word, it was equitable and fairness that had to be applied.
There will be much work to do to make people understand how we can use this constitutional referendum to listen to people from western Canada who are going to talk about Senate reform, and we will hear that, to say that this is not the end of the chapter, it is just that we have to write more chapters to improve upon them.
Similarly, think about the concerns, and again I reflect on my constituents, of what is happening in our cities across Canada such as the incredible case of joblessness among our young people and older workers being laid off, a real shortage of social housing and, real problems of public safety on the streets.
In this deal we talk about exclusive concern for urban affairs, housing and training being turned over to the provinces. It is going to be very important that we show Canadians during this time that simply giving exclusive jurisdiction does not mean the end of concern or involvement or an attempt to work together in a co-operative partnership way to deal with those real underlying, deep abiding sores that afflict Canadian society at the present time.
I look forward to and welcome this referendum. I think it is a great opportunity for us not only to encourage Canadians to agree to a deal that will repair some of the injuries of the past but will also provide some building blocks for the future.
We must do it in the proper spirit and the proper sense. In that sense I go back to a saying that I will never forget. Vaclav Havel, the former President of Czechoslovakia, had just left office. He wrote a book, Summer Meditations, which I read just in the last month or two. He said: "Those who find themselves in politics bear a heightened responsibility for the moral state of society, and it is their responsibility to seek out the best in that society, to develop it and to strengthen it".
We have a rare opportunity, one that has come around maybe only every third or fourth decade, to bring Canadians together and to give them the leadership that we in elected office have to provide, to bring out the best in society, to awaken the best potential, to make sure
Government Orders
that we understand that this is not a matter of a battle between good and evil. It is a matter of how we find the best potential for all Canadians. We must reason together in both our languages, in all our regions, to ensure that the referendum becomes not a matter of dividing Canadians but of bringing them together and showing them that we can now go on to deal with the issues that concern the people of this country so that they do not lose touch with the ground but rather bring us all together.

Madam Speaker, I rise today as a Canadian who is proud of my country and a Quebecer proud of my province to say that I support the constitutional proposals and I encourage all Canadians and especially the people of Saint-Laurent-Cartierville to say yes to the referendum question. I encourage all Quebecers to say yes to a promising future in which the French language and culture will be protected in a country of 27 million.
I encourage all Quebecers to say yes to employment and a more stable economic future. I encourage all Canadians to say yes because the time has come to change political priorities. The time has come to talk about the economy and to find solutions for the problems affecting everyone.

Provincial premiers, territorial leaders and representatives of our native communities have said yes to a new constitutional deal. They have said yes to a new Canada and have now asked us through this question to say yes to Canada as well.
I believe that this deal will at the same time protect the interests of Quebec's francophone population and ensure the survival of a vibrant English speaking community in a Quebec that is strong and that is also a strong member of the Canadian family.

We are gathered here in this House today to approve the question that will be presented to Canadians on October 26. The question is simple and the options are clear.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
However, some people do not want to have anything to do with Canada. Members of the Parti Quebecois and the Bloc Quebecois want an independent Quebec. They oppose these offers because they are basically against political union with the rest of Canada.
Their leader, the member for Lac-Saint-Jean, says that the Charlottetown accord gives Quebecers nothing. That is completely wrong. Quebec is guaranteed 25 per cent of the seats in this House and is entitled to 33 per cent of the judges on the Supreme Court. Recognition of Canada's linguistic duality is reflected in the distinct society clause.
But the separatists' struggle will continue not because they want to improve Quebecers' daily lives but because they have an ideological agenda. They have a personal agenda that has nothing to do with the betterment of our province.

These people would never be satisfied with any offers from the federal government because they are ideologically committed to the break-up of our country. Do you think they really care about the average citizens of our province? Do you think they really care about the well-being of the aging population, the seniors? Do they have a plan to look after the homeless or the poor? Do you think they have a plan to battle skyrocketing unemployment and to settle political instability? The answer on all counts is absolutely no.

I think it would be a good thing at this time to remind ourselves that the agreement reached in Charlottetown on August 28 represents the conclusion of a long consultation process undertaken across the country. Everyone had the opportunity to participate in this process to express their expectations, their doubts and their hopes. Every Canadian had a chance to speak out and today we see the results. The active participation of the Canadian people through briefs, submissions and interventions was the first step. The second step will be the upcoming vote for or against the proposed package. It is important that every one of us as Canadian citizens has a say in the final decision. It is our duty. Nothing should be taken for granted. We must work together to win the fight for a strong Quebec within a united
Canada. We live in a wonderful country offering the highest standard of living in the world.
Our country is rich in physical and human resources. We cannot risk losing everything because we have become indifferent to what is happening. Every vote is important because the total number of votes will dictate the policy to be followed by the Prime Minister.

October 26 must be at the same time an end to a process and a beginning of a new time in our history, a time when we will be able to declare once and for all that the Constitution is settled.
This constitutional deal needs the support of all Quebecers committed to a united Canada. That is why I am making a personal appeal to the people of Saint-Laurent-Cartierville and Saraguay to get out and vote. Tell all of Canada that you want to remain part of this country. Tell the separatists that they do not speak for Quebecers or Quebec and tell them so by voting yes on October 26.
I would also like to send a message to members of all three federal parties in my riding. We need your help. We need your fight and your help to keep Canada united. As the Prime Minister and leaders of the oppositions have said, this is beyond partisan politics. There will be time for that later. We need each and every one of the people committed to Canada to join us in a proud fight for our country and our province. The alternative is not a pretty sight. There is no pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and there is no paradise in a separate Quebec.
Let us not kid ourselves. A vote for the no side on October 26 will set in motion the gears that will result in independence. A vote for the yes has the chance of putting a nail in the coffin of the separatist option.

The question should be simple and specific, quite a challenge in an environment with a tendency to elaborate endlessly. We seem to have succeeded, as Canadians will soon be able to judge for themselves. The people of this country will read, debate among themselves and make up their own minds so that they can tell us in the referendum what they want their country to be.
September 10, 1992

The coming days will be tense. There will be discussions and differences of opinion but we must remember, however difficult it may be, that we are first and foremost citizens of a wonderful country. Let us make every effort to keep it strong and united. On October 26 vote yes for a strong Quebec within a united Canada.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip's assistant; Deputy Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, on October 26, 1992, Canadians, Quebecers and the residents of Levis will have to vote on the constitutional agreement that was recently proposed to all of Canada.
In the days following this agreement I had the opportunity to discuss it with some representatives of my riding. Their comments could be grouped into three categories. First are those who question specific points.
I was told that more could have been done to abolish trade barriers among the provinces of Canada. They could have been made unconstitutional or lower trade barriers could have been encouraged and east-west trade made easier. I was also told that some duplication in some departments was overlooked. However, we know that this agreement is the result of consensus and that a perfect agreement is not possible. Perfection is the enemy of the good, something like acrobatics is bad for gymnastics. We must try to have what can be obtained and not something unrealistic. We have an agreement. This is the best agreement since 1867. It does not contain everything that each of Canada's 27 million citizens might want, nor does it have some features that the 7 million Quebecers in Canada might desire, but it bears the signatures of the Prime Minister of Canada, the ten provincial premiers and the First Nations' representatives.
This agreement is the conclusion of a generation of effort. It includes the historic demands of Quebecers. Among other things we are guaranteed three Supreme Court judges, 33 1/3 per cent of its members, forever, because of our civil code is different. This agreement guarantees that we will have 25 per cent of the members of the House of Commons of Canada. It confirms what the Quebec Act, 1774, said, namely that Quebec is a distinct society. It confirms that formally and irrevocably. This agreement gives Quebec full authority over immigration, education, manpower training, the management and exploitation of its natural resources, etc.
I also heard some very negative comments. People spoke to me of humiliation, defeat, groveling, kowtowing; they said Bourassa is a traitor and so on. That is the kind of talk usually heard where Quebec separatists
Government Orders
congregate, but is it even worth commenting on? Can such language be justified? On the contrary, does it not show the lack of practical substantial reasons for Quebecers to take their province out of Canada? These comments are exaggerated. When we ask for positive things that would flow from separation, they answer "Campeau". Who is Campeau? He was an accountant at the Caisse de depot, which handles mainly funds from government employees. When he went into management, the first thing he did resulted in a $500-million loss for Domtar; the second thing he did with other people's money cost Quebec $100 million in the Steinberg affair.
They tell us about Parizeau. Parizeau incurred a $500-million loss, the press reported recently. The asbestos corporation is being sold again because Parizeau made a half billion dollar mistake.
They tell us about Larose. They say that he must be a sensible guy. I talked about Larose to my constituents. In my riding the shipyards employ 3,500 people. I talked to the wives, the workers, their children and relatives and I told them, "Ask Larose who uses your dues to attack the federal government what has kept the shipyards going for ten years". Every cent comes from the federal government. What is Larose proposing to them? Nothing. He tells them, "Separate and we'll see after".
Finally, I met supporters of the agreement who will say yes for its intrinsic qualities and its positive effect on the economy and because the alternative would be a fiasco for our families and middle class, who would have to pay more tax for a generation as Parizeau and Lucien Bouchard have admitted.
Mr. Parizeau and Lucien Bouchard admitted that those people will have to pay more tax for a generation. Remember that Mr. Parizeau is capable of doing that because he is the one who cut Quebec public servants' pay by 20 per cent at one point. It would be a fiasco for seniors who are worried about their income security and social services. Where will they get the money so that our old people can continue to live comfortably? It is a fiasco for the less fortunate. Where will they get the money to continue to assist our disadvantaged? We have no specifics from the propagandists of separation. It is a fiasco for our young people as well except for those who camp in front of the legislature. Young people who want to develop the country but not break it up, who want to continue and not start all over, still want a solid founda-

September 10, 1992
tion. That is why they ask us to vote yes and yes is the way the riding of Levis will answer.
