Mr. Speaker, I too would like to join with my colleagues, many of whom have said they will be voting yes in the referendum. I think there are very few people in this House of Commons who would be on the no side.

Madam Speaker, when I first heard the question "do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28,1992 in Charlottetown", I smiled inwardly as I contemplated the public's reaction, a public that has become cynical because we have not dealt with this matter more expeditiously.
As I have said many times in this House compromise lacks perfection. Perhaps perfection is achievable only at another level, but now we have an outstanding compromise before us.
We should learn from the turmoil in other parts of the world that this is an extremely important matter. Constituents of Regina-Wascana will treat it as such.
Early this year I circulated a comprehensive questionnaire on constitutional matters. The intelligent, informed and passionate results form the basis of my own personal constitutional position which I circulated to each household in my riding.
Decision time is here. I pledged to my constituents to make myself available, for it is important to send signals to other Canadians of how important our respective contributions can be. We must show ourselves that we do not have to be exactly the same to be equal and by living in different areas of this vast country, we still have the same aspirations.
We must become informed Canadians in order that on referendum day we can all smile inwardly as we vote with
I would like to draw your attention to the serious labour dispute between Royal Oak Mines Incorporated of Yellowknife and the members of the Smelter and Allied Workers Union. This has been ongoing since May 23 of this year.
I and my colleague, the labour critic for the New Democratic Party, feel the time has come to proceed with an industrial disputes inquiry with a view to restoring confidence and jobs in Yellowknife. My colleague, the member for Western Arctic and I have been particularly worried about the rapidly deteriorating situation which has led to tension and the feeling of unnecessary and unduly harsh police intervention in this matter.
I would like the House to take notice of this point.

Mr. Speaker, today I want to pay tribute to Louise Arcand who was a host, a reader and a journalist with Radio-Canada for more than 20 years and whose sudden death last month, at the age of 48 from brain cancer saddened us all in Abitibi and in Amos where she was born.
All agree that Louise was a remarkable woman, a formidable go-getter with great strength of character, like her parents and the members of her family, who are pioneers in Amos.
Louise found out about her illness in the spring of 1991. At that time, she had been a journalist for three years on the program Les affaires et la vie on Radio-Canada.


September 10, 1992

Louise will remain present in the hearts of the people of Abitibi. She will remain close to us all.

Mr. Speaker, with Bill C-91 being rammed through this House next week low priced generic drugs will be sacrificed on the altar of the Mexico-U.S. free trade deal.
The promises made in connection with the Canada-U.S. trade deal in the previous drug patent bill of 1987 have not been honoured. The promised 3,000 research jobs have not materialized and more than 700 jobs in the drug manufacturing area have been lost. The promise of not a single cent in higher drug prices is ignored.
This government even ignores its own drug price regulations when 40 per cent of all new drugs are allowed to exceed the price guidelines of the Drug Prices Review Board.
Bill C-91 will compound these mistakes because the NAFTA negotiations required the sacrifice of the cost efficient generic drugs as part of the George Bush trade deal.

Mr. Speaker, every spring tens of thousands of farmers take to the fields from Prince Edward Island to British Columbia planting millions upon millions of acres of fertile soil in the hopes they will receive a good bountiful harvest.
This year, although the weather was damp and different, that bountiful harvest seemed to project a tremendous result and guess what happened. As we stand here today, there are thousands of acres of grains in the west, in Alberta, that have been pushed down because of snow. We have had tremendous rainfalls which hamper the harvest and now we have had frost to damage the quality of the crop.
As I sit here, every member of this House and everyone in this country should pray that some good weather will come so that we can in fact reap this harvest. Then Canada can once again sustain the markets that it has and it can feed those in great poverty around the world. It can also help the farmers end up making a little bit of profit.
Thank God we had the foresight to put in programs like GRIP to improve the crop insurance programs farmers can turn to. Yes, we are hoping to bring the cash advance because farmers need help today. Pray for good weather.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians with disabilities are disappointed that they have been left out of the Canada clause in the constitutional agreement. This came as a surprise because the federal government's draft proposals last September, Shaping Canada's Future Together, included a clear reference to disabled persons.
The Canada clause contains a number of provisions to protect specific groups in society including aboriginal people, linguistic groups, ethnic groups and women.
Persons with disabilities want to know why they have not been included this time. They would like some assurance that their rights will not have a lesser degree of judicial protection than those other groups.
There is particular concern about disability rights following the cancellation of the Court Challenges Program earlier this year. This program helped disabled Canadians and other communities clarify their legal rights under the charter and in the courts.
Canadians with disabilities are looking for some sign that this government is committed to the protection and promotion of their rights.

Mr. Speaker, during the past summer an experiment was tried in British Columbia allowing for a native commercial fishery.
Also this year there has been an alarming decimation of some salmon spawning runs with only a small percentage of the salmon expected actually arriving on the spawning grounds. One of the factors is no doubt the native fishery.

September 10,1992
This is not due to the fact that the fishery occurred but that there has been a complete failure to enforce the regulations, to keep accurate catch tallies and to control the escapement of adequate spawning stocks on several rivers.
An extremely tense situation is developing between whites and natives and between various native groups. I call on the government to get control of this fishery situation immediately by enforcing all regulations to ensure that which occurred on the Fraser does not develop elsewhere, notably in the Port Alberni and Cowichan areas.

Mr. Speaker, veterans affairs offices across this country have received thousands of calls of concern, fear and anger from veterans whose independence program benefits have been drastically cut. This valuable program allows veterans to remain in their own homes at minimal cost to taxpayers.
The minister's office has assured me there may have been miscommunication to veterans, but in reality there were no cuts. I would ask the minister to relay this good news to the thousands of veterans and hundreds of councillors who indicate quite definitely that the cuts are real and dramatic.
I cite one example of a recent stroke victim whose monthly benefit has been cut from $300 a month to $6.11 per month. Health needs were not a consideration of those who made an arbitrary, unjust decision against the advice and judgment of those who work in the field.
Rumour has it the minister is reconsidering this decision and will restore the original monthly allotments already promised to veterans. I ask him to do so promptly. Veterans are the least among us who should be subjected to this kind of treatment.
There is a positive prologue. In discussion with the veterans affairs office in Prince Edward Island I was told things will be well very soon.

Mr. Speaker, on Saturday August 22, in Charlottetown, the federal and provincial governments agreed on a new project for the renewal of the Constitution.
This agreement is one of the most ambitious constitutional renewal projects ever undertaken by our governments since 1867. This accord is extremely important for Quebecers since it takes into account the traditional claims made by their province throughout its history. In spite of some flaws this is a good agreement. It gives Quebec solid guarantees concerning its identity as well as new powers.
This new deal negotiated by Quebec provides Quebecers with the necessary tools for their economic, social and cultural development. I am proud to give my full support to the agreement because it represents the best possible compromise between Quebec and its Canadian partners.

Mr. Speaker, not long ago, Canadians marvelled at Silken Lauman's determination and Sylvie Frechette's dignity and grace during the Summer Olympics in Barcelona. Indeed the Canadian team got the best results ever obtained by Canada in any non-boycotted Olympic Games. With 16 medals our athletes represented Canada with honour and the highest sportsmanship, showing once again the unifying power of sports in Canada and its role in the history and culture of our people.
Sports fans across Canada enthusiastically encouraged our athletes. They did not care where these athletes came from. The important thing was to know that they were giving their best.
On behalf of the House of Commons and all Canadians, I salute the Canadian participants in the Barcelona Games whose outstanding performances dazzled us. I also want to extend my best wishes to Canadian athletes who take part in the Paraolympic Games for paraplegics in Barcelona.
September 10,1992

Mr. Speaker, this week the OECD issued its report card on Canada's economy. It had some good news and some bad news.
The good news is that Canada's economy is expected to grow 2.3 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent next year. Inflation should hold steady at 2.4 per cent this year and next and the unemployment rate should drop to 9.9 per cent by the second half of next year.
The bad news is that we are not getting value for our money when it comes to education. Canada is the biggest spender on education in the G-7. However, too many students are graduating from high school functionally illiterate.
The OECD message is that if we are to prosper as a country in the future we have to ensure that our young people have the skills to meet the challenges of the next century. Education is a type of investment. Let us make sure that we invest wisely.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, once again the Minister of Employment and Immigration has failed workers in the rural area of Westmorland. After giving them a glimmer of hope in June he has refused to take any action and is now ignoring them. The unemployment situation in the area is as serious as anywhere else, and workers will be unable to find enough weeks of work to make them eligible for unemployment insurance.

The minister cannot ignore the situation in which the workers find themselves. He has to find a way to render justice to the workers of rural Westmorland who are in a completely different situation from the people living across the street in the riding of Kent.

The people of this region deserve better from this government.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to express my deepest condolences to the family of six-year old Corinne Gustavson. Tragically, the day before yesterday, her body was found sexually assaulted and smothered. This incident is only one of many violent sexual assault crimes which occurred this summer in Edmonton.
Many Edmontonians have called my office and those of my colleagues to express their belief that our justice system has failed.
We need to send a clear message that such crimes will no longer be tolerated. We need to increase the education in our society about sexual abuse and provide education and treatment for those offenders. We must impose tougher penalties on violent and dangerous offenders. We must restore the faith of Canadians in our justice system.

Mr. Speaker, within the last month veterans have received a letter from Veterans Affairs informing them that the department is changing its payment process for some VIP services. Instead of submitting receipts every month, the VIP recipients will receive an advance cheque to cover their average monthly expenses. This amount was derived from the expenses incurred by the veteran last year and does not necessarily reflect the ceiling amounts allotted to each individual by the department.
Many veterans have contacted my office and expressed fear that this was changed without cause.
Have the veterans and their organizations asked that this change be made? We can ask ourselves and the minister if this change has been brought about to benefit the veterans, or has it been brought about to benefit the government that will now be able to run a more computerized and less personal service to the veterans? Will the minister assure the House that this change has been carefully thought out and is not the forerunner of diminished service to our veterans?

September 10,1992
Oral Questions
We must always remind ourselves that the payments made to veterans are not a benefit but rather their right as a grateful country tries to pay them back for the valuable service they performed.

Mr. Speaker, this government's failure in the mid-1980s to develop a national youth policy helped create Canada's generation x, a generation largely ill prepared by education and training for the present or future economy. Statistics on youth suicide, crime, violence and drug use depict a rising level of social pathology linked with a high youth unemployment rate of 19.2 per cent, nearly double the national rate.
Neo-conservatism and its Darwinian economics continue to fail these youth as well as other Canadians. The government gives us free trade and now NAFTA so that profits are reaped by sending jobs south. It talks of the new competitiveness while cutting training, post-secondary education and job creation expenditures for youth.
What could be a stupider approach to a high value added economy? What more perverse a denial of the opportunities necessary to build it? When will the government understand that future prosperity is indispensably dependent upon the opportunity for Canadians to learn and to create, or that economic growth and social justice must go hand in hand? Or, will the continued failure of this government lead to Canadian generations y and z and perhaps omega?

Mr. Speaker, in June of this year the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans announced a ban on the northern cod fishery, and I supported that decision. But that decision has deprived a great number of fishermen and plant workers in my riding of a substantial source of their revenue.
I would like to ask the minister today to speed up the process so that compensation payments start flowing to those communities as soon as possible.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Deputy Prime Minister.
My question is related to the merger of Air Canada and Canadian Airlines yesterday. As we all know, Canada's first Prime Minister drove the last spike in building the national railway and the present Prime Minister is driving the last nail in the coffin of airline competition in Canada.
In the face of the announcement yesterday, what is this government planning to do to maintain some competition in the air in Canada?

Mr. Speaker, representatives of both national airlines have indicated yesterday in separate press releases that they had agreed in principle to a merger, that a merger committee would be put together with representatives from both airlines, and that the details of the transaction would be ironed out in that committee.
When that deal is complete, it will be investigated by two agencies of the government. At that time we will know what the content of the transaction is and we will be able to act accordingly.

Mr. Speaker, it is common knowledge that one of the main causes of the financial difficulties of both companies is the price war which has been raging during the past few years. As I said earlier, as soon as the transaction is complete it will

September 10, 1992

be examined and the Bureau of Competition Policy will ensure that competition will continue to exist within Canada's civil aviation system.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to direct my question to the Deputy Prime Minister.
As everybody knows, a very conservative estimate of the loss of jobs in that transaction is at least 6,000. Of course the Minister of Finance who seems to be comfortable with 1.6 million people unemployed might not be too preoccupied with that.
I would like to quote the Deputy Prime Minister. On July 16, 1985, when he was Minister of Transport, he said: "We promise to assist those who might suffer severe economic dislocation under a new regulatory regime".
Will the Minister of Finance keep the promise he expressed in this House in 1985?

Mr. Speaker, during the talks held in recent weeks the federal government made sure that Canadian Airlines International would have a chance to examine all the options, including the generous proposal made by its employees. We did our utmost, and we hope that other levels of government would do the same.

Mr. Speaker, I would also like to remind the Minister of Transport of something that was said by his predecessor and now Minister of Finance in the House of Commons on April 12, 1988. He said: "The results of regulatory reform and the passage of the National Transportation Act have created a new environment and with it a stable, viable and very competitive airline sector in Canada".
Now we know that the result of the policies pursued by this government is an unstable, non-competitive and in fact monopolistic airline environment in Canada.
The minister now has two choices before him. Is he planning to re-regulate the industry and turn back the reforms of his colleague, or is he planning to let U.S.
Oral Questions
carriers compete on Canadian routes against this new merged carrier? Which one will it be?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has probably not examined the results of deregulation properly, because he would have noticed, for instance, that total passenger traffic grew by 19.5 per cent from 1986 to 1990 to almost 37 million passengers and passenger kilometres on scheduled services grew by 25.3 per cent to 50 billion.
The situation in which the Canadian airlines are finding themselves at the present time is equivalent to what other airlines around the world find themselves in not because of deregulation but because of the Persian Gulf war which was the spark plug of the present situation and the world-wide recession that ensued.

Mr. Speaker, I think the minister might look at the war of attrition between our two air carriers that was carried on without any direction or policy interference by the Government of Canada.

All the experts agree that the airline resulting from this merger will not be able to survive without a major injection of capital. Surely the government examined the same figure. Can the minsiter tell us how much Canadian taxpayers will have to pay to help this new giant of the skies, with its super debt of $8 billion?

Mr. Speaker, I rise in tribute today to a very special woman, a very extraordinary member of Parliament and a passionate Canadian, Pauline Jewett.
Before I begin I would like to mention that the member for New Westminster-Burnaby who replaced Pauline Jewett, who worked for Pauline Jewett for many years, is not able to be here as there was a memorial service last night in Vancouver for Pauline and she sends her regrets for being unable to return in time today.
Pauline Jewett had a remarkable career as a professor, as the first woman to become president of a Canadian university, a university chancellor and a member of Parliament. Pauline was a fighter who took on the struggle for social justice and never let it go. She was a pioneer who opened doors that had for far too long been closed to women. The changes that she helped to make still echo today both through the halls of higher learning and on the floor of this House of Commons.
September 10, 1992

One of the changes she made of course was moving from the Liberal to the New Democratic Party, an example of her great wisdom and an example I know that all members of this House will agree is sure to be followed by millions of Canadians in the years ahead.
Pauline Jewett was indeed a woman of great vision. She had a vision of a world free from nuclear threat where common security and international development took the place of arms races and poverty. She saw in Canada a country that could embrace all its peoples and in particular the people of Quebec.

Pauline firmly believed that the Constitution should be renewed. Almost every time I spoke to her during her last months, she wanted to talk about the Constitution: every new development, every new turn in the debate, every new information. She wanted to know everything, to hear everything. She was a fanatic about the Constitution because she was a fanatic about her country.
She never relented in her struggle for equality. She stood up to everyone. She gave in to nobody, neither to the administration of Simon Fraser University nor to four prime ministers of Canada.

Sometimes Pauline Jewett won her struggles and sometimes she knew victory would have to wait for a little while, but she never gave up. Perhaps the greatest of her struggles was with the disease that eventually claimed her life. Despite the pain of that last fight, she faced it with humour, courage and dignity.
In many ways, if I may allow a personal note, I learned more from Pauline in those final months than I will learn from many of the fine speeches made in Parliament.
With Pauline's passing my party has lost one of our most passionate and dedicated voices. Canada has lost one of our real heroes, but Pauline Jewett's spirit will live on in our work for fairness and equality, for the healing of our country's divisions and for a world that rejects mass destruction and embraces peace and justice for all.
Canada will miss Pauline Jewett. Her party will miss her. She is a great loss to us all.

speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise too with my colleagues to pay tribute to our former colleague, Pauline Jewett, whose death this summer has really saddened us all.
Pauline was a very special person. She was a trail blazer in so many different fields. She was a woman who never feared to speak her mind and she was never consumed by blind partisanship. I think that is one of the reasons she had so many friends on all sides of this House and I know the deepest respect of the Prime Minister.
She served in this House for two different periods. Of course the first one was as a Liberal and then later as an NDP, the period when I got to know her.
However, that was not her only contribution to Canada. We all know of Pauline's outstanding work, particularly her presidency of Simon Fraser University. She was the first woman to hold the presidency of a major Canadian university. She was indeed a trail-blazer during those years. She refused to be daunted by the sometimes sexist comments or arrangements that existed. She broke down so many barriers for women.
She was a founder and president of the Canadian Research Foundation for the Advancement of Women. She was on the forefront in all areas for the advancement of equality of women, not only by what she said but by what she did. It was for those reasons that she was indeed a role model and a mentor for so many others.
Pauline will certainly play a very major role in the history of this country and she will go down in the history books. As the leader of the NDP has said, she loved this country with such a great sense of passion. She understood its diversity and its uniqueness. She lived in many parts of the country. She cared deeply about international issues, the arms race and the fundamental equality of all persons.
I had many opportunities to meet with Pauline as friends, and we spent some time on trips together. Her contribution was very special. I was so pleased when that contribution was recognized, not only with an Order of Canada but by being made a member of the Privy

September 10, 1992
Tributes
Council in the last days of her life, an honour that she so richly deserved.
She would show strength and determination throughout all her life but perhaps none more than during those last months when she was faced with her illness.
Pauline was an example to us all. We are very much the lesser by her passing. I would ask that we all be left with her legacy, which is the empowerment of all of us in public life, to reflect on her spirit, her decency and her determination to achieve fairness for all persons. Her life has left us richer and in a better country.

Mr. Speaker, it is my privilege to speak in honour of the life of a distinguished member of Parliament, an officer of the Order of Canada and a member of the Privy Council of Canada, Pauline Jewett.
Although Ms. Jewett spent most of her years in this House as a member of the NDP caucus she began her House of Commons career in 1963 as the elected Liberal member for my riding of Northumberland. Although she was born in St. Catharines, Ontario, she felt a kinship for the village of Brighton in my riding where several of her relatives lived.
As relayed to me by constituents, Pauline was a very self-directed person, bright yet very personable, and an inspiration to many. She determined to seek the Liberal nomination in Northumberland and to this day she is remembered fondly in Northumberland by many of all political stripes.
Pauline not only made her mark in Northumberland but across Canada. As a member of the NDP caucus she held critic portfolios in external affairs, arms control and disarmament, post-secondary education and federal-provincial relations, among others. Pauline was also a very strong advocate of women's issues and rights and we owe her much for advancing women's legitimate role in Canadian society.
Pauline Jewett was the first female elected as a member of Parliament for the riding of Northumberland and certainly broke important ground for me as a female successor some 25 years later. It was not an insignificant
feat to become a female member in the rural conservative riding of Northumberland in 1963.
We remember Pauline Jewett for her many contributions to Canada, especially to post-secondary education. I personally remember her vividly and fondly for the phone call of congratulations I received from Pauline shortly after my election. She spoke affectionately of her former riding of Northumberland and with pleasure that once again a woman held that seat.
As she maintained a special affection for Northumberland, so many constituents remember Pauline Jewett with a similar affection and with respect for her many accomplishments.
We are the richer for her contributions.
May her family and friends be healed of the sorrow of her loss with the memory of the important contributions that Pauline Jewett made to Canadian society.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to join in this tribute to Pauline Jewett.
Both the member for Yukon and the member for Northumberland referred to her previous career both in the Liberal Party and the New Democratic Party. The member for Yukon mentioned her both as a politician and as a professor.
I first knew her as my professor when I was at Carleton University. She was my supervisor when I was doing my thesis essay. Through that experience I came to know much about her commitment to issues, public life, and public policy formation.
The thesis that I was working on concerned the role of public opinion in Canada, its formation and its influence on Parliament and public policy making. Certainly a lot that I came to understand about that, which subsequently gave rise to things like my initiative here with a referendum on a plebiscite bill, goes back to some lessons that were learned with Pauline Jewett out at the Rideau River campus of Carleton University in the early and mid-1960s.
In concluding, I would like mention the song of another woman from British Columbia, Ann Mortifee. In one of her lyrics she talks about the fact that life is not confined by time. Pauline Jewett in her experience
September 10,1992

andlife voyage has shown us that. She has also shown us that political commitment is not confined by party or by party boundaries.
More important than party boundaries is a commitment to fundamental principles. That was the hallmark of her career throughout. It is fitting that these tributes are being paid to her at a time when in the House of Commons, which she served so nobly for so many years, we are setting aside party differences to concentrate on something fundamental like the formation of Canadian public opinion about our country and its future.
In a broad sense that is a way that all of us as parliamentarians through our words and actions in this place today are paying tribute to what Pauline Jewett stood for.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to say a few words about the late Pauline Jewett.
I had a chance to get to know her and work closely with her for a number of years. I regarded her as a close personal friend, as I know many other members did. She was a great Canadian who made a great contribution to this country and had a very distinguished public career. She was also a very warm individual, a very outgoing and friendly human being. She touched and moved thousands of people whom she came in contact with over her lifetime.
I know all members of this House join in paying tribute to the contribution she made to this country and the impact that she had on our lives and those of so many others in Canada.

I want to express my thanks to hon. members for the comments that have been made. Perhaps I can also observe that I knew our former colleague very well, especially during her years in British Columbia.

Mr. Speaker, my point of order concerns the failure of the minister of Indian affairs to comply with Standing Order 109.
Point of Order
That Standing Order requires the government to respond to a report of a standing or special committee within 150 days, if the committee requests such a response at the time the report is tabled in the House.
On February 13, 1992, at page 6919 of Hansard, the chairman of the Select Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs tabled the second report of the committee relating to the Arctic exiles of Grise Fiord on Ellesmere Island.
The chairman made the request, pursuant to section 109, that the government table a comprehensive response within 150 days. I have checked with the minister's office and with the Journals Branch. To my count 210 days have now passed and the government is seriously in violation of Standing Order 109. The minister is saying that he refuses to meet with the Grise Fiord people until the report is tabled in the House and on the other hand he refuses to table the report in the House, contrary to the Standing Orders.
I would urge you, Mr. Speaker, to investigate this matter and to take whatever action is necessary to ensure that the government respects the Standing Orders of Parliament.

speechtext: The hon. member for Carleton-Charlotte for seven minutes.

Mr. Speaker, to begin I will pick up where I left off on Tuesday, September 8. Under Standing Order 31 I did have a few comments on the national referendum.
In my comments on Tuesday afternoon I pointed out that the question we will be facing as Canadians on October 26 will be very simple and very straightforward. At that time, not knowing exactly what the question would be, I suggested it might be as follows: "Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached August 28, 1992? Yes or No". That will in fact be the question we will be addressing on October 26. Canadians will have to decide if the answer is yes or no.
One of the things I pointed out in my comments was that although the question itself is simple and straightforward, the constitutional package that we will in fact be voting on is rather complex. There will be many Canadians, in fact there are many Canadians today, asking what is in that package and wondering if they will know on October 26 exactly what they are voting on.
This will be the first time in 50 years that Canadians have had a chance to express themselves through a national referendum. That question concerning whether they will know is a very important one. That is where we as members of Parliament come in. Many of us in the last couple of days in the House have taken the opportunity to step through the package and attempt to explain in our own way what we see in it.
That is what we will have to do back in our constituencies as well. That is what I am committing myself to do back in my home riding of Carleton-Charlotte. In other ridings around the country if I am invited to speak I will.
This is really a follow-up to a consultation process. We are going back almost two years, spending at least 17 months on this whole process of constitutional renewal. We all know what has happened in the last couple of years.
As suggested this morning by, I believe it was the hon member for Esquimau-Juan de Fuca, after the collapse of Meech Lake he said that the message was to go to another lake. As he suggested, and I suggest, they did that. The Canadian people did. We have done it together. We have moved on from that and we have gone through a very lengthy consultative process.
We have gone through the various committees and the Spicer commission. Provincial governments have done the same thing. Individual members of Parliament have gone back to their constituencies and have carried that process forward as well, wanting to know the views of individual Canadians on the Constitution.
I did that as a member of Parliament in Carleton- Charlotte. We had 20 such meetings in my constituency. We started out late last fall and into the early winter months. I had a chance to hear what my constituents thought. It was a very helpful and healthy process.
The logical conclusion to this is for members of Parliament to get out into their constituencies and explain the proposals. Much of what we discussed in those late autumn days of 1991 and early winter months of 1992 are in these proposals and that is very refreshing.
Obviously much has been left out and there is some in there we do not agree with, but it will be up to me and others who will join me to explain what is in there so when our constituents from coast to coast go out on October 26 they will have a real sense of what they are voting for. That is the challenge for me and other members here.
It is refreshing to see we are going to do this on a non-partisan basis. In those constitutional meetings I had late last fall and early last winter I invited our provincial members of the legislature to join me in those discussions. They did for the most part, as did mayors and councillors from the municipalities and ordinary folk. They did that. They responded well.
September 10, 1992

We are going to carry that process forward in the rural riding of Carleton-Charlotte. Many have already accepted the invitation to join me in explaining the package to the people of Carleton-Charlotte and indeed, the people of Canada. It is important that we understand this package when we go out to vote on it.
I want to quote from an article by Peter Newman in the September 14, 1992 issue of Maclean's magazine. I think he sums it up best when he says: "The real issue of the October 26 referendum is deciding whether we have a future, not the shape of what the future will be". It goes on and concludes by saying: "Maybe the 20th century never really did belong to us. But if we do not as a country vote yes on October 26, we will not belong to the 21st century".
I do not think any of us could put it any better. It is incumbent upon us to get out there, work through this process, bring it to its logical conclusion. The logical conclusion of this very consultative process is to support a united "and strong Canada that will lead us into the 21st century. If we can do that, maybe we will preserve this nation for at least another 125 years.

Mr. Speaker, let me begin by thanking the hon. member for Nanaimo-Cowichan for sharing his time with me. It was very gracious of him and I will try to use the time wisely.
October 26 is a very important day for Canada. We have gone through endless discussions on the Constitution over the last number of years. At one point during the infamous Meech Lake talks it looked as if Canada was going to have a resolution of this, at least for the time being. However, for various reasons that did not come about. Over the last couple of years a number of lessons were learned from the failure of Meech Lake. As a result, Canada is now looking at substantial improvements on that agreement.
Government Orders
unprecedented public process which has brought us to where we are today.
We had the Spicer commission and the citizens' forums across Canada. Despite the cynicism, thousands of Canadians participated in those sessions. That produced a beginning of a change in the atmosphere which had been so poisoned by the failure of Meech Lake. This was followed by parliamentary committees which heard over 3,000 presentations and then decisions in this House as to the position we would take to the legislatures and across the country.
This summer first ministers spent hours working to come up with a package, an agreement which can be put to the people of Canada. Now, for the first time in our history, Canadians as individuals will vote on constitutional amendments that will eventually come back before this Parliament and the legislatures.
The final stage will come after the referendum takes place on October 26. That is the ratification of the decision of the voters on this constitutional measure. When that happens we can then turn our full attention to the other critical issues that face this country, jobs, the environment, the free trade agreement with Mexico, and so on. This is a very important process we are undertaking and it is a very important date for Canadians.
My experience in Victoria has been that most of the people I talked with until now have left the detailed discussions to those who have been involved. Therefore, there is yet to be detailed understanding and knowledge about what is in this agreement. There is an initial scepticism born from long experience that the system can produce anything of value. In that atmosphere there are voices already passing out myths about what is in this agreement.
It is said, for example, that Quebec has too much. It is said in British Columbia that British Columbia has too little. As well, it is said that this agreement seriously weakens the capacity of the federal government to provide the necessary leadership on national programs.
One of the lessons we learned goes to the heart of the I have had a chance to review the agreement and I referendum before the House today in which the people look forward to assisting my constituents in reviewing it will be participating on October 26. That is it is critically carefully. Let me say the highlights in this agreement important that the public of Canada be allowed into the offer a real opportunity for Canadians to come together process of Constitution making. It was simply unsatisfac- in a common understanding of our purpose as a country tory for constitutions to be dealt with exclusively by first and to reform substantially the systems by which we ministers behind closed doors. We have now had an govern ourselves.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
This agreement provides for a renewed Canada clause, a new clause in the Constitution which sets out the fundamental characteristics of Canada. Not only does it include as it did at the time of Meech Lake a clear statement, an entirely justifiable statement that Quebec constitutes a distinct society within Canada which includes a French speaking majority, a unique culture and a civil law tradition it also acknowledges the commitment of this country to parliamentary and federal democracy, to the aboriginal people and the critical role they have played and the need to recognize their institutions and the integrity of their societies. It acknowledges the multicultural communities and goes on to acknowledge as well the individual and collective rights of Canadians.
The agreement provides for a social and economic union. It spells out the commitments of government not only to such things as the health care system, but also to free collective bargaining and to the rights of workers in this country.
The agreement deals with major reforms of our parliamentary institutions and these are very important gains. Above all, the agreement finally offers to our aboriginal people the fundamental rights to which they have been entitled within our Confederation and which so far have been denied them.
This is a very important agreement. I look forward to sharing the details with my constituents over the next few weeks and to working with those of whatever persuasion to see if this cannot be an important, clear and rational debate within our community.
Let me close by referring to a speech made in 1874 by the hon. Edward Blake. I am grateful to Hilda Judd of Calgary for providing this to me. My friends indicate he was a Liberal then and I knew that. But since then the New Democratic Party has come on the stage and I am sure he would have been particularly interested in what we have to offer. But all of us share the sentiment that he then offered when he said:
The future of Canada, I believe, depends very largely upon the
cultivation of a national spirit. We are engaged in a very difficult
task-the task of welding together seven provinces-
That was said in Aurora in 1874. Since then we have gained three provinces and we have the territories and our aboriginal peoples. The issue remains today. We are building a nation and we are building a federal nation. It is an important task we set on today. I commend this
agreement to the people of Victoria and to the people of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, recently a letter to the editor in The Nanaimo Daily Free Press quoted someone making the observation that there are people in Quebec who think they can get along very well without the rest of Canada and there are people in the rest of Canada who think that they can get along very well without the people of Quebec. The people would survive. I believe we would all be worse off but, whatever, we would not be Canadians. It would not be the Canada into which I was bom and not the Canada into which you were born, Mr. Speaker, and not the Canada in which I have lived all of my life and expect to live the rest of my life.
I am very proud to live in Canada. I am very proud to be a Canadian. I am very proud that people know I am a Canadian when I travel. That is the kind of Canada I want to remember. That is the kind of Canada I want to continue. For that reason I am supporting this referendum. I will be voting in favour of it.
I am sorry there are people who feel otherwise. They have the right to their opinion. In my opinion, they have the right to be wrong. I could not help but agree totally with my hon. colleague, the hon. member for Esquimau-Juan de Fuca, when he took issue with those who, for political advantage, are attacking the government leadership in the province of British Columbia.
The premier of British Columbia was one of the 16 at the table bargaining, giving and taking, on behalf of Canada as a whole. To try to destroy that person is to try to destroy the referendum result in British Columbia. What would be the result? How would we interpret it if, when the referendum ballots are cast and counted, we find that British Columbia has voted against accepting that referendum? I think that would be a very bad situation for Canada and very bad for British Columbia. Trying to destroy that premier for partisan political advantage, as important as that may be to some of us, is doing a disservice to British Columbia and a disservice to Canada as a whole.
I must separate from the group of government backbenchers, the hon. member for Surrey-White Rock-South Langley, because of the way he spoke in the House today. He blasted critics of Premier Harcourt. He
September 10, 1992

knows that in blasting Premier Harcourt what they are trying to do, without saying so, without admitting it, without having the intestinal fortitude to come here and say it, is saying they really do not like it and they want the referendum to be defeated although they do not have the nerve to stand up in the House and vote against it.
I intend to do what I can to see that a Canada Yes Committee is established in my riding. I intend to do as much as I can to see that it will be widely representative of the people of that constituency. I intend to make myself available to that committee, to speak anywhere and everywhere in the riding where I am invited so that I can tell people how I feel about Canada, about how I feel about the referendum.
I was never so proud of a cabinet minister as I was when the minister of labour, the Hon. Moe Sihota, spoke at a public meeting in my riding a couple of months ago. In speaking about the Constitution he said that "there is no single issue which of itself is important enough that we should risk destroying Canada because we can't achieve our ultima". That is what the leader of the Liberal Party is saying in British Columbia. He has an ultima, a single issue. Because he cannot have that, he thinks that the government of British Columbia should have walked away from the deal and destroyed Canada.
It is not worth the price. We have to do what we can to preserve this nation. I do not think when this is all resolved, and I am hoping it will be resolved soon, that the people of Canada are going to notice very much difference the morning after, the week after, the month after or the year after. The economic problems besetting this nation are the ones that will make them feel differently now and into the future, until we do something about them.
Let us get this behind us. Let us vote in favour of the referendum so that we do have a country that can hold up its head among the nations of the world, setting the kinds of standards that Canada has become famous for: in social services, in peacekeeping. There are important jobs that we as a nation can do that we could not do if we were to fall apart or separate deliberately. We would be weakened tremendously, and the world would lose as well as Canadians. That must not happen.
Government Orders
I believe the way to save it for the present is to vote in favour of this referendum. That will give us time. We can always sort this out in the future. We might even decide to send the Constitution back to Westminster and let them look after it. It was not nearly as much trouble when it was there.
In the meantime we have to start talking about economic problems, dealing with economic issues, dealing with unemployment. Once we get this behind us, surely then the government will have no reason, no excuse, for not dealing with the real problems facing Canadians today.
I will be doing what I can to support this referendum in my riding and I will do everything I can to make sure that
it passes.

Mr. Speaker, while Canada ranks first world-wide among 167 UN nations for quality of life, this government put the future of our country in the hands of the people.
It is normally the job of the elected representatives to administer and manage the business of the country in the interest of its people. Now, for some exceptional reason, we the elected representatives are asking the people of Canada to decide what they want from this country. What kind of constitution do they want? Would they agree that the Constitution of Canada be renewed on the basis of the agreement the premiers has reached in Charlottetown on August 28?
The proposal before us today is not a haphazard one. Let us be reminded of how hard is has been for many Quebecers to find the will to go on following the failure of Meech.
I come from a fiercely nationalist region, the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean, the riding of Jonquiere to be more precise, where being nationalistic has come to take two meanings over the years. For some, to be a nationalist means to advocate a sovereign Quebec. For others like me, it does not necessarily mean that. It means defending the interests of your province and trying to the best of your abilities and talents to guarantee that your province can develop and progress within Canadian federalism.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
Many wanted to give up after the failure of Meech Lake. The Prime Minister asked several members of his caucus, including myself, to try again to renew our Constitution and to find solutions to our problems. We had two options: to try again or to give up and throw in the towel.
For my part, I took up the challenge to defend the interests of my province as a member of the Beaudoin-Edwards committee and then of the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee.
It took a lot of courage on the part of the Prime Minister to make such a decision, but he wanted Canadian unity and he had the courage to want to try. Because of this several of my colleagues from the opposition parties and from the government met a large number of individual Canadians and representatives of various organizations. We listened to what they wanted for their country and to their suggestions on how to amend the Constitution.
It is only human for a member or a chairman of a committee to hope that the decisions of the government will reflect exactly what was recommended in the committee report. It is only human and quite natural. However, should we say no simply because the contents of the constitutional proposal does not reflect exactly our own recommendations? What we must do is evaluate the agreement. This is our responsibility. We must evaluate it.
Let me give an example. The chairman of the Allaire Committee simply gave up because the agreement does not contain all of his own recommendations. He simply gave up and said: I cannot agree to that. There is the matter of the environment, for instance. Mr. Allaire wanted the environment to come under provincial jurisdiction. The people of Jonquiere are well aware of the fact that the environment and pollution know no boundaries. It cannot come under exclusive provincial jurisdiction. It is impossible.
In negotiations we have to ask for a number of things and afterwards see if the contents of the agreement as a whole give us enough of what we wanted.
I am a Quebecer. Let us look at the proposal. What does it contain for Quebecers? What are we being offered? We are offered a veto on Senate reform. Quebec has wanted for years to make it impossible for
the other provinces to change the Senate without our agreement because we are one of the co-founding peoples of this nation. Today this is what we are being offered. We are being offered a veto on any change to the House of Commons. Under the present Constitution seven provinces could decide, for instance, that there will no longer be proprotional representation in the House of Commons. They could decide on equal representation for each province. Such a decision could be made by seven provinces and without our agreement. This proposal offers us a veto on any future change to the House of Commons.
Third, Quebec is being offered 25 per cent of all seats in the House of Commons from now on. Why is that important? Each year, a large number of immigrants are admitted to Canada. They can go to any province. Under an agreement on immigration which will now be entrenched in the Constitution Quebec can accept between 25 and 30 per cent of the total number of immigrants admitted to Canada each year. However, these immigrants do not have to remain in Quebec once they are there. They can go elsewhere, to any other province, and vice versa.
There is no guarantee that Quebec will always represent a quarter of the population of Canada. In spite of that the other provinces and premiers agree that Quebecers will always hold one-quarter of the seats in the House of Commons. This is very important. We would have a quarter of the seats in the House. A majority of 50 percent plus one is needed to pass an act in the House of Commons. Since we are assigned 25 percent of the seats, we represent half of the votes required to pass or reject any bill in the House of Commons. In the future Quebec members would be, for all practical purposes, protected against any form of abuse from future governments. We only have to consult with each other. We have the tool we need in our hands. How will we use it? It is up to us to use it to shape our future.
I have another point. We are being offered a veto over any change to the Supreme Court to be composed of nine members, of whom three must be from Quebec. This is another permanent form of protection. It is important because this country was founded in 1867 by two peoples: francophones from Quebec and anglophones from other provinces. Over the years, since there
September 10,1992

are now 20 million English Canadians and 6 million of us, Quebecers have asked for such a protection.
The constitutional offer that will be put to a vote on October 26 finally recognizes Quebec as a distinct society. Section 2 of the Constitution would be amended to read "Quebec constitutes within Canada a distinct society, which includes a French speaking majority, a unique culture and a civil law tradition". Another important clause has been added: "The role of the legislature and Government of Quebec to preserve and promote the distinct society of Quebec is affirmed". To those who claim the term distinct is not good or strong enough, I say this: should a Quebec law concerning our language ever be challenged before the Supreme Court of Canada? We could as Quebecers use the distinct society clause to justify such a law. If the Supreme Court rejected our arguments we could still invoke the notwithstanding clause to tell the judges: Notwithstanding your decision to declare our law unconstitutional we will keep it. We enjoy a double protection.
Furthermore-and Quebecers and Canadians alike must realize this-when we were sitting on the Beau-doin-Dobbie committee, the first ministers and lobby groups were telling us not to impose something against their will while insisting they wanted the same as Quebec. It was pretty difficult to deal with.
The distribution of powers as provided for in the constitutional offer meets this demand. How? Any province can ask the federal government to withdraw from areas of exclusive provincial jurisdiction such as mining, tourism, forestry, recreation, housing and urban affairs. At the request of a province, the federal government would be obligated to withdraw. It would then be required to negotiate how to provide reasonable compensation. All this would be entrenched in the Constitution for five years.
Any other province preferring the federal government to remain involved can stay that way. This is what I call flexibility. To those who say that it is not good enough because it is only for five years, I say think again. The Constitution will be around for a long time. The 1867 Constitution lasted until 1982 before getting a facelift and even today we see how difficult it is.
Government Orders
If we had an intergovernmental agreement giving us back a certain power with all the related responsibilities, we would be stuck with it forever. We could even have done ourselves a disservice. The proposed formula gives us more flexibility. It would allow a province to make corrections as the need arises. It meets Quebecers' expectations. We want more powers. Others may want less than we do. It is their choice. But let us look at the offer on the table.
Let us now talk about the aboriginal issue. In 1867 those who preceded us drafted a constitution that did not include the aboriginal peoples. Today we want to correct that mistake. We recognize that the aboriginal peoples have the inherent right to self-government with basic forms of protection. Just what is important? It is always to try to correct or avoid, as much as possible, any abuse of power by anybody. We have benchmarks regarding what is looming on the horizon for aboriginal peoples, namely that the legislation will always have to conform with the notion of order and good government. It is even provided that, as the aboriginal peoples gradually take control of their destiny, they will be able to contribute financially, in proportion with the resources that they have.
The fact that the aboriginal peoples blossom within our society does not take anything away from me as a Canadian; on the contrary, it makes me grow. I grow when people next to me improve their lot. To recognize that the most beautiful country in the world can continue to move forward while respecting the needs of everyone as well as the characteristics of its different provinces.
I notice that I only have a few minutes left. I want Quebecers to think seriously before saying no. If we say no to this offer it means that we say no to something that I have been trying to get for a very long time: a veto on the reform of institutions, a guarantee providing for 25 per cent of the seats in the House of Commons, the enshrinement of our agreement on immigration, as well as other powers.
I took a close look at the accord. I did not read it only once. Of course there are times when we would like to get more in life, but there also comes a time when you have to look at what is offered. For Quebecers, this is a good offer. It is interesting. We have guarantees concerning our language, our development as well as the

September 10, 1992

characteristics of the country and our own as francophones from Quebec.

Mr. Speaker, the question that the government tabled yesterday reflects the true nature of behind the scenes dealings in Charlottetown. Whatever my former colleagues from the Conservative Party are saying we are very far from the Meech Lake accord substance. The Meech Lake accord was subjected to a real constitutional diet. The Meech baby was not very fat in the first place. We can imagine how he looked after the drastic diet and deprivation of a few days imposed on it in Charlottetown. The five minimal conditions became trifle. Indeed, eight distinguished constitutional specialists from Quebec examined the distinct society clause and concluded it was a setback for Quebec. Surely they cannot all be wrong, and I say this for the benefit of the member for Jonquiere. The distinct society concept has been completely diminished. The only distinctness remaining is culture, language and civil law. Quebec's distinctness is far more than that. Quebec is also a distinct society in the social and economic sense. Consider its social measures, including health insurance; measures affecting labour relations, such as anti-scab legislation, legislation to regulate real estate transactions, credit unions and so forth.
At the time of the beau risque which the Prime Minister of Canada likes to recall, Rene Levesque stressed the importance of recognizing the existence of Quebec as a people in the Constitution. The concept of two founding peoples has now been swept aside in favour of provincial equality. Genuine special status has been obtained only by small provinces like Newfoundland and Prince Edward Island.
The distinct society, which was to be the subject of an interpretive clause, is lost in the Canada clause which says that governments are committed to the vitality and development of official language communities.
Political scientist Leon Dion, who has been advising Premier Bourassa and Minister Gil Remillard during the constitutional talks, expressed his apprehension with respect to Bill 101, especially concerning the language on signs and the language of work. If the agreement is ratified, Bill 101 might become a target for people who feel frustrated. Quebec wanted veto rights over any changes that might affect Quebec's role within federal institutions, the structure of those institutions and their jurisdiction, the appointment of members of these institutions and the creation of new provinces. Instead, we now have only bits and pieces of a veto that is no longer significant and, more important, no veto over the creation of new provinces.
As for the division of powers, Quebec now has fewer powers than it had at the beginning of Confederation in 1867. What was supposed to bring Quebec back into the constitutional fold with honour and enthusiasm has now become a millstone around its neck. What the draft agreement gives Quebec with one hand, it takes away with the other. All this for a few more seats in the House of Commons which is no guarantee that Quebec's superior interests will be defended. Remember the patriation of the Constitution in 1982. Our world is undergoing as dramatic a change as any since the birth of the nation-state. All over the planet people are demanding independence. Too many are dying for their dream of statehood and at least here in Canada we can still debate our differences.
The evolving world political order demands of us that we be a model of how diversity can be welded together to create a strong and prosperous nation.
We had best take a close look at what is happening here at home, analyse the problems and consider what kind of future we face in this country. Listen to the despair of the Atlantic fishermen and plant workers. Hear the resignation in the voices of the unemployed from coast to coast. Feel the frustration of the young men and women from Quebec who cannot understand why their identity is being questioned and bargained over like so many poker chips. Listen to the men and women from the prairies who had their hopes of being equal partners in Confederation dashed over and over again. Recognize the anger of thousands who have lost their jobs in manufacturing in Ontario who are told "it is all right, Jack".
Most of all, beware of the undisguised contempt for the political process held by Canadians from St. John's to Victoria.
If we listened to the people, we would hear a simple message. They are angiy. They are profoundly alienated but thankfully they still believe in the country though not necessarily in its politicians or the system.
Canadians despair because their political institutions are not working. They are disillusioned because the ad hoc process of constitutional reform over the past 15 years has failed to adequately address their concerns and their needs. Those involved in fine tuning the Constitution, which should lead Canada confidently into the next century, have spent much of their time and their energies not on improving Canadian national institutions and our political structures in the best interest of Canadians but on shuffling the deck, on redefining federal-provincial relations, never really addressing the underlying fundamental reason for the crisis in confidence that is eroding the fabric of Canada.
The political pendulum continues to swing between federal and provincial interests. The price has been the alienation of the people of Canada from their governments and their politicians. That is the source of the deep malaise in Canada.
Economic, social and political problems are traumatic and painful but more dangerous still is the lack of hope, the absence of trust and the discouragement of Canadians upon realizing our political system seemingly is incapable of dealing resolutely with deeply felt concerns.
Our protracted constitutional debate has demonstrated just how out of touch we are with what Canadians are really troubled about. Years have been spent trying to codify what nearly all of us already know and accept, namely that Quebec constitutes within Canada a distinct society, that aboriginal people have a right to self-government, that an elected Senate should have real power and that Canada should be an open and free economy from sea to sea to sea.
Everyone wants reform but reform of what? I believe reform must begin at the heart of the political system in Parliament itself. We must reform the Senate and also the House of Commons. To do this we must be prepared to reveal the failings of our system.
We must explain why elected members of Parliament
do not play a meaningful role in the governing process,
why the House of Commons is a rubber stamp and why

we have allowed the executive to usurp the legislative functions of government.
When there was agreement to reduce the number of Senators, the size of the House of Commons should have been decreased, not increased. The charade must end that ordinary MPs on all sides of this House exercise any real power of any kind.
Canadians want a democratic Parliament. We need a responsible government and accountable politicians. Surely Canadians are creative enough to devise a system of government that will combine the best elements of the various models we are very familiar with.
Until this happens we will not be able to encourage more capable and competent men and women to participate in the political process and confidence will not be restored in our institutions.
Future generations will judge us harshly if we fail and we will have much to answer for because we have had every opportunity to get it right.
Canadians want to continue to survive as a nation where people have overcome diversity of language, culture, ethnic origin and religion and lived together in relative harmony.
There is no doubt in my mind that we must agree to answer the referendum question that is before us in the affirmative, but we had better begin the process of restoring integrity and credibility to our political institutions. Any student of history will tell you that great nations are not the result of constitutional, legalistic arrangements, but rather are the achievements of men and women committed toward working together to create a system of government truly responsive to the needs and aspirations of its people and to the building of a society that strives to achieve the ultimate goal of providing everyone of its citizens with an equal opportunity to live in peace, prosperity and dignity

It has been a long and arduous process. We are all a bit fatigued but perhaps not more so than the Canadian general public itself.
At the same time I am sure we have all had the experience I have had that every time we talked about the Constitution to one of our constituents we would have a response of frustration with the ongoing interminable process. Yet, as soon as those frustrations were expressed, people would give their own version of what their perfect model of a Canadian Constitution should be.
We have all learned over these many months and years that there is no perfect model that would satisfy all the legitimate needs and all the aspirations of all of us, no matter where we live in this great country or the different interest or ethnic groups to which we might belong.
We live in the largest country in the world, which is also by all objective criteria the most prosperous country in the world. I ask whether it does not stand to reason that our predecessors and perhaps we ourselves in our modest way have not done a few things right to bring us to this enviable position.
We are a very young country relative to the other democracies after which we have fashioned our public institutions. When you think about it in terms of our Constitution we are also among the older countries of the world in the sense that we have not changed our Constitution veiy much over the last 125 years.
As an example, let us look at Germany. It is an interesting comparison in the sense that it was precisely at the same time in 1867 that the northern German states first organized themselves into some kind of loose federation. Shortly thereafter, in 1871, the first German Reich was founded which in turn led to the so-called Weimar Republic. It in turn was followed by the Third Reich and after the war it turned into the two Germa-nies. Of course we all remember the dramatic events which in 1990 led to the reunification of Germany which gave form to the present federation.
One would hardly be inclined to envy the Germans for their eventful and colourful 125 year history. They did manage to relieve themselves of the kind of rigidity through these various reforms which we find necessary now to change in our own Constitution.

The historic facts which led us to where we are today date back much further than 125 years. They go back to 1763, the royal proclamation, which established a relationship between the settlers in the new world and the aboriginal people they would encounter. In 1774 the royal proclamation established certain rights the French would enjoy in the new world. The Quebec Act, 1791, dealt with language rights, the Napoleonic civil code and certain religious rights that would have to be granted to the French population in the new world.
To ignore or to attempt to wipe out these rigid historic facts would require nothing less than the kind of convulsive and revolutionary change that shaped the history of countries such as the one I mentioned earlier.
Canadians never had a taste for that kind of change. We are more inclined to agree to changes through consensus and through honourable compromise which requires tolerance and understanding and good will toward others. In fact, as some of our colleagues have mentioned, this is what we are known for throughout the world. This is what is distinctively Canadian. It is also what led to the accord which is now before us and which we are asking the consent of the House of Commons and the people of Canada to support on October 26.
Cartier said in 1867, and I quote him as did the Prime Minister yesterday:
We sealed our pact without bloodshed and without exploitation of the weak by the strong. All it took was fairness, justice and some compromise on both sides.

If we had not met in a spirit of conciliation and with an anxious overriding desire to form one country under one government we would never have succeeded.

Mr. Speaker, the question we are debating today is the following one:
Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be renewed on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28, 1992?
In the minute amount of time that I have been allotted to speak on this question and on the broader question of the accord, I do not intend to get into lofty constitutional discussions but I do want to make a few comments from my perspective first as a lawyer and second as a representative of the people who live in the riding of Scarborough West.
As a lawyer I have come to respect the value of words, what they mean and how they are used. I look at this question and I see a word which offends me. The methodology of the use of the word and the attempt to manipulate which offends me. The word is renewed.
One might ask: Why quibble with words? My answer to that is that the way we communicate, the way we convince ourselves, is through the use of the word, spoken or written. We have seen in the very recent past how the courts have interpreted words, how they have written meanings in where there were no such meanings, and how they have taken words out that were written in. Therefore it is very important to be as precise as possible when using words.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
There was no need to use the word renewed in this question. A simple word which would have made the question completely neutral would have been: Do you agree that the Constitution of Canada should be amended on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28, 1992? It should have been amended instead of renewed. Renewed puts this sort of who would be against renewal spin on it. That to me is an attempt to manipulate, that is to play us, myself, my constituents and the people of Canada, for fools. I personally resent it.
Is that going to be enough for me to vote against this question? Of course not, because I believe that this question should go to the people of Canada and should be considered by them.
However, I want to put on record that it is unnecessary for the Prime Minister of this country to fool with words when a simple neutral question could have attained the same results.

going to say that we will understand it immediately, but do we care enough to investigate is?

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure and a privilege to rise today to speak on this topic of the upcoming referendum on the renewal of the Constitution of Canada.
First I would want to thank all those in the House, in the Senate and in the Public Service for the extra time and effort they have taken to work on this proposal over many months. I also want to thank those in my riding of Prince Edward-Hastings for their participation, whether that was through letters or phone calls to the Spicer commission, the Beaudoin-Dobbie commission, the Charest committee or whatever it might be, and the hundreds of people who either phoned me, wrote to me, met me on the street or came out to town hall and public meetings I have held in the riding on this issue over the last number of months.
I can assure them their views were heard and they were passed on by myself to people who were more closely involved in this issue. I also remind Canadians, not only those in Prince Edward-Hastings riding, that we have the privilege in Canada to do that. Many countries in the world today do not have that privilege, that freedom of speech, that freedom of association, and we should all remind ourselves how fortunate we are.
Where are we now? We have a proposal, if it is passed on October 26, that I feel will certainly keep Canada together. If it does not pass, I do not even want to talk about it because I shudder at the fallout that will likely come from that. The important thing is that all of us as Canadians have that choice to make now. We have that opportunity. It is not a perfect proposal as so many of my colleagues here in the House have said. We know that. However, all of us have been involved in enough
By passing this we can tell the rest of the world and we can tell Canadians that for now at least we have made up our mind on the future direction of our country. We can get on with doing what we need to do as a country, that is get our economy going again and get people back to work and people earning money. That is important.
As I say, it is not a perfect proposal. If I had written it I would have made the Senate more effective, but it is the best we could get right now. The economic union is not as strong as it could be, but I think we can work on that. The recognition is there that it needs to be improved, and that is a step forward.
Let us look at the positive aspects of it. Of concern to many people in my riding are the words distinct society. I want to remind them that in the Canada clause distinct society is defined to refer only to language, civil law and culture. It is important that definition is there. Francophones are protected with this agreement outside Quebec and anglophones are protected within Quebec. The Senate is elected and equal and it can be made more effective by changes in the rules of the House. The aboriginal people will be given self-government as they should have. Changes to national institutions such as the House, the Senate and the Supreme Court can only be made with the full agreement of all provinces and the Parliament of Canada.
Yes, Mr. Bourassa can say that Quebec has a veto on this type of action, but I remind people that every province has a veto and that is not a special veto given to the province of Quebec.
New provinces can be created by the Parliament of Canada. I have always said that if we are going to redistribute the jurisdiction of forestry, tourism and mining to the provinces nothing special should be done for any particular province. Nothing is done special for any particular province. The opportunities in this propos-

September 10,1992
Government Orders
al for one province are there for all provinces, and that is important.
The Canada clause protects the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and it keeps it foremost and strong. There is a commitment and it is a very strong one. Canadians are committed to social and ethnic equality. There is a commitment to the equality of female and male persons.
Yes, we could pick holes in this agreement. Let us not get caught up in partisanship, narrow minded bigotry or narrow personal thoughts. We are talking about the future of a country, one that has withstood a lot, one that has been formed from people coming together from all parts of the world, and one that offers so much to so many.
We have in our country of Canada a very precious country and to me it is far too precious to lose. My Canada is the whole of Canada. I urge Canadians to support the Charlottetown proposal for a renewed Canadian Constitution.

Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to have this opportunity however brief to address the historic question before us about the future of our entire country.
The real question before us is whether we are to say yes to a new and stimulating move forward in Canada's journey as a unified nation or whether we are to say no and continue to drift in the agonizing impasse of constitutional conflict and threatened separation.
While it is tempting to many to forestall the heavy burden of facing that question directly and perhaps to seek refuge through preoccupation with the broad range of significant individual factors for which the referendum question will be a single proxy, it remains essential for every Canadian to address the only question that really counts squarely: Do we say yes to the unity of Canada at this time or do we say no?
Therein lies the challenge for every member of Parliament, indeed for every elected representative at every level of government and for every citizen who can be encouraged to join the referendum campaign, to ensure that Canadians are truly inspired with the magnitude of the responsibility and the opportunity now being presented to each one of us. It is a rare chance for every individual of voting age to make a direct and measurable contribution to the future directions of our country.
Over the next several weeks leading up to October 26, every citizen will be able to experience the essence of the political process in a direct and dramatic way, to recognize, to consider and to evaluate all the complex issues involved in Canada's future, and then to exercise all that collective personal knowledge and wisdom in the form of a single judgment and decision to move Canada forward in unity and inspiration or to keep Canada mired in division and discord.
