To be sure our first job is to inform and educate ourselves and our fellow citizens about all of the issues involved to the greatest extent possible in the time available. That in itself will be no easy task. Even at best, we must accept the reality that very few of us will really be knowledgeable about Canada's constitutional complexities before it is time to make our decision.
However, that should not be cause for frustration or undue concern because the average citizen cannot be expected to gain instant expertise in such affairs. That is why Canadians have yearned for the kind of leadership in this issue in which they can place their trust. Fortunately, and to an extent perhaps never before displayed in Canadian history, we have seen such leadership in this constitutional mission. It has come from every major jurisdiction in every comer of the country and its recommendations are unanimous about the direction in which it points us. That is not to say that Canadians should blindly follow any leadership without due caution, care and consideration, particularly in such a critical direction as we are now heading.
However, it does mean that in the absence of perfect understanding or ultimate knowledge or divine wisdom, which obviously none of us will ever have, there is a compelling basis for trust and and confidence in following the leadership which the first ministers of Canada have demonstrated along with their territorial and aboriginal colleagues in reaching the constitutional consensus that was signed at Charlottetown on August 28.
In the absence of better information or higher knowledge or wiser choice, I believe that the Charlottetown agreement is a foundation for judgment on which any Canadian can rely in making an affirmative referendum
September 10, 1992

decision. Certainly it is on that basis that I will cast my own vote.
It is especially imperative that we encourage Canadians to come to grips with the very nature of our confederation and with the realization that we continue to build Canada today in the same spirit of collaboration, concession, compromise and consensus as it was founded 125 years ago.
As the Prime Minister said in opening this debate two days ago, Confederation itself was a creative innovation to cope with the major constitutional and economic problems of the day. He went on to quote Sir John A. Macdonald who said at the beginning: "The whole scheme bears upon its face the marks of compromise. Of necessity there was a great deal of mutual concession". Obviously we now see clear evidence of a similar approach which our present leaders have used in reaching a constitutional accord.
Frankly, I would like it even better if the Charlottetown agreement was called just that, the Canada accord. For me, at least, those words more aptly describe the essence of Canadian federalism in the modem day. The concept of accord seems a stronger and more rational expression of the inter-relationship and interdependence which must exist among all participants in a federation such as ours. In truth, that is effectively what has been achieved, a Canada accord which reflects a reasoned and fair reconciliation of all the diverse interests which exist throughout this vast country.
This Canada accord is not a menu of half measures to merely provide each participant with a little bit of something and not much of anything as some critics have claimed, but rather it is an innovative and effective working plan for the continued development of Canada as a unified nation. It has been achieved through long and intensive consultation with Canadians from every walk of life, in every part of our vast land. It expresses the diversity of their hopes and aspirations in a balanced approach that offers the best prospects yet defined of making those hopes and aspirations attainable.
The Canada accord is a statement of vision for our country, a vision that is based on unity and a vision to which we must each address ourselves. It is simply not possible to side-step this ultimate question of vision.
Government Orders
That is what the referendum will be all about. Is our vision of Canada based on unity or is it based on division?
In the most simple of all terms that is what we shall each be expressing in the voters booths on referendum day: our own vision of Canada, securely unified or dangerously divided. We simply must not deceive ourselves about that question and the responsibility for each one of us to vote yes for the Canada accord and support a solution that will keep our country whole or to realize that in voting no we are accepting the prospects of continued deep division and probably even disintegration within Canada as we know it.
The day of judgment and decision for Canada will come quickly upon us.
The entire thrust and spirit of the referendum campaign will be to ask Canadians if they are prepared to place a priority on the context of the country as a whole and to accept the principles of the Canada accord which have been reached to make unity possible.
As I have said, the challenge before us is not simply to make some selective choice among individual elements of the accord, but rather to lift our sights and our judgments to the future of Canada in its entirety. Those alternatives, yes or no, are competing visions. For the destiny of Canada we must each accept the solemn responsibility to make our choice between them.
For me and my house, and I believe for most citizens in my constituency, we shall choose to stand proudly for a united Canada.

Mr. Speaker, after two years of the widest possible consultation in the history of Canada, through the Spicer commission, the Charest committee, the Beaudoin-Edwards committee, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee of which I was a member, we now have a unanimous agreement by 17 people consisting of the Prime Minister, the 10 premiers, two territorial and four aboriginal leaders.
The Charlottetown agreement goes far beyond the Meech Lake accord which for a time also had unanimous agreement. It goes beyond Meech Lake in its extensive consultation process, through its involvement with literally hundreds of thousands of Canadians and through the participation of our aboriginal peoples.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
Further, the Charlottetown agreement goes beyond Meech Lake in that it provides a clear definition of the distinct society clause and its guarantee of protection for our two official language communities both in Quebec and across Canada.
There are billboards across Canada that carry the words "My Canada includes Quebec". I would go further and agree with the right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra who earlier in this debate said: "It is not just that my Canada includes Quebec, but for me there is no Canada without Quebec".
I would also add that this agreement with its distinct society clause, its protection of our two linguistic communities, the new division of powers, as well as the limitation of the unilateral use of the federal spending powers, is consistent with the vision for Canada of Macdonald and Cartier.
Both Macdonald and Cartier grasped the fundamental reality and secret of Canada, that of two founding peoples, English and French speaking, working harmoniously together while respecting each other's language, culture, religion, and civil codes.
Not only is this agreement consistent with the 1867 British North America Act, but it is also in harmony with our history and with other acts such as the Quebec Act, 1774, and the Canada Act, 1791.
The agreement goes far beyond Meech Lake in that all 10 provinces and the federal government are now correcting a long-standing historical problem through the recognition of the inherent right to self-government of our aboriginal people.
Additionally the agreement's process and focus is different. Meech Lake attempted to correct a past omission for a province. The Charlottetown agreement corrects that omission and focuses on the Canada of the future.
The details of the agreement are very important. I hope every Canadian will read them, but when they are read I hope every Canadian will seriously consider the months and months of deliberation and discussion, of debate and compromise, and do what the 17 individuals did in Charlottetown on August 28, 1992, and what the Fathers of Confederation did beginning at Charlottetown in 1864 through to 1867. That is to put their own agendas and preferences aside and make them secondary
to the national interest and to the needs of a strong united Canada.
I am disappointed that the preamble that was unanimously recommended by all 30 members of the House and Senate on the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee was not accepted by the required seven out of 10 premiers. Nevertheless I want to publicly thank the Prime Minister who tried both in late July and again in Charlottetown to gain acceptance of that preamble. I am also disappointed that property rights were not added to the agreement for inclusion in the charter of rights. Who in this House can forget Boris Yeltsin's words to us on June 19 of this year when he said that one of the key reforms to rebuilding Russia and the democratic rights of its people would be to add the right to private property to their new constitution.
I am also disappointed that section 121, the economic union clause, was not significantly modernized and strengthened. I am however pleased that the Prime Minister and the premiers have agreed to revisit that weakness as a top priority item once the agreement has been ratified.
I am sure that all 295 members of this House and all 26 million Canadians would each have written a slightly different version of the agreement and that none would be totally alike, but I whole-heartedly endorse this agreement. It is a result of hard work and of compromise in the best sense of that word, of democratically elected representatives from all levels of government, from all regions and territories, from all political parties and involving our aboriginal people. That is why I will support the agreement.
However, the details of the agreement alone are not what this vote is all about. This vote on October 26 is about Canadians participating in a process to get Canada working again. The question is very sharp and unequivocal, requiring a simple yes or no. The issue is clear: continue or terminate.
I also believe it is not fear-mongering to simply put the stark reality of what a no vote could mean. A no answer could set in motion an irreversible unravelling of our national fabric of health care, education, transportation, social services, justice system, business cohesion, fiscal integrity and national defence. All the essential ingredients of our country would be at risk and could ultimately be compromised.
September 10, 1992

We owe it to ourselves and future generations to look beyond the details of this agreement and recognize the ultimate outcome of a no answer.
Let me say that I am the son of immigrants who fled the Soviet Union and came to Canada in 1923. My parents taught me to love Canada, to thank God for Canada and to work for the people of this great land, the best in the world. We know that and now the United Nations is saying that as well.
Canadians do not do much flag waving. In fact we complain far too much and we are far too cynical about ourselves and of our great nation. But October 26 gives us a chance to brag a bit, to feel good again and to purge some of the cynicism and some of the poison from our system and say yes to Canada and to say yes to our future. We owe that to ourselves and we owe that to the rest of the world that looks to Canada and to Canadians as a beacon of hope, good will, tolerance and common sense in a world that desperately needs those qualities.
To close, I would like to quote from George Brown who in 1865, during the American Civil War, said: "We are endeavouring to adjust harmoniously greater difficulties that have plunged others into all of the horrors of civil war. Have we not then cause of thankfulness that we have found a better way for the solution of our troubles?"
Canadians have found a better way. On October 26 we can vote yes and continue in that tradition of the better way in which we can build one another up as fellow Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, newspapers like La Presse in Quebec have already printed surveys which show that half the people who would have voted yes to that agreement would have done so because they were fed up with the constitutional debate. I was particularly shocked to hear, a few weeks ago, people like Bourassa, Mulroney and Clark, the ones who proposed that agreement, say that Canadians were fed up with the constitutional debate and that that could be used as an argument. That strategy has surely worked because nearly half the people who would vote yes would do so not because they believe the agreement is a good one, but rather because they are fed up with the constitutional debate. Constitutional weariness is what I want to talk about today
Government Orders
because it is a fact. It is affecting not only those who may find the agreement unsatisfactory, but also those who oppose this particular deal. Constitutional weariness is affecting everybody. One thing is sure: we are suffering from constitutional weariness. But could it have to do with the length of the debate? Could it be due to constant and persistent lying on the part of the leaders who prepared this agreement? Are we going to ask the people of Quebec to vote for this agreement because we feel they have had it up to here with unkept promised? Is that what we have in mind?
Let me tell you straight out what I think. If people are suffering from constitutional weariness-not so much the fact of being fed up with the Constitution or a particular piece of legislation but that of being tired of being taken for a ride and lied to by politicians elected to make decisions-it is because these very politicians, often for the sake of playing for time, talk absolute nonsense, loosing any credibility in the eyes of the people.
They may well end up sickening the people. Then to turn around and ask them to vote for this agreement, just because they have had enough of the lies they have been hearing for the past seven or eight years, up to thirty years in some instances, that is a bit much. I do not fall for it and, come voting day, I am convinced that the people of Quebec will not fall in that trap either.
This reminds me of an issue that has been one hot issue in Quebec for the longest time, and that is public funding. You remember, Mr. Speaker, do you not? You had even spoken in support of it at the time. You may also recall that it was one the main themes of the Mulroney government platform in the last campaign. As a matter of fact, it was used as an umbrella to prevent the scandals they were plagued with from getting out of hand during the campaign.
At the very end of the campaign, three days before polling day, the Prime Minister solemnly promised the people of Quebec, and it made the headlines in La Presse, that he would establish democratic public funding the very next day following his re-election. How did he play for time after that? He set up committees and commissions then waited a few months. When complaints about him not keeping his word started flying again, he said: "This is a somewhat complicated issue.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
We are going to strike a royal commission of inquiry." The Lortie commission went to great lengths for some three years I guess, to buiy the problem. Today the Prime Minister operates under the assumption that the people do not remember. He thinks that the people are so fed up that they will have forgotten. He thinks he can go before the people in the next election and tell them: "No, this is no longer valid". He believes that is the way of keeping his credibility intact. But that is not the way things work in the real world. Next time around the people of Quebec will pay the Prime Minister back for his constant lying. They will give him a ticket, all right, a one-way ticket. That is how you thank people who deceive you.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I am sorry to interrupt the hon, member, but I notice that he has referred to lies and lying on four occasions already. I believe it is contrary to parliamentary practice to ascribe such intentions to our colleagues. I would therefore urge him to be more careful from now on.

As I was saying, the people will remember. With regard to the constitutional agreement, this one point in particular.
Mr. Bourassa told us, I do not know how many times, from the beginning that there would never be an equal Senate where Quebec would have the same weight as Prince Edward Island, which is as big as my riding and has almost the same population, a Senate where Quebec would have as much clout as Newfoundland, for example, or any other province. Quebec will never be treated like the rest of the province. He told us that constantly, all the time. He repeated it. Today he accepts it. People are fed up, disgusted, but I do not think that is a reason to vote for the agreement. I do not think that is a reason.
Both the Prime Minister of Canada and the premier of Quebec told us that Quebec's five conditions for repairing the affront of 1982, the five minimum conditions of Meech, would be guaranteed and there would never be less than that. It was a prerequisite, a precondition.
Three years ago, the Prime Minister began the downward slide into accepting anything with the Charest commission. Mr. Bourassa signed this agreement or this offer from English Canada. They have completely broken their promises. Mr. Bourassa said that he would
never negotiate again with 10 partners. This time he did not negotiate with 10 but with 16.
Today, with a decision to make for or against the agreement, the same Mr. Bourassa and Mr. Mulroney ask Quebecers to vote for it not because it is good but because they have had enough. So much so that the Conseil du patronat du Quebec says today that we will have to vote for it but without enthusiasm. We will have to vote for it because it is the best we can hope for. That does not mean it is good. There will be nothing better. We are not worth much, are we? Then he adds: "Why couldn't we have more? Well, when you have to negotiate with 16 others, it is very hard to come up with a good agreement". It comes down to that. He says: "Well, we will support it".
We have had 30 years of debate on the Canadian Constitution. In the 1980 referendum, Quebecers were told to vote no, to vote against the question put to them and we would have a renewed federalism in which Quebec would have a place of honour. What happened? A year and a half later English Canada, in Quebec's absence, came up with a constitution that forced Quebec to take its punishment. It was an affront, a slap in the face. That was the answer.
We wanted to correct that affront with an agreement. Today we are told: "Well, you will have to take it. It will be enough. It is better than nothing. We cannot offer you more". Do you think Quebecers will accept that just because they are fed up with the constitutional debate? Personally, I think we can do better.
When we are fed up with something and have had it we must consider why. The reason we are disgusted is people have not been able to keep their promises. They say one thing one day and something else the next. They are politicians who cannot be trusted any more. All the polls show that throughout Canada, in Quebec but also across Canada, people have lost confidence in their institutions. Why? For those reasons.
I really hate that so-called agreement. It bothers me. It makes me sick, but I cannot vote for it by saying that will be the end of all that. I cannot sweep it under the rug like that. None of the problems raised by Quebec is solved by that agreement.
September 10, 1992

The agreement itself contains 79 points still to be discussed. They even wrote that. On the one hand they say: "You must vote for this agreement because you are sick of hearing about it". They say we should vote for the agreement because it is time we went on to other things, but on the other hand, they say there are still 79 items to discuss and finalize. Anyone who thinks the constitutional debate will end on October 26 when people vote in favour of the agreement is greatly mistaken. The leaders on the yes side are making a case based on arguments that are totally misleading. I am shocked and appalled.
The Bloc Quebecois, however, offers a valid alternative, to tell people the truth. Bloc leader Lucien Bouchard gave up ministerial privileges including staff, additional allowances and a limousine. Bloc members also gave up a lot of privileges such as trips abroad. My friends opposite know exactly what I mean. On the other hand they now have a chance to tell people the truth and nothing but.
Today the truth is yes, we are fed up with the constitutional debate; yes, 30 years of this is more than enough; and yes, some people are incapable of making decisions when they are supposed to. There are governments that govern by opinion polls, their only interest being in getting re-elected when election time come up, which applies both to the Mulroney government and the Bourassa government. However, some people realize that and will say no to the agreement because they are sick and tired of this kind of treatment.
We can hardly be expected to applaud in a supine position. Why should we applaud the fact that we have to get down on our knees? I think that is beneath our dignity.
Why should Quebec, which is demanding a number of historic rights, accept this agreement and say yes? Quebec has at least as many rights as the aboriginal people. The point is that Quebec's historic rights are extremely important. We cannot sell our birthright for a mess of pottage. There are a number of issues that are extremely important. If our leaders, our first ministers, are unable to meet their commitments, to keep their promises, to respect Quebec as it is and in such a way
Government Orders
that Quebec will feel at home in Canada and will again become a part of the Canadian family, with honour and enthusiasm, to quote the Prime Minister, if they cannot do that then they should get out, and If they do not go willingly there will be an election pretty soon.
Next year there will be a federal election, and there will probably be a number of elections at the provincial level as well. Then we will be able to deal with the real problems, because we are not getting anywhere here in the House.
We are being asked to approve an agreement without any kind of legal text. We are given a document that is not a final text and we are told that the final version will not be ready until Christmas, but just the same we are being asked to approve this one on October 26.
Why the hurry all of a sudden when the Charest committee, the Spicer commission, Castonguay-Dobbie and Beaudoin-Dobbie met for months and this was in addition to the constitutional conferences? All of a sudden we are confronted with a non-definitive draft agreement, no text, and it is all very urgent. As members of this House neither I nor my colleagues have been asked to work on this text. It was drafted without any consultation with Parliament. The best face they can put on this is to say: "Vote for this agreement because it is the best we can do. In any case, you are so fed up you might as well vote in favour of the agreement to get rid of the whole thing".
I am sure Quebecers will pronounce a resounding no to this proposal and this charade.

Mr. Speaker, I am most pleased to be able to speak on this historic occasion. Like many Canadians I have roots in all parts of Canada. When my father emigrated from Russia he landed in Montreal, moved on to Winnipeg, and settled in Edmonton. My mother was bom in southern Quebec. I was bom in Alberta, my wife was bom in British Columbia, my daughters lived in Nova Scotia, Ontario and Quebec. I have aunts, uncles, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews in every part of Canada.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
For me, the loss and cutting off of one part of Canada would mean the loss and cutting off of part of my family. I, as a Canadian, will not allow this to happen. That is why I am supporting the accord reached in Charlottetown.
I am one of these people who has had some unique opportunities. I have been a negotiator for unions. I have also been a negotiator for management. I have negotiated on both sides. I have made recommendations to principals to accept the outcomes of negotiations on numerous occasions. Not once were those recommendations based on the fact that I had got everything I wanted, that I had got everything I had asked for, wished for, or dreamed for; or that the deal was perfect or that was going to be the last time there was going to be discussion about it. Contracts, like constitutions, are living. They are not static and they will evolve. However, I made recommendations based on the premise that at this time that was the best deal I could arrive at.
For me, the constitutional accord had a number of bottom lines. It had things which I felt had to be there for me to support it. There were five of them in particular. Some other minor ones, but five in particular. First, there had to be justice for our aboriginal people.
For 200 years we have kept the aboriginal peoples from controlling their own lives and their own destiny. We have stopped them from fulfilling their potential, fulfilling it in their own way and within their own culture and values. This constitutional agreement, through its recognition of the inherent right to self-government, meets my concerns to allow for justice for our first peoples. The fact that the aboriginal peoples will also be guaranteed seats in the Senate strengthens their rights and recognizes their special status in Canada.
The second point that this constitution had to include was what we call a social charter. There had to be some recognition that Canadians had social rights within this country, and this agreement does that. I am most pleased to see that it sets out policy objectives. The first is providing throughout Canada a health care system that is comprehensive, universal, portable, publicly administered and accessible. Right now in British Columbia that is very important because our medical association has gone on record stating that it does not support those five
principles of public medicare. They are now enshrined in the Constitution.
It provides for adequate social services and benefits to ensure reasonable access to housing, food and other basic necessities. It provides an objective for quality education, both primary and secondary. For me and people who have been involved in labour, it recognizes the rights of workers to organize and to be collectively represented. It recognizes the need to preserve and sustain the integrity of the environment, not only now but in the future.
It met my concerns around the second point, guarantees for social rights.
My third bottom line was to abolish that abomination of a non-elected Senate. We are in a democratic society in which we are still being governed by people who are appointed in a manner that is reminiscent of colonialism and the landed property rights of the wealthy. There is nothing more insidious than that other place has been over the years. It is an anachronism in a democracy. No other modem democracy would have tolerated it for the length of time that Canadians have.
This agreement finally abolishes the non-elected Senate. It provides us with an elected Senate that equally represents the provinces and has a meaningful role in the government of this country.
My fourth requirement was that this Constitution, and I am sorry that the previous speaker has had to leave, gives Quebec the tools and resources it needs to maintain itself as a distinct society in terms of its language and its culture.
I visited Quebec on many occasions and I love it. I love it because it is French. It is a different culture and a different society. That is what makes it so valuable. It is the one thing that I sometimes cannot understand when I talk to people, particularly people from the Reform Party. They seem not to understand that the very thing that makes Quebec so valuable to Canada is that it is different, that it is distinct, that it does have a different culture and a different language. It is like a part of a family. If everybody in the family was the same, you would not value them. You value them because they are individual, they are different, and they are distinct. That is the value we place on Quebec.
September 10, 1992

This Constitution gives Quebec those tools.
Fifth, particularly important for me with my concern for social justice and social programs, was that the federal government had to have been left with the power to institute new national programs such as day care. This constitutional agreement makes it clear that it can.
It is still going to take a government that has the will to do it. Simply because it is permitted within a Constitution does not mean that it will automatically be done. It will take a government that has the will.
Yes, there are things that I do not like about this agreement, things that fell short of what I would have liked to see. Quite frankly I am disappointed that the federal government is surrendering so much of its responsibility in the area of social housing. There is a need for social housing programs and policies that are nation-wide and uniform.
I would have liked it if the needs and wishes of the handicapped and the visible minorities were better addressed. I certainly would have liked it if issues around promotion of gender equality were addressed more strongly in the Constitution, and felt that they could have been.
That is always what happens when you go into negotiations, you do not get everything you want. On balance you have to make a decision.
My householder is coming out. It is already being printed. I would like to read what I am saying to my constituents of Surrey North which is, as everybody knows, the fastest growing riding in Canada. It consists now of 55,000 households.
As I write, a national referendum is being planned on the constitutional proposals agreed to by the first ministers and now being considered by Parliament.
I urge you to take part in the debate accompanying the referendum and to make an informed voting choice.
The constitutional process has been long and arduous but B.C. has made gains through a more equal Senate and a total of seven new House of Commons seats between now and the 1996 census redistribution.
My own choice is to accept the agreement. I have many reservations but the social charter, the recognition of native self-government and increased B.C. power in the House of Commons are clear advances.
We cannot start from scratch yet again and hope to retain one country-
Vaughn Palmer, writing in The Vancouver Sun of Aug. 28, said: "This accord represents a defeat for separatism and it will allow our
Government Orders
leaders to get on with issues like economic recovery. For those reasons alone, the deal is a good thing and we ought to accept it".
I want to say one other thing. I am not worried about the no forces being led in the province of British Columbia by the Reform Party or by the carpings of people like Gordon Wilson, the provincial leader of the Liberal Party. However, I am very much concerned about the bickering and sniping of the Tory caucus from British Columbia against the premier of B.C.
That is the only way that the referendum will be defeated in British Columbia. I urge them to unequivocally stand up, each and every one of the Tory caucus, and declare that they are fully behind this accord and fully behind the premier of British Columbia so that we may all move forward with this constitutional deal. As Vaughn Palmer says: "For those reasons alone, the deal is a good thing and we ought to accept it".

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker and hon. members, it is a very great privilege for me to stand in the House today and participate in this very important debate.
It seems to me after listening to some of the speeches that surely the truest test of democracy is its ability to withstand dissent. In this Canadian discussion we have certainly had many opposing points of view to bring forward. However, in spite of all that, on August 28 in Charlottetown Canada's first ministers and the territorial and aboriginal leaders finally reached a consensus on a number of constitutional reforms.
The path to this consensus was a long one with many stops for consultation and reflection along the way. However, I suppose that is the way it should be, because nation-building is a never-ending journey.
This journey that Canadians embarked upon to make Canada whole again and to revitalize our federation has been a long and sometimes a difficult one. There have been set-backs; there have even been set-tos. Throughout the journey all of us who had the honour and the privilege of participating in the process were inspired by one single goal, that at the end of the day if we listened to Canadians and heard what they themselves had to tell us then surely the outcome would be a stronger, more united, more modem Canada.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
We are close to achieving that objective. On October 26 Canadians will have an opportunity to express their views on the consensus for constitutional accord that was reached and on issues that will change the fundamental laws of our land.
Consensus itself does not reflect any individual idea of perfection. Instead it is an agreement representing the majority view after all sides have been heard and have been listened to and after all issues have been thoroughly discussed. Consensus building is the modem and civilized way to deal with opposing viewpoints.
The other old way involved conflict, anger, bitterness, all those emotions that lead us blindly and ultimately to destruction. Those engaged in building consensus know that their personal opinions, their own dearly held convictions are at risk of being lost in the search for an accord that everyone can accept.
In this discussion there is no question that the me's and I's are irrelevant. What is relevant here is the common good. Certainly the August accord reflects most of the constitutional aspirations that Canadians themselves have articulated over the past number of years and months. Canadians certainly have been articulate in this particular Canada round.
Let me just tell you a little bit about some of the consultations. It began with the Citizens' Forum on Canada's Future. Some 400,000 Canadians were heard. Then the special joint committee on the amending formula heard testimony from 209 witnesses and received over 500 briefs from 450 groups and individuals.
The results of these initiatives played a very important role in shaping the 28 proposals the federal government put forward last September in Shaping Canada's Future Together. This then was referred to the 30-member Special Joint Committee on a Renewed Canada I had the privilege of co-chairing.
Of course my committee travelled across Canada. We visited small and large communities. We heard from Canadians from all walks of life in all stations. That was part of the fulfilment of our mandate to get advice from people across the country on the government's proposals. Some 3,000 concerned individuals and groups took
the time to send written submissions to the committee and another 700 appeared before us as witnesses.
The committee also initiated a series of government-sponsored conferences that involved 1,500 participants including interest groups, academics, civil servants from various levels of government, and perhaps most important but certainly most especially, ordinary Canadians. All of this led to the final unanimous report by the committee that was tabled on February 28.
Then, of course, each of the provinces and territories held constitutional hearings. The aboriginal community itself participated in the discussion and held hearings across the land.
Equipped with the results of these extensive individual consultations and dialogue, federal, provincial and territorial leaders, and for the first time in Canadian history, aboriginal leaders from Canada's four aboriginal associations met as equal partners and looked for a consensus that was already emerging.
Throughout this phase of the Canada round, reality and flexibility were the watchwords that carried the day. We had learned from the Meech Lake process that closing doors does not open minds. At the end of each day after the negotiations, people came out and said what they thought, mentioned where they had made progress, expressed their concern and involved the public in the discussions that were going on.
On July 7 unanimous agreement on the principles of constitutional reform were reached. This opened the doors that allowed Quebec to come to the table for a first ministers' conference.
Finally on August 22, after extensive discussion, the Prime Minister announced the premises and principles of this particular accord had been achieved. The first ministers, the aboriginal leaders, the territorial leaders had reached a fair and workable consensus.
I think it is very important to remember all of these things as we proceed to the debate over the referendum question, the question on the Charlottetown accord.
We must also remember consensus does not respond to any particular interest. Consensus responds to the common interest, and the common interest at hand in this particular case is to unite our diverse federation with
September 10,1992

the threads of the agreement that were spun from the consensus at Charlottetown.
It worries me greatly when I hear interest groups making statements that spurn the accord because their particular agendas are not being met. I remind all of you whose interests may not have been specifically addressed that this is not the final constitutional round. I remind you the Constitution is a living tree with roots going deep into our past to find nourishment and growth for the future.
There will be another chance. In the meantime of course we are all protected by the kind of country Canada is, by its social order, by the genesis in the British parliamentary system and the guarantees that are already contained in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. No single interest can prevail in this particular discussion.
As I said before, there will be other times for compelling interests still to be heard and ultimately entrenched in the Constitution if it is proven they are for the greater good of our country and our society.
Let us turn now to what is in the accord. The first thing that strikes me as I read the document is that it is an affirmative document. It is a document that is positive and expresses things that say yes.
It is an affirmative statement about the interdependence of the partners in the Canadian federation. It is an affirmative statement about Quebec's right to remain in Canada while maintaining its language and its custom of civil law, both of which created a distinct, unique culture. I might just say this distinctiveness lends character to all of us as Canadians as well. I do not think any Canadian who thinks about it for very long will agree that Canada would be Canada without Quebec.
The Charlottetown consensus is also an affirmation or statement about the kind of nation we are, a parliamentary democracy wherein people respect and care for each other and where we draw strength from our diversity and from our individuality. It is an affirmative statement about our ability to be flexible about our institutions, open to changes that respond to the imperatives of the times.
Government Orders
It seeks to rebalance the sharing of power, to maintain the integrity of a strong federal government in a federal system. It seeks to empower first peoples by returning to them their right to determine their own affairs. It seeks to address an old and compelling sense of alienation and regional imbalance through changes to the Senate and through entrenched first ministers' conferences where matters of the federation can be addressed in a regular and more productive basis.
These are the issues, the important premises and principles that Canadians must keep in mind as we go through the next weeks of this discussion about the particular question at hand. It is important that we not be side-tracked by single special interests. It is important we set aside our special interests in the pursuit of a common goal.
We also must resist the temptation to get bogged down in wrangling over details or even more interestingly, get caught up in the fascinating but often unproductive exercise of constitutional hair-splitting.
When all is said and done most of us want the same things. We want fairness, equality, freedom, respect, prosperity, and the ability to have a say in the things and decisions that will affect us. Most of us want desperately to keep this country together because these are the things that Canada stands for. These are the things that are reaffirmed in this constitutional accord.
As we have heard before perhaps we do not have perfection here, but if it is not perfection, at least we know it is an honest attempt by honest men and women and by honest people everywhere in Canada to build a better country, one that will last for a millennium, a country for the future.

Mr. Speaker, I am honoured today to rise to the debate on the referendum and the Constitution of Canada, the renewed Canada's Constitution.
This debate is not about our past; this debate is about our future. It is about reordering our constitutional priorities in a way that will better reflect who and what we are as a nation and what we want to become.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
In the process of finding solutions many different options were put forward. The agreement reached between federal, provincial and territorial governments and the representatives of aboriginal Canadians is not the perfect solution to all our problems. Everyone recognizes that fact and it has been stated over and over again in the House.
Many of us on both sides of this House have many questions about different aspects of this new arrangement. For example, there is no national economic union clause. That begs for more discussion.
Of course many would say it is an imperfect Senate because there is a trade-off there. Effectiveness is traded off for equality in the number of seats. Delay in the justiciability of self-government to five years rather than immediacy. Perhaps too great a shift to the provinces and the weakening of the federal government's role and the true meaning of a strong central government.
Some problems of course are referred to with the ambiguity of the words in the question itself which states "on the basis of" and means that the Charlottetown accord will be subject to interpretation by several different governments.
However, I personally believe that the deficiencies of this constitutional package do not outweigh its many positive aspects. For that reason, I intend to encourage the support of this agreement and encourage all Canadians, northerners, aboriginal people, women, minority groups, all Canadians to vote yes on the referendum on October 26.
It seems clear to me and to most other Canadians that after several years of trying and after the failure of the last attempt to reach a constitutional consensus, this proposal is the best we can expect.
I have personally been involved in several rounds of constitutional discussions. I have learned a lot and I pay tribute to those members of Parliaments, the people who provided legal advice from the various departments and from our party's perspective and to the senators who have the accumulative experience to have shared with us. It has been an honour to serve with people like Senator MacEachen and to learn from these people who have been through numerous rounds on the Constitution.
I was on the Charest committee and the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. I have also had some dealings with the Meech Lake accord and with the last first minister's conference which I feel was a dismal failure, not just a failure for individuals but a failure for this country. It was a failure for First Nations and a failure for northerners.
I always said that I would accept Meech Lake amended and I believe what we have with this particular consensus is Meech plus. I am satisfied the aspirations of the north will be met because with the Northwest Territories we wanted to have the pre-1982 conditions prevail for the creation of new provinces and this deal gives us that.
We have a yes team in the Northwest Territories. I spoke to the Minister for Aboriginal Rights and Constitutional Development who has worked very hard for the north and the aspirations of northern peoples. He definitely agrees with this consensus that we have reached and would support what was agreed to in Charlottetown.
We also have a premier in the north, Nellie Cour-noyea, who worked very hard. We had Rosemary Kupta-na from the Northwest Territories who is the president of ITC. We also have Roger Gruben, president of the Inuvialuit Development Regional Corporation, who is also very instrumental. We also have John A. I always call John Amagoalik John A, the other John A, who also played a role in numerous rounds of the Constitution. We have Gary Bohnet who represents the Metis First Nations in the Northwest Territories.
These people have made a significant contribution. We have other people who have contributed from the north who have contributed as well. Because I am a northerner, I have to speak of northerners. These people are Mary Simon from northern Quebec who is adviser to Rosemary Kuptana. We have Francoise Paulet who participated in the AFN's national circle on Constitution.
I want to say that I feel that after numerous rounds on the Constitution we have come to a point, come to a position where we have to say this is good enough. This is as good as it can get.
I am prepared to make that commitment. I am prepared to stand with my party and with my people and say that if we proceed to open up this whole can of worms again we stand to lose everything. I believe we have achieved a lot on the inherent right to self-govem-
September 10, 1992

ment. We have the four national leaders to thank for that.
We have the Assembly of First Nations Chief, Ovide Mercredi, we have Ron George from the Native Council of Canada. We also have Yvon Dumont from the Metis and we have Rosemary Kuptana from the Inuit Tapirisat of Canada.
Northerners and aboriginal people have made a significant contribution to what will become the renewed Canada. Aboriginal Canadians love this country. They love this land. They use this land. The rivers are not just scenery. The mountains are not just to look at. They are there because the aboriginal people claim title. The reason they claim title and the reason that aboriginal people find it unacceptable to extinguish their rights is that they really believe that if you utilize the land, if you respect it, you cannot be separated from it. That to us is what is Canada.
I am proud today to say: "Canada, you have my support. My people are important to me. This country is important to me. As aboriginal people we are going to contribute. There were many concessions that were made on all sides, but I have to tell you, Canada, you have my yes".

Mr. Speaker, it is with honour and with great pleasure that I stand here today to take part in this historic debate on the Charlottetown accord. At the end of the day we will have the vote that will be set down in history.
I would like to take this opportunity to join with my colleagues in the House in congratulating the minister for constitutional affairs, the member for Yellowhead, for his work. It has been a hard road for him as well as for all Canadians, but we now see the light at the end of the tunnel.
I believe that when one looks at the positive side, and there are many positive factors, of the whole constitutional debate that has taken place in recent months, one can only conclude that it has brought us closer together and has made us more aware of one another.
This proposal is a result of numerous forums and public meetings, national and regional consultations with aboriginals, women's groups, with all kinds of organizations and business interests. As the Leader of the
Government Orders
Opposition said Tuesday, we have been consulting on the Constitution since 1980.
I can report that many of my constituents took the time to tell me of their feelings about Canada and what follows is a summary of those. We now have completed the consultation process and we are at the pinnacle of our democratic system, the preparation necessary for holding a national referendum.
In April 1991 the Leader of the Opposition proposed the use of a referendum. I am extremely pleased that the federal government took the initiative to utilize this process.
We have been committed to this process every step of the way. The polls indicated that Canadians wanted a referendum and now each and every one of them will have the opportunity to help decide this country's future. October 26, 1992 will give every Canadian an incredible sense of pride to be able to mark their ballot.
The outcome of the October 26 vote will be a yes to Canada, a yes to a stronger and much better Canada.
Canadians are eager to turn the page on the Constitution. They are anxious to deal with another ailment, the economy. We have record unemployment in this country and we are facing many new challenges as we prepare for the 21st century. Now we will have the tools to face these new challenges as the country will function as a unit, as a team.
I realize that time does not permit me to speak on all the points that I wish to, but I would like to address a few issues. I am pleased that our initiative to have a Canada clause has been accepted and that it ensures a commitment by all Canadians to the future of this country. The commitment to linguistic duality also gives the two official linguistic groups an opportunity to flourish and to guarantee under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms the protection of individuals' rights.
For all of us, economic union is of the utmost importance. How can we expect to be competitive in the world market when we cannot resolve our country's interprovincial barriers? It is difficult to understand that we can have a free trade agreement with the United States and we can be taking part in negotiations on NAFTA, and yet interprovincial trade has met with numerous obstacles with no agreement in sight. We must become united economically. I strongly believe that protectionism de-

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
feats to a certain extent the spirit of the Charlottetown agreement.
In 1982 the Liberal Party enshrined in its constitution the inherent right for native self-government. I am very pleased that since then the concept has evolved and many first nation communities are prepared to determine and to control their destiny according to their values and traditions. However, this objective can only be attained if the federal government and the provincial governments supply them with the economic tools favouring a balanced development of the communities.
I do have some reservations about the Senate. I really question the logic behind the allocation of senators. Do we really need a Senate in its proposed form? If we are to have a Senate we must ensure that it is useful, that it has adequate powers to be effective. Moreover, I fail to see how a senator could emulate his duties as a legislator as well as answer his constituents' needs. For example, a senator in my province of Ontario would have well over 1.5 million people to serve. It is not humanly possible to do both jobs adequately. It should be revisited, as it needs much improvement.
For the time being we have come a long way and years down the road we will look back with pride and a sigh of relief at this period in history. Once again I would like to say that I am pleased that on October 26 Canadians will be voting in a national referendum. Canadians will, once and for all, put the record straight by voting to strengthen the bonds that bind our regions together and retain this country called Canada.
This morning I was standing in my office and on the wall I have a framed copy of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The quote at the end of the charter summarizes exactly what we are trying to accomplish: "We must now establish the basic principles, the basic values and beliefs which hold us together as Canadians so that beyond our regional loyalties there is a way of life and a system of values which makes us proud of the country that has given us such freedom and such immeasurable joy".
We are the envy of the world and I am proud to be a Canadian.

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to rise
in the House in support of this consensus report on the Constitution reached in Charlottetown on August 28, 1992. I am also delighted to be here in the company of members of the House from all sides who are supporting this consensus.
We in Canada are privileged to engage in what is surely one of the most fundamental exercises of democratic tradition, a national referendum on a renewed Constitution, the fundamental document of our democracy.
There are millions of people around the world at this very moment who are not privileged, whose disagreements are settled by bullets instead of by debate, whose freedoms are defined by command instead of by consensus, whose futures depend on the laws of force instead of the force of laws.
As Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs for the past 17 months, I have been honoured to represent Canadians at the most important international organizations in the world, the United Nations, the Commonwealth, la Francophonie, the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe, the Organization of American States, to name just a few.

In each of these organizations, Canada's voice is very special and highly respected because it speaks for tolerance, respect for diversity and human rights, progress, prosperity and above all peace and stability.

Our achievements in these regards are reinforced by our actions, whether in the dangerous battlefield surrounding Sarajevo or in the desolation of Somalia. In Cambodia, in the Middle East, in Central America, Asia and in the South Pacific Canada is a welcome intervener, whether as a peacekeeper or a mediator or as a partner in development through trade or through assistance.
There are very few people, citizens of veiy few nations of the world, who are accorded the same passe-partout that is accorded to Canada and to Canadians. We are blessed with a very special measure of goodwill from virtually all of the peoples of the world. This goodwill does not show up in our national accounts, certainly not directly, but it is a very real part of our national heritage,
September 10, 1992

a heritage that we have built as Canadians together, one that is shared by all Canadians.
When the nations of the world see Canada, they do not see a collection of provinces. They see one country, Canada; a country where the whole is greater than the sum of the parts. When they hear Canadian voices at international meetings they do not question the fact that we speak English or French or a combination. They hear the voice of one country, Canada, and they know the message they are hearing is an important one.
When Canadian teachers or athletes or business people go abroad, people in their host countries do not ask if they are aboriginal or first generation or second generation. They are welcomed as the citizens of one country, Canada.
At the United Nations the face of Canada is a francophone woman from Montreal. Our face in Latin America is a man from McLennan, Alberta, and at NATO it is a native from Ontario who speaks for all Canadians.
The faces of Canada abroad are much the same as the faces in this Chamber and the faces on our streets and neighbourhoods around this great nation.
These people many times over the past several years of gruelling constitutional negotiations and discussions have time and again been asked: What is happening to Canada? Will Canada stay together?
They will now be able to answer those questions with a resounding yes, Canada will stay together. Yes, Canadians have sorted out their differences in the great Canadian democratic tradition. Yes, Canadians have found new ways to live together in our diversity as neighbours and as friends with dignity and with respect for one another.
Yes, we have reformed our institutions to enhance our democratic principles. Yes, we have provided fundamental justice to our first peoples. Yes, we have rebalanced internal roles and responsibilities to ensure continued progress and prosperity. Yes, we have developed new processes that can be a shining light to those peoples throughout the world who seek sometimes at great cost their own democracy.
Yes, the shining torch of our ideals, our values, our principles can be passed to the next generation and to
Government Orders
many generations to come. Most of all, yes, we have done this despite disagreement, despite tension, through discussion with sensitivity and a sense of compromise with our only weapons: reason and love of country.

It will be a great day for the nations of the world because Canada has always had a reputation as a country that uses democracy to the limit. That it can reach this limit without oppression and bloodshed is a lesson that many other countries will want to learn thoroughly, whatever their own stage of democratic development.
Seeing a modem Canada emerge from this process even stronger and better prepared to face the challenges of the next century, they will be even more inclined to follow us on the paths of peace.
I just said how well disposed other countries in the world are towards Canada. Our great success in resolving our own internal conflicts can only strengthen that good feeling.

Canada and Canadians have never backed down in the face of suffering or adversity, from the Canadian soldiers with roots from all parts of Canada who died in distant places through two world wars, in Korea and in numerous peacekeeping missions, to the proud young men and women who carry the name Canada on their uniforms today to new and dangerous situations.
We have been and will continue to be a force for peace and justice in the world. We are on the verge of achieving inner peace and that will only strengthen our resolve to bring this same gift to the many troubled nations of the world.
Two weeks from today I will have the honour of addressing on behalf of our country the nations of the world at the 47th session of the United Nations General Assembly, an association that Canada was very active in founding. Much of my speech will deal with the quest for peace in the world, for the need for democratic development and the protection of basic human rights.
As I deliver those words in New York my thoughts will be with the thousands of Canadians who serve us around the world and those other thousands of Canadians who participated in our discussions at home through commissions and task forces, whose valuable work and insights

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
ultimately guided the agreement reached in Charlottetown.
They have done a great service not just for Canada but for the world's community of nations. They have wrestled with many of the same problems and shown that there are in fact reasonable and honourable solutions peacefully achieved.
By saying yes to Canada, Canadians will play no small part in establishing a standard for peace and tolerance to be emulated by all the nations of the world.
When I see how other countries are tearing themselves apart through ethnic hatreds, whose roots are lost in the obscure myths of history, I thank God for our country and I thank God for our success in achieving this solution so recently come to that is bringing us even closer together as Canadians. I think as well that were Canada to fail, God help the world.

Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure to say a few words here today on behalf of my riding on an issue which future generations will most likely judge to be of great historical importance.
The agreement reached at the Charlottetown conference is the culmination of five years debate and it needs to be supported as a major step toward the evolution of our Constitution.
Previous speakers have mentioned people in their provinces, the Prime Minister has lauded a number of people who have participated in the debate leading up to the agreement, and members of my party and the New Democratic Party have done likewise, but I do not think anyone has mentioned to this point the contribution made by the host of the Charlottetown conference, Premier Joseph A. Ghiz.
Premier Ghiz over the past five years of constitutional debates, successes and failures, has always had the national good first and foremost in mind. The provincial interest of Prince Edward Island he felt would naturally be taken care of if the national good was taken care of first.
He always believed in a country which included all provinces, which included all people within those provinces. He has made an immeasurable contribution to the
success of the Charlottetown agreement and I believe he will be recognized in the future as one of the new fathers of this country.
One of the things which Premier Ghiz agreed to and which still seems to be a centre of debate not only with government members but with members of my own party, was an equal Senate.
Prince Edward Island, regardless of its population and regardless of the fact it has four members of Parliament, is much more than that. There are ridings in this country which are much bigger than Prince Edward Island, there are ridings in this country which have a greater population than Prince Edward Island, but these ridings never were, are not, and never will be provinces.
Prince Edward Island was accepted as a province in 1873 after a number of years of courtship by John A. Macdonald and the other Fathers of Confederation to enter into the Canadian union. Finally they accepted and agreed to become a participant in Confederation and they were accepted as a province by the Fathers and have been a province ever since.
The new concept of the Senate I believe is long overdue. It not only recognizes Prince Edward Island as an equal to our sister provinces, it also will be able to play an effective role because of its legitimacy as an elected body in forming legislation for the eastern region. The Atlantic region and the western region combined will have 80 per cent of the Senate. It says in one of the booklets which were passed out that the Senate could have prevented policies like the National Energy Program and the GST from ever happening. I would think if that is true, and I believe it is true, I believe the reorganization of the Senate is probably three years too late in one regard for Prince Edward Island. If that Senate had been in effect in 1989 the closure of the search and rescue facility in Prince Edward Island and more particularly in St. Eleanor's and Sum-merside would not have happened. I think the Canadian people recognized that particular move as a very unfair policy of a very vindictive government. I think they would have stopped that particular policy move and Prince Edward Island still would have enjoyed a military base as each of the other provinces do.
September 10, 1992

As we know, the federal government and the 10 premiers, the two territorial leaders and the leaders of our aboriginal peoples have come together in an historic, classic Canadian compromise. Rejection of this accord would not guarantee that some time down the road we would have a better deal. What it would guarantee, however, are many more years of tortuous constitutional debate. Canadians have been beaten to death by this constitutional debate.
For the past five long years they have undergone such a constitutional bombardment that now throughout the country there is a desperate cry for relief. Accompanying this cry is a growing demand for action on what is considered the real problems of this country. The people of Canada want this forum here, this House of Commons to get down and address the real day-to-day problems of this country, whether it is the 1.6 million people who are on unemployment insurance, the many more who have given up even looking for work and the many who have had to go to relief or welfare. The people of this country, and I think with good reason, want us to get on with the business of this country, governing this country and creating jobs for the Canadian people.
Despite all these problems that we have had, a few short months ago the UN chose Canada as the best place in the world to live. After 125 years we are now at the top of the heap as far as the 160 most developed countries in the world are concerned. I do not think we are prepared as a people to throw this rating down the drain. There are very few Canadians who do not realize what will happen economically if this particular agreement is not supported.
In conclusion, I want to say that I am prepared in my riding of Egmont to form a non-partisan group of political parties, of Royal Canadian Legions, of businessmen, whatever it takes to make sure that the vote in my particular riding is a positive vote for this country.

Mr. Speaker, the Charlottetown agreement represents the culmination of the most inclusive public political process that this country has ever experienced, a process which is in sharp contrast to the Meech Lake process where we saw
Government Orders
a small group of men cook up a deal behind closed doors. The Charlottetown agreement was preceded by the Spicer commission. It had the input of the Allaire report, the Belanger-Campeau report, the Edwards' committee report, the Beaudoin-Dobbie report, provincial reports, public constitutional forum reports which were held across this country and televised and which included the direct active participation of hundreds and hundreds of Canadians. Last but not least, it includes the recorded opinion of my constituents in Northumberland who responded to constitutional meetings and public forums, surveys and submission requests.
As a Liberal member of the House of Commons, I did not have a personal, direct role in the formulation of the Charlottetown agreement, yet I endorse it. I did have an ample opportunity to input to the Liberal Party of Canada constitutional policy process.
I am especially proud of our leader and our constitutional affairs critic for their leadership in moving the proposal in directions which I believe reflect the history, tradition, values and wishes of the majority of Canadians. Of course they were closely and diligently assisted by other members of our caucus.
I was particularly proud when our leader appeared in 1991 before the Belanger-Campeau commission, the only federal politician to speak unequivocally and forcefully in Quebec in support of a strong, central federal government.
What we have before us today and what we are being asked to vote upon by referendum on October 26 is the so-called Charlottetown agreement, a final constitutional agreement. Because it represents the final consensus of the federal government, 10 premiers, leaders of the territories and aboriginal leaders who reflected upon all the earlier mentioned reports, I believe it has validity as a document and must be seriously considered by all Canadians.
Since the end of last week we have had copies of the actual agreement text as agreed to at the meeting in Charlottetown. The fact that we do not have the legal language translation of this is not in my opinion terribly relevant although cast as essential by those who would oppose supporting this agreement, I suspect for other reasons.
September 10,1992

Government Orders
The agreement in plain English is before us and is available to anyone in the constituency of Northumberland or Canada who wishes a copy. We do want Canadians to be fully informed on what they are being asked to make a decision on October 26.
Although the Charlottetown agreement represents a broad consensus of opinion it is not perfect, but I believe it is not possible to produce the perfect agreement, the perfect agreement to meet all of my concerns and the concerns of each and every Canadian.
Nonetheless, the agreement encompasses some very important principles and values which will enhance the character and well-being of all in our country. It will allow us to take a fresh breath of Canadian air, clear our minds of constitutional legalities, and have a vision of a new prosperous future in Canada and a perspective of Canada's important and respected place in the international community.
I am particularly pleased that the Charlottetown agreement recognizes the inherent rights of our native peoples to self-government. I am pleased that the agreement recognizes Canada's historical heritage of linguistic duality and that it recognizes Quebec's distinctiveness.
The desire of Canadians to encompass all Canadians' heritages and cultures within our mosiac is important. These positive messages must be conveyed to all citizens.
I am, however, disappointed that we did not achieve the economic union we advocated and that the Senate reform falls far short of the ideal. I do believe that much can be done to correct these inadequacies through House of Commons rules and the amending formula encompassed in the agreement.
Canadians will be urged by me to support the Charlottetown agreement. We are all weary of the constitutional issue, as my leader says: "sick to death". We are not going to get a better alternative. We have a culmination of many ideas, visions in this agreement. We do not now have room for destructive prejudice and historical misunderstandings to undermine our achievements to date.
We must get on in this country to deal at the national level with the issues that are crippling and plaguing our country: joblessness, poverty, economic and regional woes of every sort, environmental issues, equity issues and legal issues.
I will work in my riding of Northumberland to continue the public information process begun several months ago. I am promoting the organization in Northumberland of an official yes committee and will encourage all political parties, all groups and individuals who support a yes vote, to participate.
I will hold more public forums in centres such as Port Hope, Cobourg, Colbome, Campbellford, Brighton, and Trenton, much the same as was done by me previously in Northumberland, to get my constituents' views into the constitution development process.
I am anxious to meet with school groups, clubs, organizations, ad hoc groups of constituents at any time between now and October 26 in order to help in building an understanding of the Charlottetown agreement. I am pleased that the Liberal Party request and the wishes of 98 per cent of my constituents for this referendum are being met. Our Northumberland yes committee will endeavour to get a resounding yes to the Charlottetown constitutional agreement and to Canada on October 26.
In closing I would like to remind other Canadians and my constituents of Canada's very special qualities through the words of a constituent, Phetwaney Luan-grath, who arrived in Canada from Southeast Asia as a refugee at age 5 and who now, at 19, won a Cobourg Rotary Club essay on the theme of Canada and national pride. After living a year in a refugee camp in Thailand, she writes:
We had the opportunity to apply to the country in which we wished to live. The countries that one could apply to were the United States, Canada, France and Germany. My family applied to Canada, a place we had heard believed in freedom, dignity, respect, equality and fair treatment and was a country of opportunities. These were all the qualities for which my family was looking.
In conclusion she writes:
I do not think that a parent can do anything more special for their family than bring them to a country of peace and freedom.
Let us all reflect upon the words of this young Canadian. Let us all with open minds endeavour to understand the choice we are being asked to make on October 26, consider the implications of refusal and make an unequivocal choice for a renewed Canada, a land where we envision future generations of Canadians living in peace and freedom and with an abundance of opportunity and well-being for all.
September 10,1992

Mr. Speaker, the question we should be debating today is: Do you agree to give your governments the mandate of negotiating changes to the Canadian Constitution on the basis of the agreement reached on August 28, 1992? Yes or no.
We are really dealing with endless negotiations here. Indeed, in this 60-point agreement, Mr. Jean Allaire from the Quebec Liberal Party picked out 60 points requiring negotiation or clarification following the referendum. What we are really asked for is a mandate to negotiate without a deadline.
I guess that when the Minister of National Health and Welfare and member for Roberval says that he does not want to hear about the Constitution after October 26, that is just his way of telling us he plans to resign, probably in hope of being appointed ambassador, something he has been dreaming of for months.
The question is not whether there will be further negotiations but whether we agree to further negotiations on the basis of the preliminary agreement reached on August 28, 1992. To believe that this referendum will close the constitutional debate is pure nonsense. Especially considering that, under the guise of a democratic process we are asked to surrender all our aspirations. We are asked to accept minority status under federal authority. What the proposal really amounts to for the people of Quebec is the slow death so well described by Mrs. Lise Bissonnette, editor of Le Devoir.
The Prime Minister still dares to talk about honour and dignity. He still dares holding up the Canadian federalism as an example of tolerance where the French language will be protected till kingdom come. He did not make that statement in English, mind you. Two languages, two messages.
In French, this is called demagogy. Saint-Exupery said that demagogy sets in when, in the absence of a common denominator, the principle of equality is cause to degenerate and turn into that of identity.
That is why the Prime Minister is spending tens of millions of our tax dollars in publicity to make us believe that we are Canadians and proud of being Canadians, as
Government Orders
if the pride of a nation could be bought and sold like a box of soap.
Although the target of repeated brain-washing attempts, the vast majority of the people who live in Quebec have grown to become first and foremost Quebecers. That is the true identity we want to affirm. And millions of dollars in publicity cannot change that.
To get along with the rest of Canada, we are not prepared to lose our identity as has been the case for millions of francophones outside Quebec who were assimilated with no regard for their rights.
Let those who describe Canadian federalism as an example of tolerance tell us why Mr. Ovide Mercredi cannot remember that his ancestors spoke French.
We all know that since Confederation, of which the Prime Minister praises the visionary character and the spirit of tolerance, the rights of francophones have been disregarded. In fact, at one time the will to preserve one's francophone identity was even considered high treason.
Louis Riel would be ashamed to find out that more than a hundred years after he was hanged, a simple statement by the House of Commons praising his patriotism would make us forget the real history of intolerance towards francophones in this country.
We can understand that francophones outside Quebec would want to be protected as the minority group which they have become. They have a right to such protection, but Quebecers do not want to be recognized as a minority in Canada: they want to be recognized as a majority in Quebec. They do not want the provisional safeguards that the rest of Canada would deign grant them. They want, today and forever, be the masters of their own future.
Quebecers are no longer merely trying to survive: they are now asserting their full cultural, economic and social potential.
You all know very well that this basic reality is at the root of the recurring political crisis in Canadian federalism.
For Quebecers to assert their cultural, economic and social potential requires an appropriate political frame-

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
work, and there will be no constitutional peace as long as the political institutions will not recognize this need.
We all know that the citizens of the rest of Canada want the federal government, of which they form the majority, to have the right and the power to intervene in all aspects of their cultural, economic and social life. But we also know that, to the extent that Quebecers refuse to give to the federal government the tools necessary to shape their future, we will continue to be in a crisis.
We want to put an end to these endless political and constitutional crises. That is why Quebecers have reached a consensus on an approach and on concrete proposals, through the Belanger-Campeau commission. Among them, those who want to preserve the federal link have made a list of the rights and powers that they want exercised by the National Assembly, and a list of the rights and powers that they want to be exercised by the federal institutions, whereas others have proposed the patriation and devolution of all the rights and powers to the National Assembly, as well as forms of co-operation other than the federal link with the rest of Canada.
The basis for negotiation under the agreement reached on August 28, 1992 does not in any way satisfy the demands of even the federalists in Quebec.
We had reached a large consensus on our future and the decision made by Mr. Bourassa to break this consensus and accept the basis for negotiation proposed by the rest of Canada generates a major crisis in his own party, as well as disapproval among the majority of the population in Quebec. How can he claim that an agreement reached on that basis would put an end to the political crisis and the constitutional debate?
The about-face made by Mr. Bourassa will only increase tensions in Quebec and with the rest of Canada. We must call him to order. Quebecers have the opportunity during this debate to look at various aspects of the negotiation framework proposed in the August 28 agreement.
As financial critic, I am responsible for dealing more specifically with the economic side of these negotiation proposals.
Let us listen to Mr. Bernard Roy, former chief of staff of the Prime Minister and current chairman of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Montreal. He tells
