us: "It is obvious that what they are offering is not what the business community was asking for. Providing for a discussion procedure to give Quebec control over some areas of provincial jurisdiction through a five year agreement is not very efficient. And the proposal to give an equal Senate more powers will make the federal government more difficult to manage and less effective."
He then asks himself: "But if such is the price we have to pay to maintain the federal system and prevent the country from breaking up, are we going to turn our backs on this agreement because it creates some kind of monster?"
I still do not know how Mr. Roy will answer his question. I must thank him for having decided, despite his personal friendship with the Prime Minister of Canada, to make public such a clear assessment of the economic aspects of the August 28 proposals.
I can also understand the premier who decided to sell these proposals despite his friends' assessment and who joined forces so quickly with the head of the Liberal Party of Canada and Leader of the Official Opposition in the upcoming referendum campaign. He has chosen his side; let us choose ours.
With the economic challenge facing Montreal and all other regions of Quebec we must not agree to live with a monster just to save an overbearing federalism. On the contrary we must give ourselves political structures meeting the aspirations of both people and allowing them to finally express, without unnecessary and costly obstacles, the economic, cultural and social leadership they are capable of.
Why accept any longer the horrendous costs and inefficiency associated with having two ministries of Science, Technology, Justice, Immigration, Labour, Manpower, Revenue, Industry and Commerce, Financial Institutions, Health and Welfare, Energy and Resources, Agriculture, Environment, Transport, Recreation, Communications, Social Affairs, Regional Development, International Trade and even External Affairs?
This duplication is exceedingly costly for taxpayers and produces well-known horror stories such as a lack of co-ordination, inconsistency and even outright contradiction between programs run by both levels of government. It has become impossible for the taxpayer to know which level of government is responsible for what and to
September 10, 1992

make their elected officials accountable for their decisions.
If we want to stop wasting federal public funds we must take away from the federal government the power to collect and spend our taxes as it sees fit in all areas essential to the development of our cultural, economic and social potential.
Preserving the federal power to collect and spend taxes as proposed in the August 28 agreement means not only giving growth hormones to an exceedingly costly bureaucratic monster but also relinquishing to the federal Parliament, where we will always be a minority, the power to use our taxes to manipulate our development as it sees fit.
Canada must not be developed at the expense of Quebec and its people. We must say no to the unacceptable proposals before us.

speakeroldname: Mr. Marcel R. TVemblay (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, dear colleagues, dear fellow citizens who are listening to the debates in this House, I must tell you that it is a great privilege for me to have this opportunity to publicly voice my opinion regarding the Charlottetown agreement.
As we all know this unanimous agreement was reached by the leaders of this country after incredible efforts and long negotiations reflecting a sense of belonging to Canada and most of all in keeping with the democratic principles so essential to the survival of a people.
As the former UN Secretary-General, Mr. Javier Perez de Cuellar, said yesterday, our respect for democracy is an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Indeed this Canada where every one is free to express their opinion without having to retort to violence or being its victim is well worth our making together all possible efforts to preserve it. This is really the raison d'etre of the present agreement.
Did you ever wonder why so many people want to become Canadians, Mr. Speaker? The answer to this
Government Orders
question is obvious. A country is a whole, a family. And as in any family, each member has his or her own peculiarities, expectations, needs and idiosyncrasies. If we thought of splitting up whenever there was a disagreement, where would Canadian families be? For me, this agreement is evidence of the necessary adjustments we have to make to allow for the evolution of our community, and we can do it through dialogue and sometimes compromise.
Perfection does not exist in every day life. It is impossible for everything to be perfect in a country, but there are enough positive things to keep it whole and agree to make the necessary changes as we go along.
For far too long we have been talking about constitutional reform without ever reaching an agreement which would allow us to channel our energy toward other important issues. I think that we have done it this time. Canadians, just like us, want to resolve this issue. Ask manufacturers, workers, seniors, mothers or our young people. We are mature enough to finally decide to stand strong and united in this country which is the envy of the world.
The words diversity, distinct character, dignity, honour, compromise, concession, success, strength, nationalism and patriotism are not incompatible, lb the contrary, they are the very essence of the human being, a constructive not destructive human being.
One has to strive for a country of such quality and it is now time for the Canadian people to make their choice known. I therefore commit myself from now on to making sure that my fellow citizens in Quebec-Est will be able to make their choice an informed one and to providing them with all necessary information.
I will explain the content of this agreement to them: the will to recognize the inherent right to self-government of the aboriginal peoples, a concept of justice and equity; the Senate reform, a concept of efficiency; all the implications of the Canada clause; the social and economic union; the changes affecting the Supreme Court; the representation in the House of Commons; the First Ministers' Conferences; the amending formula and any other questions. I will inform them.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
The cultural wealth of Canada is recognized all over the world. We are lucky enough to have this great territory to share with people who profess different values, have various ways of thinking and speak different languages. That reality must be entrenched once and for all in our Constitution so that we never have to relive the negative experiences of the past.
This being said, I must add that my intention is not to delve into the past; I am eager to go forward and to prepare the future for our senior citizens, for our own generation and for our children and grandchildren. All parents at one time say to a child: "don't get angiy that way, try to understand your brothers; go kiss and make up".
This sentence is an exact image of what Canadians are: peaceloving people who care for the quality of life they have acquired over the years in this country which is dear to them.
I want to remind my fellow citizens that the agreement reached in Charlottetown is the necessary tool for this renewal that can no longer wait. I do not want my family to be subjected to a weakening of any kind. This is why in 19841 decided to run in my riding of Quebec-Est. At that time I put all my faith in the Prime Minister. Some were talking about a "risk worth taking". As for me, I preferred to talk about this very determined man with an incredible sense of honor. The years have shown that I only knew part of the strength of that man and I want to pay tribute to him today for all that he has done for us and for our country.
I will end with this motto: Vox populi, vox dei. [English]

Mr. Speaker, this is an unusual debate in that apart from my friends in the far comer off to the right, there is not a great deal of debate and yet, as every member would recognize on all sides, the issues that we are discussing are of the greatest importance to this country and to its future.
I have not participated in every constitutional debate in this House, most people will be glad to know, but I have participated in a few over a great number of years. Every time one of these debates occurs, it strikes me
what an unusual country we have. It was a bit more than 20 years ago when Mr. Bourassa, in his first appearance as the Prime Minister of Quebec, appeared on Quebec television and said: "Quebec, ce n'est pas une province comme les autres."
After the events of the last few years, as we have debated all these constitutional issues, you could say: "Canada ce n'est pas un pays comme les autres. When you recognize the degree to which this country can engage itself and the kinds of discussions that have gone on at every level, from the level of first ministers down to the average citizen, you realize that we are a very strange country indeed. It is not just that we have such an enormous land mass, the largest now in the world and covering so many time zones, so many types of geography and different communities, but it is a bit staggering to realize that for the first almost 100 years of our existence we did not have a flag, a national anthem or even our own Constitution.
We functioned from 1867 to the early 1960s without any of the trappings that most self-respecting nations had for themselves. It was some time in the 1920s that we started to be concerned about such things. It was with the meetings that took place and the Statute of Westminster in the 1930s when we got serious about having our own Constitution and perhaps ultimately having a flag which we got in 1964. We got around to ratifying O Canada in 1980. We ultimately, with a great deal of turmoil, brought the Constitution to Canada, retrieving the British North America Act and writing a charter of rights 10 years ago in 1982.
However, as we all recognize, the great element that was missing was, if one can put it this way, the oldest colonized part of the country which was Quebec which, in a formal sense, from the government of that day, did not participate in the constitutional accord. Therefore we spent another decade finally closing the loop.
Nobody should doubt that both in the Meech Accord and in the Charlottetown accord our first item of business was including all the provinces in this agreement.
We were told over the last year that this is a Canada round, and it very much is a Canada round, but it is crucially important that if the Constitution of 1982 is to
September 10, 1992

be the Constitution of Canada, the province of Quebec be fully a part of that accord.
Second, there was the concern for a whole variety of related matters affecting the functioning of the federal Parliament, the nature of the Senate, institutions related to it, economic and social concerns. A certain measure of progress has been made in finally democratizing the Senate, something that should have been done a very long time ago. How effective it will be remains to be seen.
I want to say that for my mind Canada has again broken new ground among the Commonwealth of nations by recognizing and righting a wrong that took place here half a millennia ago, beginning with 1492.
Finally in 1992 it is recognizing that the aboriginal peoples and all their various communities are equal citizens of this country, even to the point of describing what is being agreed to here as a new third order of government.
There is a great deal of concern around the world about what has happened over the decades and the centuries to aboriginal peoples. Nowhere has this been more poignantly revealed than in the events of Africa and the continuing events that are searing the face of southern Africa.
The recognition of aboriginal peoples as being a third order of government is absolutely crucial to the renewal of Canada and to the example Canada gives to the nations of the world. I have spent a bit of time in constitutional committees. I could spend many hours pointing out in the 60 clauses of the Charlottetown accord the weaknesses, the dangers and where the problems lie. I have to say that if Canadians from coast to coast to coast do not find this an important step forward in the history of our country, then I am a monkey's uncle because I believe that what has been achieved by first ministers, by aboriginal representatives, by a host of officials and experts is an important contribution in the 125th year of this nation's history.
I will be urging every one of my constituents in downtown Toronto and in any part of this country where I speak to say yes on October 26, a date that Canada has with history.
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, the last time I participated in a debate dealing with the Constitution of Canada was in 1990 on the Meech Lake accord.
Up to 1987 and leading up to the establishment of Meech Lake, there were legitimate problems in Canada. Among the major problems that we were facing and have been facing was western alienation. The west was feeling that it did not really participate in the life of the nation, that all the big decisions were made in central Canada, particularly in Ontario and Quebec, a feeling that anything that the central government did was always done for the benefit of Quebec.
We had the problem of ignoring the First Nations as part of the Canadian Constitution. We also had the problem of the formal recognition on integration of Quebec into Canada.
The perception that grew about these problems was that they became more aggravated. Economic disparities became greater. Immigration brought people into Canada whose cultural backgrounds were certainly different from Canadians who were here. The injustices to First Nations were totally unacceptable to a vast number of Canadians. Changes were in order. We had to do something about this.
Those changes were not to the basic principles of what built this country. We were not going to change the principle of tolerance. That was not going to change. The ability to respect differences was not going to change. It was not going to touch the principle of accommodation which is the invitation to share the welcoming, to be part of the whole. It was not going to change the principle of fairness, a recognition that human rights as well as collective rights and individuals rights have to be respected and that we have to make sure that the people of this country can share in the production of the wealth of the country. There was also a need to update the social contract. This arrangement would allow the citizens to share more fully in the wealth that they helped to produce. The attempt was made in 1987 with Meech Lake, and it failed. I supported Meech Lake and I have no regrets about having done so. What followed the failure of Meech Lake was a long and elaborate process to come to grips with these problems that we were facing. It was long and protracted, and that is typically Canadian.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
It is the way we do things in Canada: millions of hours of meetings, dozens of committees, hundreds of reports, thousands of publications, dozens of forums, and hundreds of debates. Hundreds of thousands of citizens were consulted, hundreds of millions of dollars were spent, I would like to think invested.
Not one bullet was fired. Not one person was killed. Not one life was lost in this emotional, draining and sometimes very boring exercise. That is our nature in Canada. We are looked on as people who would rather talk than fight. We are people who are seen as those who would rather spend hours and hours debating how many angels would dance on the head of a pin than put on the boxing gloves and take on somebody.
We are known as a nation of compromisers. In fact, there is the notion that Canada was built on compromise. There is a lot to be said for that, when you examine the history of the formation of Canada. That is the price we pay to be-
The best.

That is the price we pay. We do not mind people making comments about us, about how boring we are, about how we would rather talk than fight, and so on. That is the price we pay and that is a price we are willing pay. It reflects a very unique heritage. It recognizes that we have different groups in this country and that we have to let groups have a chance to say something.
When governments do not listen to what the groups have to say governments find out in a hurry that the groups do not want deals cut behind closed doors. They want a more open process.
Of course there are short cuts. If people do not like the process that we have been following there are short cuts and they can follow those short cuts. Those short cuts are Lebanon, Yugoslavia, Tajikistan, Nagorno-Karabakh, and Georgia. If people want the short cuts they can go for them.
We have chosen our way. We have chosen to respect the principles that built this country which meant that we have to go through this process of consultation. What we have is the consensus report, third revision. Is that not typically Canadian? We are not over it. This is only one
of the many steps before we get to the end of the process.
This package represents a compromise. Even the late Senator Eugene Forsey underestimated Canadians' ability to compromise. I want to quote something he said in his presentation at the time of the Meech Lake accord in 1987. He said: "The chances of any amendment being adopted even under the seven province formula are virtually nil. Ontario and Quebec will never accept any reduction in the number of senators from either province nor will the Atlantic provinces any reduction in their quotas. The House of Commons will never accept any change that gives the Senate more real power. The reformers will never accept any change that does not. Under the unanimous consent formula, the chances of change are microscopic".
What we have here is an agreement for change. The late Eugene Forsey underestimated the ability of Canadians to compromise because I believe the document that we have before us and that we are debating is really a compromise.
How does the compromise agreement deal with the problems I have listed? What were they? Do you remember, Madam Speaker, the concern for First Nations to be finally recognized as important and integral to Canada? The First Nations are now going to be placed four square in the Constitution. That is a big step forward. That alone merits very positive support from Canadians.
The concerns of western Canadians have been advanced. I do not think they had been fully met. They may not be satisfied with respect to the Triple-E Senate which was their big push, but I think their concerns have been addressed to some extent and they have been advanced. I would think they would like the proposed agreement rather than the present system.
Quebec is recognized as a distinct society and its ability to be a master in its own universe has been consolidated, advanced and enhanced.
The Constitution is only a framework of how we relate to each other, how we govern ourselves and how we manage our affairs. But a country is more than a framework, just as a human body is more than a skeleton. A country is made up of people, people who have dreams, who have hopes, who have aspirations. They have basic needs: bread and butter, security and shelter.
September 10, 1992

Government Orders
While we Canadians have been in the back of the airplane discussing constitutional renewal, we have left the airplane in the hands of financial interests both national and international. They have been only too pleased to continue signing real estate deals, signing trade agreements, shuffling paper, putting money into their pockets, building their own and strapping on their own golden parachutes in case the airplane goes down, while large numbers of Canadians have become unemployed and have been thrown on to the welfare rolls of the municipalities and the provinces and on to unemployment insurance.
Those skyrocket and the victims are blamed for having put these funds into deficit. Imagine the unemployment insurance fund for the first six months of this year is already $10 billion in the hole.
While we have been continuing our discussions in the back of the plane we have watched the deindustrialization of our nation. What good is it if we defeat this agreement and continue discussing constitutional change in the hope of getting the perfect constitution and everyone saying: "This is the perfect constitution that I support" and we inherit at the end of it an economic wasteland for a country?
I am not supporting the agreement because it is my ideal. I suppose the only way it would be my ideal is if I had written the bloody thing. I am supporting it because it is the best we are going to get for now. We have established in this agreement what I consider to be the most important elements. With this agreement we can now hold governments accountable for what I consider to be important things to the people of the country. I want to read the things that I consider important: providing throughout Canada a health care system that is comprehensive, universal, portable, publicly administered and accessible; providing adequate social services and benefits to ensure all individuals resident in Canada have reasonable access to housing, food and other basic necessities; providing high quality primary and secondary education to all individuals resident in Canada and ensuring reasonable access to post-secondary education; and protecting the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively.
This commitment is now being made. Look at the fuss we have in Ontario over the labour bill. Now we are establishing a national goal to which all the provinces subscribe.
I also consider protecting, preserving and sustaining the integrity of the environment for present and future generations to be important.
The policy objectives continue, and here is my favourite. Now we have written into the Constitution the objective or the goal of full employment. No longer will a government sitting across the aisle be allowed to use the unemployed in this country as cannon fodder in some war against inflation, recession or whatever else.
Ensuring that all Canadians have a reasonable standard of living and ensuring sustainable and equitable development are also important.
Those are the issues. Once we have disposed of this agreement, those are the issues on which we should concentrate all our efforts, our minds, and our strength. Those things affect Canadians very sensitively, such as the right to a job. We have put those things on hold for the last couple of years. We have left all these things to John Crowe, the international bankers, the domestic bankers, and others like them. They have been only too happy to accommodate us and now we are living with 12 per cent unemployment in this nation. Our people are taxed beyond their limits.
It is nothing to crow about.

There is certainly nothing to crow about, absolutely nothing to crow about.
As a social democrat I am supporting the agreement because I believe those things identify clearly the kind of co-operative federalism we have always talked about.
We are putting in place a clear injunction to ourselves as lawmakers that we are indeed our brother's keeper. We do have a responsibility for each other. On that basis I believe this agreement is worthy of support and I intend to work in my riding for the yes position on this agreement.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased in the final hours of this debate on the national referendum question to join with colleagues

September 10,1992
Government Orders
from the three national parties in indicating that I will be supporting the yes vote.
I have been encouraged in the last number of days by the numbers of calls that have come to my constituency office in Waterloo, Ontario. They are from people, many of whom come from a multicultural background in an area that is largely German speaking, a high percentage, wanting to know more about the deal, wanting to know how they can be a part of sending messages of the importance they see in Canada.
I think of this year's largest ever, most vibrant Canada Day celebration. I think of the expressions of affection for Canada that have come largely because we have begun through the process of the Spicer commission, through the hearings of our parliamentary committees and other fora, to focus on what Canada is. We each have our own reasons for voting yes. As I speak in the Chamber tonight. I think of my days in student political life in Canada-

I have developed a close friendship with two members of the House of Commons, the members for Saint-Denis and Papineau, that offers me an opportunity to understand the essence and the spirit of the province of Quebec.

I think of my time with CUSO looking at Canada from Africa. I think also of the importance of English and language in that great continent.

I think how very important it is for the development of Africa and for numerous young men and women who work there, thanks to CIDA and to other governmental programs, I think about the Canadian contribution to development.

Along with the hon. member for Rosedale, I think of the contribution of the churches, English and French, with their connections in the developing world and in Eastern Europe. I think of Canada's partnership and leadership. I think of the challenges facing our world and I recognize what Canada has done. I feel that the best days are still ahead of us.
The great Canadian, Joseph Howe, used to say: "Brag about your country, boys". We all know we have not been much accustomed to making this sort of speech either here in the House, in committee or in the countiy. I am looking forward to going across Waterloo region and other parts of the countiy to encourage Canadians to see ourselves as others see us.
In the last five years, as a member of our Canadian delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations, I have had the opportunity to see how others see us, how they feel about us, our contribution, what they feel about our ability to deal with minorities, our sensitivity to the kinds of world problems that are on the news every few moments.
I want to say a word about Canadians serving abroad. I noticed in today's media that 30,000 Canadians who are imprisoned in provincial and federal penitentiaries will have the vote. Members of our foreign service, members of our military, members of CIDA and development staff who are overseas and are based in Quebec have come to my attention.

'Hiese bureaucrats are officially domiciled in Quebec. They have lived in Europe and worked for the United Nations for more than two years and they do not have the right to vote.

I asked the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs. I asked the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for External Affairs if they will not review this because there are no prouder Canadians than those who serve overseas for us in our embassies and peacekeeping forces. If they have been at Lahr for a number of years and have suddenly gone into Yugoslavia to be a part of that situation, why should they lose a vote?
We have time to get the apparatus in place. Let there be consultations. There are many in Central America and many in eastern and central Europe who look to Canada and say: "We feel that you can live together". At recent conferences of the United Nations development program, people came again and again and said: "We are glad to hear your three parties have a positive proposal to put forward. We are with you and we want you to succeed".
September 10, 1992

The external affairs committee visited the former Soviet Union, Russia and Ukraine. We saw what we have to offer. We know the links in Canada, people who have their roots there. We looked at southern Africa and tabled a report in June. We saw what we can do with democratic institutions, respect for minority and the whole infrastructure role.
Let me say we have already looked at the ingredients which are part of the Charlottetown package, the importance of the recognition of Quebec as a distinct society, the aboriginals, the question of an elected and equal Senate and the new division of powers. Let me conclude by reflecting on this to Canadians as we gather to talk about our future. Let us reflect that when the Japanese want to learn about peacekeeping, they come to Canada; when the brave democrats of eastern Europe and Russia want to find out about parliaments, banks, stock markets and legal systems, they come to Canada; when Mikhail Gorbachev was Minister of Agriculture and wanted to improve Soviet farms, he came to Canada; when the Americans want to find out how to make health care more efficient and effective, they come to Canada; when the Namibians want expertise in municipal affairs, they come to Canada and to Kitchener-Waterloo; and, when South Africans, black or white, want to learn about elections that are fair, a new legal system that is just and modem, an economy that works, they come to Canada.
Canada is in the heart of all of us. Each of us has a different perspective of it. We have much and have given much; we have much to receive from the world. All of our futures are best off with a peaceful, just world. Canada has that reputation. The resources of English and French give us a unique position in the family of nations. I, for one, will be working to encourage a very positive yes vote in order that the legislature of Ontario may quickly pass it, along with the other legislatures, and we can move on to the important issue of jobs.

Madam Speaker, I am proud to be able to participate in this historic debate. During my eight years in this House there have been many important issues and bills discussed such as capital punishment and abortion. We voted to have a free trade agreement with the United States, and we voted to go to war last year in the gulf. In my opinion none of these debates or votes was as
Government Orders
vital as the issue we have been debating for the last few days, the future of this magnificent country, Canada.
On August 28 the Consensus Report on the Constitution was agreed to unanimously by the Prime Minister of Canada, the 10 provincial premiers, the leaders of our two territorial governments and the representatives of four aboriginal associations. The agreement by these 17 leaders culminates the most extensive consultation ever with Canadians. The agreement is not perfect. It does have some flaws. I am concerned, for instance, about the cost of the increased size of the House of Commons. I am not sure if the new Senate will be effective or if it will create legislative gridlock. I believe it is accurate to say that not one of the 17 leaders meeting in Charlottetown was totally satisfied with the agreement. This situation was expected if an agreement was to be achieved. There had to be understanding, compromise and a good spirit of give and take.
Now is the time to turn to the people of Canada. One of the main criticisms of the Meech Lake accord was that it was done by 11 men behind closed doors. This negotiation process, the Canada round, was just the opposite. As I said earlier, during the past two years we have witnessed the most extensive consultation with Canadians in the history of this great country. It is now appropriate and democratic to go back to the people for their say on this historic package of fundamental changes in our parliamentary system. Between now and October 26 Canadians will be asking questions and making comments. The greatest challenge we are faced with is communicating the essence and the highlights of this Charlottetown agreement so that Canadians can make an informed decision when they cast their vote.
I know there is a great deal of cynicism about the process. Some Canadians believe we have spent too much time on this issue. They believe we should be spending more time on economic issues and job creation measures. I agree these economic issues are of vital importance, but solving the constitutional impasse is crucial for resolving economic problems. The two are entwined.
The lack of constitutional agreement has created financial instability. Foreign and Canadian investors have put projects on hold. A positive resolution of the Constitution impasse will open the path and create a climate conducive to addressing the very real and pressing economic and social challenges facing Canada. As

September 10,1992
Government Orders
the Prime Minister said on September 8: "This agreement, if endorsed by the Canadian people and enshrined in our Constitution, will mark an accomplishment that has eluded many generations of Canadians and their elected representatives". I think it is useful to highlight some of the fundamental objectives that had to be attained in order to achieve a durable and lasting national reconciliation. For decades the western provinces have felt frustrated with their lack of power and influence on many major decisions made in central Canada. Atlantic Canada has had to deal with many aspects of economic disparity.
As the Prime Minister said, we must find a way to ensure that Quebecers, whose special character so enriches the distinctiveness of our national life, become willing and enthusiastic partners in Canada.
The voices and concerns of the people of the north and our aboriginal peoples had to be addressed in an understanding and compassionate manner. The time has come for Canadians to embrace the inherent right to self-government of aboriginal peoples.
In trying to achieve all of the above objectives, we must not ignore the frustrations and concerns of the people of Ontario, whose great contributions to the well-being of Canada are in my opinion sometimes either misconstrued or not recognized and appreciated.
I believe these fundamental objectives have been met. It is now time for Canadians to reflect on the proposals within the agreement, ask questions and discuss it with friends and neighbours.
I thought Peter Newman made a profound statement in a recent Maclean's article when he said:
The real issue of the October 26 referendum is deciding whether we have a future, not the shape of what that future might be.
A yes vote at least gives Canadians the chance to shape our future as a united countiy. A no vote does not. We have a great, tolerant, diverse, rich country that we must fight together to preserve. We must continue to be proud of Canada and all we have achieved since our birth as a nation.
Sir John A. Macdonald's words, spoken in 1861, ring equally true today:
Whatever you do, adhere to the union, we are a great country, and we shall become one of the greatest in the universe if we
preserve it; we shall sink into insignificance and adversity if we suffer it to be broken.
I understand the House will rise next week so that we can spend the next five weeks in our ridings talking with our constituents, listening to their views and answering their questions.
I plan to help organize a yes committee in Markham and in Whitchurch-Stouffville. These will be non-partisan committees comprised of concerned residents who will help co-ordinate activities.
Canadians must have the opportunity to arrive at the polls on October 26 in a position to make an informed and bold decision about this constitutional package and the future of Canada.
On October 26 I will be voting yes to a united Canada. I hope that our pride and confidence in the future of this great nation will encourage all Canadians to participate in this historic referendum and give a renewed Canada their enthusiastic stamp of approval.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to participate in this important and historic debate. I want to say from the outset that I intend to cast my vote with millions of other Canadians on October 26 for the yes side in this referendum campaign which will begin in a matter of days.
All across the country there are many voices, particularly the voices of the premiers who sat around the negotiating table, the voice of the Prime Minister and the leaders of the opposition parties that encourage us to examine constructively this Charlottetown accord. I hope Canadians will do that. They will find a document which I think reflects Canada, reflects the shared values of a nation that is diverse from sea to sea, that is different from sea to sea, but nevertheless holds in common a set of beliefs about ourselves as a people, how we organize ourselves and those things we believe to be important.
It reflects a spirit of generosity, a spirit of tolerance, a spirit of brotherhood and sisterhood that is unique among nations of the world and certainly must be seen to be unique among the nations of the world as we watch with anguish night after night the bombs in Beirut, the bullets in Bosnia and the starvation in Somalia.
September 10, 1992

We sit in the security and the comfort of our homes watching this horror. Much of the world is unveiling itself to us nightly on our televisions as we sit secure in our homes with the knowledge of the protections afforded to us in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
We have to reflect upon these values of being a Canadian. I want to say that something that has bothered me as a member of Parliament for a great many years about this constitutional debate, something that I think has to cease during the course of this referendum campaign, the tendency in this country to be asked to define ourselves and our role in Canada as if we in our respective communities or provinces were mere pieces on a Monopoly board.
If we were to believe those who would seek to divide us, there are no Canadians in this country called Canada. There are only Newfoundlanders, Nova Scotians, Ontarians, the people of British Columbia, Quebecers or Albertans. That is not true. For every voice that would ask us to examine this constitutional accord based on what it did for me in my back yard, I am convinced that there are 100 more in whose breast beats the heart of Canada.
I am a Newfoundlander, but let nobody marginalize me. Let nobody seek to reduce me. Let nobody seek to constrain my vision and my participation in this great experiment on the northern half of the North American continent to Newfoundland and Labrador, as wonderful as that is.
I take pride in all of this country. I have driven through the Rockies and their majesty. I have seen the great individualism of the people of British Columbia, their resilience and energy; people on the prairies; the great entrepreneurship of the great industrial heartland, Ontario; the uniqueness of that distinct society that is the people of Quebec and the rich tapestry of the colour and the energy of the people of Atlantic Canada. Every part of it is part of what I am. I am part of Canada.
I say to my fellow colleagues that if we ask the people of our ridings, the people of our constituencies, the people in the provinces from which we come to measure this accord on the basis of whether or not within our own back yard, whether it is our community, our town or our province, we somehow won a great victory, we came
Government Orders
away with a larger share of the national pie than our neighbour, then every one of us is doomed to come to the conclusion that we failed. But if our vision is bigger than our own back yard and if our imagination is broader than the boundaries of something called a province, if we can see, feel and participate in this referendum campaign as Canadians, if we can see beyond our disappointments, whether individual members, government or political parties, and see the opportunity that still resides in this fantastic country, I am convinced Canadians from coast to coast will say yes to the constitutional renewal of Canada.
There is something else I want to say because it has to be said. One of the reasons I am going to vote not with resignation, not with it is the best we can do attitude but with enthusiasm for this accord is that I believe it is important that we recognize the people of Quebec.
There are a few million francophones in a sea of 300 million francophones who need to know that their language and culture is secure and protected and they need to know they can look to the national Parliament, to the national government here in Ottawa and not just to their government in Quebec City to protect that language and culture.
There is provision in the Charlottetown accord so my fellow Canadians, francophones in Quebec, can count on their national government, national institutions, national courts, national Constitution, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the good will and generosity of their fellow Canadians to ensure that in a sea of anglophones the Quebec people, their language and their culture are protected. That is the spirit of generosity and tolerance I talked about.
I will not attempt to repeat the analysis done by those who have spoken before me of the individual components of this package. Let me just repeat again that if what we seek in this accord is perfection it will not be found because if perfection had been the measure of success of the British North American Act, the British North American Act of 1867 would have been a failure.
If perfection was the requirement of the Constitution Act, 1982, then the Constitution Act, 1982, would have been a failure. If perfection is what we expected in our families, in our spouses, in our children, in our friends, in our jobs, or in ourselves our lives could be nothing but failure.

September 10,1992
Government Orders
If we see as we must this accord, this compromise, this honourable compromise and a spirit of fairness, balance and tolerance, we will see it as the basis upon which to put this debate behind us, to renew this country constitutionally and to help it achieve its full potential as we march as we do toward the year 2000.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise in this debate to support the referendum question and the Charlottetown accord of August 28. I do so with enthusiasm and commitment.
It is true, as many other members have said, that this accord is not perfect, but neither was the the British North American Act of 1867. It went to the Supreme Court and the Privy Council thousands of times. I am not overestimating that, thousands of times. That Constitution and the society it founded, the country it founded, lasted for 125 years.
If the people in 1867 had nit-picked at that Constitution like many of our people nit-picked at the Meech accord and at this accord, we would never have had a country. They had the political will to form a country and to adopt a Constitution despite its imperfections.
I say to this House that despite some imperfection in this accord, it represents many substantial gains for many communities in this country. What are they? To begin with, for the first time constitutionally we have recognized the inherent right of the aboriginal peoples to govern themselves. Those are landmark, world precedent, provisions. We should be proud of them.
If it were only for those provisions alone in the accord I would go to the wall in support of that accord because those are so important all by themselves.
For the first time constitutionally we have recognized the minority language communities in our Constitution with a commitment to their vitality and development. I say for the first time we have recognized the official language communities because in the Constitution of 1867 and in the Constitution of 1982 we recognized the right of individuals to go to court in English and French, to have schools in English and French, but we do not refer to the communities, to the collective rights.
This is the first time that we have said we recognize the collective rights of the communities, the francophone communities outside of Quebec, and the anglophone community in Quebec.
I must remind the House that there are now over one million francophones living outside of Quebec in this country. There are more francophones outside Quebec than there were in Quebec in 1867. There are 800,000 or more anglophones living in Quebec, which is more people than many of the provinces.
Again, these provisions represent a substantial gain for those communities.
Third, the Charlottetown accord contains several provisions that recognize the distinct society of Quebec and assure not only its continued existence but its epanouisse-ment and development.
This accord, without doubt, contains much more than the Meech accord to protect the unique position of Quebec. I cannot understand why those who supported the Meech accord, like the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean and the other members of the Bloc Quebecois who at that time were in the Conservative Party, would now attack this accord when it contains much more than Meech.
If we put the Meech accord side by side with this you would see that eveiything that was in Meech is here, plus the guarantee for Quebec to keep 25 per cent of the seats in the House of Commons-which it historically has always had more or less so this is not something new, but it is now written in the Constitution-plus a guarantee that they will have one-third of the judges in the Supreme Court of Canada, plus a veto with other provinces on changes to national institutions, plus a double majority in the Senate to protect language and culture at the federal level, plus greater clarification and consolidation of provincial powers.
Again there are definite gains, not all that people in Quebec would like but substantial gains to protect the language and culture and the future of Quebec within Confederation.
Fourth, this accord gives more clout to the west and to the Atlantic provinces through a reformed Senate. It is true that it is not a Triple-E Senate, much to the disappointment of many people in the west. I would have supported a Triple-E Senate. However, it is a two and a half E Senate. It is an elected Senate. It is an equal
September 10, 1992

Senate and it is almost an effective Senate. That remains to be seen.
It is true that the Senate will only have a total veto on matters relating to resources and on matters relating to the French language and culture, but its power to force joint sessions with the House of Commons on other matters will have more significance than many people expect.
Right now the present Senate has full legal powers to veto every bill that comes from this place, but it is rarely done because they are not elected and because they do not have political credibility. They have full legal powers but no political credibility.
Under the Charlottetown accord the new Senate will have less legal power but much greater political power because they are fully elected and there are only six senators from each province. It is my sense that when the 24 senators from the west, with others, turn down a House of Commons bill the government will take that message very seriously and will attempt to work out compromises with the Senate rather than force a vote in a joint session in the House of Commons. I am willing to bet that we will see more compromises worked out behind the scenes than we would otherwise.
Madam Speaker, you are signalling that my time is up.
I must say that seven minutes for such an important subject is not enough, but let me conclude.
While this is not a perfect document it is a definite improvement for most Canadians and it does not diminish the rights of anyone. It is time to stop nit-picking. It is time to get on with other economic and social matters. This accord demonstrates that as Canadians living in this great land we have much more that unites us as individuals than that divides us. What is required is vision and political will, and a vote yes on October 26.

Madam Speaker, as the member for that wonderful riding of Richmond- Wolfe in the Eastern Townships, I would like to say how much I appreciate the agreement arrived at by the Premiers because it is good for all of Canada, for all the regions of Canada and especially for Quebec. Therefore, I will encourage my constituents to vote yes in favour of that agreement.
Government Orders
I am tempted to list here all the reasons I will do so, but since time is short and we must compromise, I will give my colleague, the member for Verdun, the opportunity to follow up and complete my comments in a few minutes.
However, I will mention one attitude I believe to be unfortunate and harmful in this debate which is about to begin. I am thinking here about that climate of verbal violence, about those insults flying around, particularly in Quebec. I find it inadmissible, when dealing with such a fundamental issue that people, political leaders, representatives of the nation be so disgraceful, trading insults and spouting abuse at each other. I feel this is a very disturbing start to such an important debate.
My second comment is this: I disapprove, of course, of all the critics coming from the opponents to the agreement, those who favour the no. Let me give you an example. They condemn the government and the provincial premiers for not having a legal document to offer. I almost feel like asking them right out if there were legal documents for the 1980 referendum; at least let me remind them of what the situation was. I would say that the text of the question itself left the debate wide open and gave enormous leeway to any government taking office after sovereignty.
It is therefore unacceptable, that we be condemned because the debate is not supported by legal documents. Let me give you another example. Quite often business people, who are experienced and who have everything to lose because they have a fortune and they have investments will not even read a contract and the legal documents because they trust the person they have chosen to represent them, whether a notary or a lawyer. This criticism is therefore unacceptable.
There is also the so-called vagueness of the question. In my opinion the question is a lot more precise since it asks us to approve a project, a contract that is already on the table, which was not always the case in previous consultations as far as I know. This is a lot closer to something that we can evaluate concretely.
Moreover, this proposal can be improved over time. This brings me to make the following statement. We are criticized because the agreement provides for future

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
consultations which could give rise to disputes, but this is precisely what is good about it. In the present Constitution unanimity is required to be able to make changes with the result that attempts were often made but always in vain because we could never have unanimity. This agreement, however, allows us to improve the content. In a federation, to revise a contract between partners every five or ten years is the least we can do. These criticisms are not justified in my opinion.
Some members of the no side contradict each other. Recently we heard that to say no would not necessarily mean we are saying yes to sovereignty.
But it is rather strange to read this in today's issue of La Presse about the leader of the Bloc Quebecois: "The Bloc Quebecois leader said in an interview that sovereig-nists will not be bound by a Quebec vote in favour of the provisional constitutional accord". Mr. Bouchard goes on to say: "Legally it would be binding", referring to a vote in favour of the agreement.
If 50 per cent of the voters plus one are in favour it is a decision. Politically though it is different. You can see that the no which Mr. Parizeau said was not a yes to sovereignty seems to be interpreted differently in another statement made by the Bloc leader who said: "Should the yes win, we will keep going and consider that sovereignty will come back".
I see that the clock is ticking away and, as in any agreement between partners, I was willing to make a compromise. I wish to inform you that the member for Verdun-Saint-Paul will take over from me. But I urge the people from Quebec to avoid this climate of verbal violence and insults, to remain calm, to be informed, to read and to make the decision that will preserve the dignity and the honour of Quebec, that is to vote yes.

Madam Speaker, I am very happy to be able to say a few words on this agreement, especially in front of this very personal audience.
As you are no doubt aware we have always had a touch of nationalism in Quebec, but as it turns out one cannot
be a nationalist any more unless he or she belongs to the category of nationalists who advocate sovereignty.
I know from personal experience what it is to be a nationalist advocating sovereignty. To some extent that is why I sit on the other side of the House now.
Just yesterday the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean was saying that he would vote no because he wants a better future for his children, an easier and better life, and he is willing to take the chance.
I agree with that to some extent but my position is just as good. The difference is that, in his mind, his children have a dual nationality. As you know, having married an American, his children will have the choice of settling here or in the U.S. Mine are living here.
They will live here all the time and have to face things as they come. When you go to Quebec you meet sovereignists like the leader of the opposition, Mr. Parizeau, who tells the people that sovereignty has been put aside and so on. I have also had the chance to meet him.
What he is saying is quite simple. He will tell you that the people do not count for much. What is important is to gain power and to do what you want with the people. On the other hand, Mr. Bernard Landry, his right-hand man, is promising jobs for everyone.
Everybody in an independent Quebec will have a job, he said, but what he really wanted was Parizeau's job. So we are faced with a power struggle within the no umbrella group. We in the yes umbrella group are seen as traitors because we want a better future for our children and their children.
Why should we not have the right to a strong Quebec as well as a united Canada? Who is going to deny us that? Really, nobody can deny us that because what people truly want is change. They want to focus on the economy. They need to feel secure. They need to talk about something else.
The agreement is certainly good. You can argue all the legal points. You can show all the advantages. There will always be some people who are for it and others against it. In the end what people want is someone they can trust.
September 10, 1992

For 11 months I sat on the other side and there is one person I have seen get up and fight for Quebec: the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister always believed that it was possible for Quebecers to have a future within Canada.
The reason I came back is that I trusted one person. The offers we get today are perfectly acceptable. The majority of the people are willing to accept them because they want, on October 27, to be able to work, to be able to move on to something else, to set the Constitution aside, because nobody lives on Constitution.
There are those who say that, on our side, some speak from both sides of their mouths, that the member for Roberval says that he has had enough with the Constitution or that Senator Gerald Beaudoin says that it will go on. Sure enough, Senator Beaudoin will have less work once the constitutional issue is settled. As for the member for Roberval he will resume his activities as minister of National Health and Welfare; that gives him the Opportunity to promote something, to allow people to succeed, to live.
For me, it is rather simple. Ayes is a yes to renewal, to progress and to a new life. Personally, what I want is stability; it is political stability that people need. Let them be the judge later on when general elections are called; the choice will be theirs. Right now what we need is for the economy to recover. For that every Canadian should say yes to the agreement.
What also prompted me to rise tonight is that I saw on television the press conference given by a prominent leader who cannot even make up his own mind. He had to have an 800 line to talk to his followers and get an idea of what he was supposed to do. The Reform Party of Canada said it is against it because people called in at their own expense to voice their opposition to the agreement. The party could not cover people's expenses. People had to call at their expense to give their opinion, to say wether they were for it or against it. It is an extremist like him who will be one of the leaders of the no side. We can imagine the wonderful team they will make, the reformist extremist in the west and the sovereignty extremist in Quebec will take the same side on a question people at large have already a very good understanding of. They know very well that saying yes to the agreement is saying yes to stability and solidarity;
Government Orders
they will thus show that they understand we are teaming up together.
There will always be problems between provinces. In Quebec, for once, we gain something definite. People tell us that Mr. Bourassa did not do well in the negotiations. Could anybody tell us what other premier has succeeded in reaching an agreement with all other Canadian premiers? None. No other Quebec premier was able to come to an agreement with his counterparts in the rest of the country. Mr. Bourassa is the first one to do so. He is the first one to present an acceptable offer which he is ready to defend before the people. We must not forget that it is not the big guns of the federal government who will sell the agreement in Quebec. It is Mr. Bourassa who has agreed to present the proposal to the people and defend it.
During this referendum campaign we will stand behind him and provide him with all the information we can get on our side. We are going to build. People on the no side are destructive. They do not realize that, right now, people are not in a destructive mood. The silent majority is listening. It can clearly see direct attacks on issues that are totally irrelevant. They are free to launch personal attacks against the Prime Minister or Mr. Bourassa, but they should not confuse that with the referendum question or the issue of sovereignty or any other issue. There will always be political points to make.
I think this matter is important for the people. As far as I am concerned, I will ask the people in my riding of Verdun-Saint-Paul to vote for the renewal of Canada on October 26, to vote for an economic renewal so that future generations will have a chance to succeed in this world of ours that needs unity. I hope October 27 will be the beginning of a new era.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to say a few words tonight, although there will not be many because of the hour, concerning the Charlottetown agreement.
It seems to me that this agreement which was brought together after massive consultation across the country, and with the participation of the 10 premiers and the Prime Minister, represents a very good compromise for our country.

September 10, 1992
Government Orders
The miracle is that this compromise was reached. It seems to me that during the next several weeks we are going to have a chance to put forth our vision of Canada and Confederation. It represents a compromise in many directions and for that reason many members of the House have many qualms or concerns about individual parts of it.
However, at the end of the day we have to ask ourselves whether we want more consultation. Do we want the kinds of negotiations that we have been going through for the past year to continue? What are the consequences for our great nation? We know that they are very serious.
As I said, it is not a perfect document but it is the kind of compromise which has kept our country together for these many 125 years which we celebrate this year. Most of us believe that a failure in this referendum that will take place on October 26 would have the most serious consequences our nation could ever face.
Therefore I vote for this motion. I work for this Charlottetown consensus document and I hope that other members of the House will do the same.
